story:
Who We Are

RealLivePeople is a Philadelphia-based dance company that explores human experiences through firsthand stories and unspoken gestures; we focus on the spaces between, the quick look away and the light tap on the shoulder. Our work strives to balance inventive, athletic movement with poignant and provocative interactions that resonate with an audience. We tackle our subject matter from multiple perspectives, collaborating with composers, artists and filmmakers and even incorporating our audience’s opinions and stories into the work in real time. For us the work is about being human onstage—part performance, part real-life.

Would I lie to you?

We recently spent a week in the woods of northern New Jersey in a residency made possible by White Pines Productions, and what we re-discovered there is simple. We really like what we do. A valuable affirmation, yes? However, what was so incredible about that week was the time and space it afforded us to really dig into this new project as an ensemble.

'Would I lie to you?', like previous work by RealLivePeople, is an exploration of our sense of identity and common humanity. But this time it’s all about lying: who we lie to, when we lie most often and how we feel about it.

Rather than asking these personal questions to strangers we’ve stayed a bit closer to home: each of the dancers tracked his or her lies and reported them back to the group. From there I, Gina, conducted an interview with each dancer about his or her lying habits – the text from these interviews forms a large portion of the sound score for the piece.

What we’ve learned so far is this: pretty much everyone lies all the time but we feel really differently about it. Some dancers believe that their lives would be better if they never lied while others believe that lying is a necessary part of many of their relationships and interactions – it keeps thing cordial. There are also discussions about cheating, familial patterning, text/email deceit, chronic exaggeration and long term self-delusion. It’s kind of juicy.

We dance to the sound of ourselves talking about what liars we are. We follow verbal improvisation structures that often reveal surprising truths about a dancer in real time. We ask audience members to anonymously submit a lie they've told, and we make a dance about it. Oh, and there’s a lot of exciting, ambitious and full-bodied dancing.

Your Help

We are a small, young, talented dance company. We have the drive, the organizational abilities and the artistic expertise to make this show a success. We are presenting 'Would I lie to you?' as part of the Philadelphia Fringe Festival, and as with any self-presented show, we must cover every cost ourselves. 

This year is our first receiving funding from both the Philadelphia Cultural Fund and the Samuel S. Fels Fund, and we are more than grateful for their confidence in this project. The entire budget is approximately $14,000. We have already raised over 35% of the money through the generous support of the above organizations, and, to be safe, we are only budgeting on 25% of our income coming from ticket sales. Will you help us cover the rest? Your support will go to important, real things:

  • Artist fees for the dancers: Gina Hoch-Stall, Drew Kaiser, Megan Mazarick, Sara Nye, Adrian Plascencia, Megan Quinn

  • Costumes and the work of our talented costume designer Michelle Yeager

  • Rented lights and the work of Maria Shaplin, our innovative lighting designer

  • Other crucial staff: Dramaturg Jenna Stelmok, Technical Director A.J. Garrigus, Stage Manager Angie Coleman, photography and videography services

  • Space rental for performance

We chose IndieGoGo because it ensures that your donations are tax-deductible through our fiscal sponsor, Fractured Atlas. We also tried to create perks that both acknowledge you and invite you to share in our world. But we know that you'll most likely help because you believe in this project so we want to assure you, it's worth believing in.

The Impact

As a small company we often face challenges with funding and scheduling but what we do not lack is talent, creativity and an eye for making dance exciting to watch. 'Would I lie to you?' is by far our most ambitious and exciting project to date. The act of giving towards this project tells us, “Yes, I affirm that this sounds interesting, and yes, I believe is it worthwhile doing, and yes, I think that you as artists should make more work like this.” So, thank you for that vote of confidence, confidence in what we're doing now and where we could go in the future. Really. We're not lying about that part. We are truly grateful.

Other Ways You Can Help

1. Tell Aunt Millie: Do you have an aunt in Minneapolis that loves to support artistic endeavors? Send her our way!

2. Come see the show: We would LOVE to see you in the audience of one of the shows! That way, you'll be able to describe it in detail for Aunt Millie at Thanksgiving this year.

Performances:

WOULD I LIE TO YOU?

The Latvian Society, 531 N. 7th street (7th and Spring Garden)

Friday September 5: 7 & 9pm

Saturday September 6: 7, 9 & 11pm

Sunday September 7: 5 & 7pm

Tuesday September 9: 7pm

Wednesday September 10: 7pm

Tickets available HERE

RealLivePeople is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the purposes of RealLivePeople must be made payable to Fractured Atlas and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

Note: Donating does not also secure you a ticket. Tickets are purchased separately.

story:
We're commissioning Veda Hille and Amiel Gladstone, members of the creative team behind A Craigslist Cantata, to develop a new musical entitled Onegin. Adapted from the classic Russian verse novel by Alexander Pushkin and the opera by Tchaikovsky, Onegin is a story about a group of young friends whose bright futures take a dark turn when an innocent flirtation sparks dangerous jealousy.

Right now, Onegin has just wrapped up its fourth series of workshops, with the aim of completing the script and score. Next up, the team will be working on the staging of the play, which will be designed to create an engrossing and captivating audience experience, and to bring a contemporary style and tone to 19th century Russia.

Onegin has already won the 2014 Stage West Pechet Family Musical Award from the Playwrights Guild of Canada for the best new musical in development! We love what we have heard so far, and you will too. Watch our video to see clips from the workshop, and to learn more about this project.

We Need Your Help

While the new work has already come a long way, there is still a long way to go! Musicals are more expensive to stage than any other type of theatre. They need twice the expertise, twice the amount of people involved, and often take twice as long to produce. It's a collaborative process that requires composers, actors, musicians, directors, and musical directors working together.

We're turning to theatre lovers like you to help raise $10,000 towards the development of this play in time to be staged at the Arts Club's new theatre in Olympic Village next season. While our goal is $10,000, in actuality it will cost closer to $30,000 to complete. Any amount raised over our goal will go towards that total.

Your contribution will help underwrite the costs of:
  • The completion of the score and orchestration
  • The completion of the script and lyrics
  • Workshop time for the actors and musicians
  • The time and expertise of the director, designer, stage manager and technicians for a staging workshop
  • A public reading of Onegin to give the artistic team feedback on their work in the summer of 2015
In the past, donations to our new play development program have enabled us to successfully stage all six Silver Commissions, including award-winning plays like Tear the Curtain!, The Patron Saint of Stanley Park, and How Has My Love Affected You?  This campaign gives you the opportunity to bring what is sure to be a timeless new Canadian work to life. 

The Perks of Playing a Part

Play a part in bringing Onegin to the stage, and you'll receive exciting perks that give you the exclusive opportunity to be a part of the making of this exciting new work.

Please note that the production schedule is subject to change, and the delivery of perks are contingent upon production schedule.

If you need help processing your donation, please contact the Arts Club's development team: (604) 687-5315 ext. 847.

Spread the word: tell your friends and family, and help us reach our goal!

The Arts Club Theatre Company is a not-for-profit registered charity, and a member of the Professional Association of Canadian Theatre (PACT), The Greater Vancouver Professional Theatre Alliance, and the Alliance for Arts and Culture, and operates under the jurisdiction of Canadian Actors Equity Association.

story:
The Box Show  

The Box Show is a one-woman theatre piece that I created inside of a cupboard. In the span of sixty minutes, I play over 20 characters and transform this tiny space into vastly different realities! These dynamic scenes range from a fighting couple in Vegas to the Greek army inside the Trojan Horse. This show is wacky, heartfelt, hilarious, poignant, and straight from my insane brain. :)

After two successful productions of this piece in San Francisco, I want to build a box that I can take to festivals and theatres along the East Coast! But it can't happen without your support! Help me 'Box up my Box Show' and take it to NYC!
 

What We Need: 

Your contribution will DIRECTLY FUND the creation of this project! Every little bit helps! 

Your support will help me offset the costs of:
  • The Box- Your funds first and foremost will help me purchase, refurbish, re-imagine (essentially trick out...)  a 3'x 4'x 2' box. Rather than just jump into the flimsiest IKEA cabinet I can find, I want to work with a designer to create a really bad-ass mini-stage for myself! 
  • Space Rental - I will need to rent studio space for my rehearsals and a theatre for my NYC performances! 
  • Festival Fees 
  • Storage of the Stage! :)
  • Publicity Materials
  • Insurance Costs
  • A Stage Manager .... (or a "Box Manager") 

About the Artist

For those of you who don't know me, my name is Dominique Salerno, and I am a professional theatre artist with a passion for edgy new work. I studied theatre at Princeton University and recently graduated with my M.F.A. from American Conservatory Theater. I am headed to NYC to launch my theatre career this fall.  I have written, directed, and performed cutting-edge new work at various Fringe Festivals across the globe (The Edinburgh Fringe, SD Fringe, and The Roma Fringe Festival). I love innovative theatre that pushes the boundaries of what is possible for both artists and audiences. If you do too, I would love to have your support as I embark on this cubic adventure! 

Other Ways You Can Help! 

Even if you can't contribute financially, there are other things you can do to move this project forward:

  • Come see the next production of The Box Show (details coming soon)!
  • Share this Indiegogo campaign on Facebook, Twitter, or by Email! :)
  • Donate Storage Space, Materials, Theatre Space, or your time/talents to the project!

story:
"FEFU" NEEDS YOUR HELP!

OUT LOUD Theatre kicks off their 2015 Season with a challenging and innovative theatrical experience! Help OUT LOUD Theatre and the Artistic Team behind Fefu & Her Friends keep on producing work in Providence, Rhode Island and beyond!



WHAT YOUR DONATION WILL MAKE POSSIBLE:

Any Amount Helps! From $1.00 - $100.00. Your Donation will make a difference!

The more we raise, the more we are able to grow. Your Donation will go a long way in helping to fund key components of our upcoming production.

ALL DONATIONS WILL GO DIRECTLY TOWARDS:

  • Performance Rights
  • Quality Rental Insurance
  • Rehearsal / Performance Space Rental Fees
  • Artist Stipends (Photography, Design Work)
  • Innovative Sets & Props / Costumes / Lighting
  • Publicity (Posters, Postcards, Programs) 

Photography by Justine M. Johnson

LEARN MORE ABOUT FEFU & HER FRIENDS:

The all-female cast of Fefu & Her Friends takes the audience on a journey through the lives of 8 women living in 1935 New England. Set within the time frame of 24 hours, we explore different areas of not only their personal lives and intimate struggles, but of the physical environments within varying playing spaces throughout the Theatre. Feminist playwright, Maria Irene Fornes, explores gender and societal roles - generating a conversation just as relevant today as it was during its release in 1977. Fefu & Her Friends is a uniquely interactive and immersive theatrical experience - truly not to be missed!

"A wonderful, important play." - Susan Sontag."An extraordinary play of uncommon insight and wit." - Los Angles Herald Examiner. "One of the most powerful plays written about the mysteries and shared hallucinations of the female experience." - L.A. Weekly.

Performance Dates:
SUNDAY FEB 15 @ 7:30pm - Pay What You Can Preview Performance
TUESDAY FEB 17 @ 7:30pm - OPENING NIGHT / Press Night
THURSDAY FEB 19 @ 7:30pm
FRIDAY February 20 @ 7:30pm
SATURDAY February 21 @ 7:30pm
THURSDAY February 26 @ 7:30pm
FRIDAY February 27 @ 7:30pm
SATURDAY February 28 @ 7:30pm

Talk Back Sessions will be held directly following each performance.

Questions? E-mail outloudtheatre@gmail.com

Learn More @ www.outloudtheatre.org

story:
Our Mission

In an age where our neighborhoods are quickly evolving into a series of online social media pages, A Public Fit aims to reinvigorate our community by working with emerging Las Vegas artists to create exciting, innovative and provocative theater. 

APF believes strongly in the communal power of great stories, dramatic ideas and the sincere engagement that audiences find in challenging theatrical events. A Public Fit genuinely hopes to unite artists and audiences through the most effective form of human connection, treating each production as the beginning of an unending conversation.

Our Aim

APF is trying to raise $20,000 to do our first show.  

This money will pay for the space, the set, the costumes, the designers and performers. The staff of APF will be working merely to cover their expenses in order to make sure that the performers and behind-the-scenes-artists get paid first.  

Las Vegas needs local, professional downtown theatre to helpredefine our city's cultural identity. 

*Make sure you check out our "Perks Page" to see all the cool stuff we are offering to show our thanks for your generous donations!*

Our History

We started slowly - a series of play readings on a Las Vegas patio.  

Soon, it was standing room only as our growing company of theatre professionals envisioned making a major contribution to a growing local scene. We have taken the monthly readings public which has attracted new talent and an ever-growing audience.  

The readings continually draw a standing room only crowd… so it's time to throw our first fully-realized Public Fit:  

Dawn King's Foxfinder 

November 13-23 

at the Art Square Theatre in downtown Las Vegas.

Our Culture

Las Vegas draws the most talented people on the planet to perform in its neon-fueled strip spectaculars. Once they land here they immediately yearn for the cultural community they left behind.  

We are going to harness those creative super-novas by creating an innovative, dynamic, truly professional theatre company with a downtown vibe, offering true Las Vegas cultureto an audience that's been forged in the fires of national ridicule. (If you live in Las Vegas, you know what we're talking about)

Right now, our city is known as a punchline, an advertising slogan. You know as well as we do how much more there is to our small desert town. We are a company of performers who grew up RIGHT HERE IN LAS VEGAS. We came of age beneath 60 foot signs of half naked showgirls bearing the ironic declaration "Bring the whole family!!"

Ours is an aesthetic very different from anywhere else in the world because we are immune to sexual suggestion, deaf to the ring ring ring of the beckoning poker machines. The strip shows are not our art, the strip shows are fodder for our anthems.

Where we’re going…

Steppenwolf began in a church basement; A Public Fit was born on a hot Las Vegas patio.

But we need your help in order to pay our performers a reasonable wage.  Too often in community theatre, actor "salaries" end up as little more than a "per diem," gas money in order to offer some sort of compensation for long hours and creative exhaustion.  APF respects artists too much to ask them to work for free.


Our plea

Unite with us to bring a megaphone to the lips of those artists who understand Las Vegas as something much more than "what happens here, stays here." It's time for what happens in Vegas to shake the pillars of the national artistic gestalt.

Right now, our city is known as a punchline, an advertising slogan. You know as well as we do how much more there is to our small desert town. We are a company of performers who grew up RIGHT HERE IN LAS VEGAS. We came of age beneath 60 foot signs of half naked showgirls bearing the ironic declaration "Bring the whole family!!"
Ours is an aesthetic very different from anywhere else in the world because we are immune to sexual suggestion, deaf to the ring ring ring of the beckoning poker machines. The strip shows are not our art, the strip shows are fodder for our anthems.
Where we’re going…
Steppenwolf began in a church basement; A Public Fit was born on a hot Las Vegas patio.
But we need your help in order to pay our performers a reasonable wage.  Too often in community theatre, actor "salaries" end up as little more than a "per diem," gas money in order to offer some sort of compensation for long hours and creative exhaustion.  APF respects artists too much to ask them to work for free.
Our plea
Unite with us to bring a megaphone to the lips of those artists who understand Las Vegas as something much more than "what happens here, stays here." It's time for what happens in Vegas to shake the pillars of the national artistic gestalt.

story:
What Would Happen If Coffee Was Illegal? 

Would we still drink it in underground cafes like the speakeasies of the Prohibition? Would the lack of coffee affect our ability to think deeply and create art? What kind of a world would ban such an innocent pastime anyway? 

These were the questions that started us on our journey. Since its conception two years ago, A Cup of God  has grown into a full-scale, two-hour experimental project that combines musical theater with a laid-back cafe aesthetic. 

We've taken questions of obsession, perfection and hero worship, mixed it with a fun, romping score of original indie folk music, and created the perfect battleground between the everyday and the dangerous, the artist and the criminal. 

WHAT WE'VE DONE SO FAR

  • Written and re-written a 100+ page script with the help of professional critique and many table readings by our cast
  • Composed almost all of a 12-song score and recorded a music video you can view in our Gallery 
  • Officially previewed our concept in Gettysburg 
  • Networked with venues and roasters in the area for backing and research
  • Held auditions and put together our cast 
  • Are currently in the thick of rehearsals after our first month of blocking 

We will be premiering the musical in Gettysburg, PA, The Most Famous Small Town in America. Gettysburg has witnessed a recent upsurge in cafes and coffee culture. A Cup of God will be opening for several brand new cafes, drawing crowds in an attempt to give back to the community that has supported us since the beginning. 

After that, backed by our friends at the Ragged Edge Roasting Co., we are planning on taking it around the state on a Route 30 Tour, hitting up every major city between Gettysburg and Philadelphia. 

We would be honored if you would help us show our thanks and promote an appreciation for the arts and for coffee by contributing to our campaign. 

Why We Need Your Help

During our production process, we discovered that making a musical requires money. Unfortunately, paying for everything out of pocket is no longer a viable option for a couple of recent college graduates. That is where you come in. Here are the things this campaign will fund:

  • Set & Costume Construction – set design, props, lighting, sound system, costumes, makeup, storage ($800)
  • Touring/Travel Expenses - gas mileage, tickets, hotel costs ($600)
  • Venue Rental ($500) 
  • Promotional Campaigns – public performance permits, printing costs, advertising ($300)
  • Cast Recording – studio rental, printing costs, CD or DVD production ($300)

We are very hopeful about reaching our campaign goal, but if we do not meet our mark, we will cut where we can and use what we've got. Any and all donors will receive promised perks regardless of whether or not we meet our goal. 

What You Will Get

We are working closely with the Ragged Edge Roasting Co., a local coffee brand. They have been extremely generous in donating time and resources. They have even agreed to sit with us and create a special themed blend, available only to campaign contributors (available in 2 oz., assortment, and 1 lb. bags based on donation size). This coffee is freshly roasted especially for you in Gettysburg. 

For those generous donors willing to contribute $350 and above, the Ragged Edge has offered to host a private roasting and cupping session. SCAA member and primary roaster Chad Close will teach this select group all about how to create a good cup of coffee at his headquarters in the heart of Gettysburg. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are looking for other ways to help us realize our goal, get involved by telling your friends and family about our project. Help us make some noise by following us on Facebook and Twitter, and don't forget to use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
photo by Omer Yukseker

Venturing home...


Jane Alison McKinney’s Wild Rabbit Dance Projects presents the premiere of Venture: a dance series, performed and created by Maritime natives Andrew Hartley, Emma Kerson, and Jane Alison McKinney, with additional choreography by acclaimed dance theatre artist Meagan O’Shea. The series includes six short unique dance works that explore the collective’s interest in dark elements, humour, and ecstasy. Venture will run for three nights at the BMO Studio Theatre from August 14, 2014 to August 16, 2014.

Graduating from the same class at The School of Toronto Dance Theatre, the three performing artists, who all grew up in the beautiful east coast, have developed a wonderful working relationship, and have joined together to offer this series to the city of Saint John. 

Venture’s diverse program of expressive dance works will marry the artistry of these Maritime-born emerging artists. It strives to pull at hearts strings, ignite laughter, and present a unique take on contemporary dance. 

How you can help

We are asking for your assistance for the cost of our time at the lovely Saint John Theatre Company's BMO Studio Theatre. The cost is $1,000 for our three days in the theatre. These three days will be spent with technical rehearsals, arranging props, costumes, and sets, and of course three nights of performances.

We have spent many hours rehearsing the work for this show, and we are thankful for the support from the Canada Council for the Arts in providing support for the Artistic Costs of the project.

We are also thankful for the support from our local dance organizations Port City Dance Academy and Rondos Dance Theatre, as well as Teed Saunders Doyle and Co., JTR Dumpster Services, and Shadow Lawn.

    Impact

    A four-time recipient of the Arts New Brunswick Scholarship, Jane Alison McKinney’s training began at Port City Dance Academy in 1999 in Saint John.  After graduating from The School of Toronto Dance Theatre she received an artsnb Career Development grant to attend Arsenale della Danza in Venice, and perform in Bibliotecca del Corpo by Ismael Ivo, in Italy and Brazil.  In 2012 she also co-produced and performed in Fantasies and Other Poisons, choreographed by Sharon B. Moore.  McKinney has presented her choreographic works in Toronto, and Saint John, and now embarks to take on production as Artistic Director of Wild Rabbit Dance Projects.

    Wild Rabbit Dance Projects seeks to perform work in small communities, to venture in less travelled and funded areas and share our points of view as artists. Your support enables us to continue our work and create bigger and bolder things. We have big dreams and hope you can be a part of them.

      Other Ways You Can Help

      Many thanks to you for showing interest in our endeavours! Any assistance in enhancing this series would be greatly appreciated. Please check out our WEBSITE, you can also help us by sharing this campaign, and if you are in Saint John in August, please come see the show!

      ..................................................................................................

      Wild Rabbit Dance Projects presents

      Venture: a dance series

      August 14-16, 2014 | 8PM

      BMO Studio Theatre (112 Princess St., Saint John, NB)

      Tickets: $18 Students/ Seniors/ Arts Workers | $22 General

      Ticket reservations: email wildrabbitdanceprojects@gmail.com

      Artistic Director/ Producer: Jane Alison McKinney

      Performers and Choreographers: Andrew Hartley, Emma Kerson, Jane Alison McKinney

      Additional Choreography: Meagan O’Shea

story:
Questions of Identity.
Questions of Integrity.
Questions of Self.
Question: What was your name again?

Jerry Lieblich has written one of the most exciting and theatrical plays of the last five years, tackling questions of self, our place in the world, where and who we fit in with, and who exactly,  takes authorship of their art.

D Deb Debbie Deborah  examines the increasing distance between us as people in the 21st century. As the world shrinks and people are closer than ever before, honestly, do we really know anyone at all?

To be frank, we are FLIPPING OUT,  we are so excited to bring this play to life,

BUT WE CAN’T DO IT WITHOUT YOU!!

We have a theatre space, thank goodness, but we still need…

  •   Lumber, Lumber, LUMBER, Paint:  Around $1500
  •   Sonic Soundscapes To Make Deb Deborah: $500
  •   Programs, postcards, posters, graffiti artist: $800
  •   Approximately 30 hours of off site rehearsal space at $15/hour: $450
  •   Assorted Props and Fancy-Type Threads for Actors: $500-ish
  •   Actor, Director, Stage Manager and Designer Stipends: $3800

You get it.  We need to raise about $12,000.00 to mount the production we think this script deserves.  We are hoping to raise at least $7,500.00 of that with this campaign. 

All gifts are tax deductible, as Theatre of NOTE is a 501(c)3. So any contribution you make helps you come tax time! Let Uncle Sam know you've been supporting the arts!

Seriously though, THANK YOU for Helping Bring This Script to Life

Hopefully some of our perks will excite you.  But even more importantly, we hope supporting great theatre and this exceptional script will inspire you.  We will be grateful for any donation, no matter how small.  And, if you have no funds to give,that's cool too, you can still show your support by: 

TAKE THE WORD OF DEB TO THE STREETS!!! (and the tweets)

  • Spread the word on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Vine, YouTube, Snapchat.
  • Follow our progress by following and re-tweeting us on Twitter. (@DDebDebbie, @TheatreOfNOTE.)
  • Hashtag us with #NOTEDDebs
  • Follow the play visually on Instragram @TheatreOfNOTE.
  • "Like" Theatre of NOTE on Facebook and get our news in your feed!
  • Come out to our Drag Queen Bingo Fundraising Event at Hamburger Mary's on Wednesday July 6th at 7pm in West Hollywood!!
  • Make a stencil of our awesome graphic and take it to the street, Banksy style! (Theatre of NOTE does not condone vandalism but what we don't know can't hurt us.)
  • And most importantly, dear hearts, don’t forget to come experience “D Deb Debbie Deborah," opening August 11th at Theatre of NOTE!!!

IF YOU WANT MORE INFORMATION ABOUT THE PLAY AND OUR TEAM, READ THIS…

Theatre Of NOTE has been an LA Theater institution for over 30 years, and in that time has developed a reputation as a place where original, edgy, world premiere plays are brought to vibrant, visceral, non-compromised life. We are proud to now add Jerry Lieblich's D Deb Debbie Deborah to the mix. Jerry is a Brooklyn-based playwright whose work has been developed at Playwrights Horizons, Clubbed Thumb, Soho Rep, Page 73, and Ars Nova.  D Deb Debbie Deborah (Clubbed Thumb) was a New York Times and Time Out New York Critic's Pick.  Our production is the West Coast premiere,

and the show opens in our theatre at 1517 N. Cahuenga Boulevard (on Sunset, across from Amoeba Records!) in Hollywood, on August 11th, 2016!

THANKS SO MUCH FOR ALL YOUR HELP!

Sincerely,

The Debs

story:
Greetings Musical Theater Lovers!  

"The Beachcomber Boys" is a fictional tale of the historic true-life fraternity of painters and poets and novelists and playwrights who, since 1916, have gathered each Saturday night for an evening of rollicking good fun and certain debauchery, in a not-so-disclosed decrepit location, on a spit of sand jutting out to the sea, known as Provincetown Massachusetts.  

Some prominent members were:  Eugene O'Neill, Edwin Dickinson, John Whorf, Harry Kemp and Charles Hawthorn.

Set in 1953, amidst the Hollywood Blacklist, major themes are art, literature, fame and family, and the disappointment of failure, in work and love.  

Not only is the story driven by this, seemingly, male-dominance, but also by the powerful force of the women who orbit and confound their lives; words are tossed and hearts are wrecked...and the fog horn blows...and the wind whips...and the Town bells chime!  

And art is made. 

It is an age-old fishing village "love storm" ...and, like many, has an emotional rip-tide, where some swim safe to shore...and others, are pulled under.

~

The Beachcomber Boys began as a play...and then one day this wave of music washed over it and down the aisles and it was suddenly realized, as if it were known all along, that Provincetown is nothing, if not deeply orchestral and melodic. Not to mention enchanted. The place, itself, sings!  And to the heavens!  

The Beachcomber Boys is a love-letter to it...and to all its sweet, salty and strange characters, past and present. 

~

IT TAKES A FISHING VILLAGE!

~

WHY WE NEED YOU!

The $20,000 we hope to raise will be one-third of the actual cost of this Production.

*We will be teaming up with additional Producing Partners to be announced soon!

YOUR DONATION WILL PAY FOR:

Musical composition, arrangements and score

Audition materials/and audition space rental

Rehearsal space rental

Travel and housing expenses for creative team, a dozen actors, composer and musicians, for Workshop Reading

Publicity for Workshop Reading

Rental of theatrical venue for Workshop Reading, with Music

And this is just the Development phase!

~

PRODUCTION:

With good luck and careful planning, we will also be able to put some of your generous donations into Production, set to premiere in Provincetown!

Sets

Lights

Costumes

Projections

Orchestra

Publicity

Programs

Equity contracts

Pay for non-union actors

Pay for running crew

Housing/Travel expenses for Production

Bells & Whistles & Banners!

~

PHEW!

~

Yes!  This is ambitious!  

But where else but Provincetown would the sky be the limit?

Please help us realize this enormous vision...and Thank You! Thank You! Thank You!

~

THE COMPANY 

Irene Glezos (GLORY BRYANT) has performed in theaters both regionally and Off-Broadway.  Favorite acting credits include: Maria Callas in "Master Class," Lady in "Orpheus Descending," Anna Prager in Shauna Kanter's "Legacy," Joyce/Isabella Bird in Caryl Churchill's "Top Girls" directed by April Shawhan, Fairouz in Naomi Wallace's "In the Heart of America" (directed by Tony Kushner), Collette in "Four Dogs and a Bone," Shirl the Pearl in "Criminal Genius," Sally in "A Lie of the Mind," Anna in Ron Elisha's "Two" (with Mark Hammer), Kathleen in "Terra Nova," Bo in "Criminal Hearts," and Antigone in "Antigone" at St. John the Divine (directed by Suzanne Shepherd). She has appeared in films including "Deadly Obsessions," Woody Allen's "Celebrity," "Mentor," "Skeleton Woman," "The Bittersons" and the soon to be released "Louder Than Words." She has appeared in numerous television series including "Sex and the City," "Criminal Intent," "Conviction," "Trial by Jury," "Third Watch," and "Law and Order." For her portrayal of Maria Callas in "Master Class" at MTC in Westport she was recently nominated for Outstanding Leading Actress in a Play by the Connecticut Critics Circle. She will be returning to the Tennessee Williams Festival in Provincetown in September, 2014 to play Gertrude Eastman-Cuevas in Jane Bowles' "In the Summerhouse" directed by David Kaplan.


Lori Ada Jaroslow (MABEL BRYANT) Lori has performed on Broadway, Off-Broadway, regionally, internationally and at sea. Acting work includes on Broadway: Rizzo in Grease and Tzeitel in Fiddler on the Roof, directed by Jerome Robbins.  Regional theatre and Off-Broadway includes, Grandma Sylvia’s Funeral, Nunsense, Gypsy, Othello and Broads.  Jaroslow co-produced and directed the multi award-winning CD series Tell Me a Story which features such actors as Len Cariou, Bryce Dallas Howard and PaulaPoundstone. The last CD in the series Women of Wonder won the prestigious 2010 Audie Award for best original work. The Road Theatre received an NEA grant in 2011 to produce The Baby Project, an original musical theatre piece written by Lori and composers Fonda Feingold and Noriko Olling which had a limited run at The Road Theatre in Los Angeles in 2012. Please keep an eye out for its official birth. Lori has taught acting and musical theatre to kids and teens extensively in New York and Los Angeles. She has also directed innumerable plays and musicals for kids ages 6 to 86 and has coached actors of all ages on various projects. Ms.Jaroslow is on the board at The Academy for New Musical Theatre/New Musicals Inc.  For more info please go to www.babyprojectmusical.com and www.loriadajaroslow.com 

Chelsey Jo Ristaino (CLAIRE) is a Boston native and a recent graduate from Montclair State University in New Jersey, holding her BFA in Musical Theatre.  You might have seen her recently at Cape Rep Theatre as Franca in The Light in the Piazza.  Other credits include: Next to Normal (Natalie), Jerusalem (Pea), and The Mystery of Edwin Drood (Rosa Bud).


Tom Riis Farrell (MALCOM VITALE) Broadway: Chicago; Coram Boy; Dirty Blonde (also on tour, for which he received a Helen Hayes Award and a Joseph Jefferson Award nomination); Wrong Mountain; 1776. Off-Broadway: Disaster! The Musical (St. Luke's, directed by Jack Plotnick); Caucasian Chalk Circle with Christopher Lloyd (Classic Stage Company, directed by Brian Kulick); A.R. Gurney's The Old Boy (Keen Company, directed by Jonathan Silverstein); The Resistible Rise of Arturo Ui with a cast that included Al Pacino, Steve Buscemi, Dominic Chianese, Billy Crudup, Charles Durning, Linda Emond, Paul Giamatti, John Goodman, Chazz Palminteri and Tony Randall (National Actors' Theatre, directed by Simon McBurney); Li'l Abner (Encores!, directed by Christopher Ashley); Mary Rose (Vineyard, directed by Tina Landau); The Slug Bearers of Kayrol Island (Vineyard, directed by Bob McGrath); View of the Dome (NYTW, directed by Michael Mayer). Regional: Picasso at the Lapin Agile (Long Wharf, directed by Gordon Edelstein); Betty's Summer Vacation (Bay Street, directed by Trip Cullman); Circle Mirror Transformation with Sandy Duncan (George Street, directed by Anders Cato); Rag and Bone (Long Wharf, directed by Tina Landau); Once in a Lifetime (Williamstown, directed by Michael Greif). TV: “Nurse Jackie”; “Crossbones”; “Elementary”; “The Americans”; “Blue Bloods”; “The Good Wife”; “Fringe”; “Brotherhood”; five “L&O”s, two “Criminal Intents”; “Ed”; “Spin City”; “NYPD Blue”. Film: The Bourne Legacy, All Good Things, Trust the Man, The Stepford Wives, Almost Famous, The Out-of-Towners, Devil's Advocate, Sleepless in Seattle, Scent of a Woman (upcoming: Lullaby with Richard Jenkins, Anne Archer and Terrence Howard; That Awkward Moment with Zac Efron).

Nathaniel Hall Taylor (GORDON O’KEEFE) recently stepped off stage as Polonius in Peregrine Theatre Ensemble’s critically acclaimed production of ‘HAMLET: PRINCE OF DENMARK.’ He originated the roles of painter Edward Hopper in ‘HOPPERS’ GHOSTS’ and author Vladimir Nabokov in ‘GLOVES OFF! NABOKOV VS. WILSON,’ new works by playwright Kevin Rice. Nat is thrilled to be involved in the evolution of THE BEACHCOMBER BOYS, being the grandson of Bohemian artist stock on the Outer Cape, and a huge fan of Eugene O’Neill. Beginning with The Actor’s Gang in LA, CA, he became involved with avant-­garde theatre artist/choreographer Ken Roht, and ended his tenure in the city of Angels in the development of new plays with The Echo Theater Company. Graduating from Broadway’s Circle in the Square Theater School, he worked in New York with directors Moni Yakim (THIEVES’ CARNIVAL) and Alan Langdon (THE CHERRY ORCHARD, FIVE WOMEN WEARING THE SAME DRESS) and then director Josh Fox in his WOW theater installation piece, SURRENDER, about Iraq war veterans’ reintegration into civilian life. In Boston, he premiered in the Company One’s production of Lydia R. Diamond’s ‘VOYEURS DE VENUS’ (James Bradsford). He is a proud member of Peregrine Theatre Ensemble. 

Patrick Riviere (CHAZ FITZGERALD) most recently sang four solo performances at Tin Pan Alley and sang back-up for Lady J in THE GOSPEL OF DOLLY as part of the Afterglow Festival in Provincetown. He co-starred in the concert of KISS ME KATE in the spring of 2013 with the Buffalo Philharmonic at Kleinhans Music Hall. Broadway on the Boardwalk: ANYTHING GOES at Trump Plaza, Atlantic City (The Purser u/s Moonface); Off-Broadway: FAMILY DINNER at The Beckett, WELCOME TO OUR CITY at The Mint, THE ROBBER BRIDEGROOM at Theatre Off-Park and OPA!, for which he was nominated for Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Musical.  Regional highlights include the North American Premiere of I AND ALBERT, Che in EVITA at ArtPark, Reuben in JOSEPH… at Studio Arena, Stewpot in the Connecticut Critics Circle Award Winning Production of SOUTH PACIFIC, Sancho in MAN OF LA MANCHA at Merry-Go-Round Playhouse, Snoopy in the tribute production of YOU’RE A GOOD MAN CHARLIE BROWN at ECST and El Gallo in THE FANTASTICKS for which he was nominated for Best Actor in A Musical.  He created the role of The White Baron in the American Premiere of THE IMAGINARY LIFE OF THE STREET SWEEPER AUGUST G in Los Angeles and is featured in several festival films including the starring role in a Stephen King short film, A Very Tight Place. Patrick can be heard as the voices of Doctor Einkopf and Jimmy the Cabin Boy in the animated series Captain Stargood (Web Series) and was cast as Forensic Expert Robert Johnson in the short-lived Fox TV show The Jury.  Proud member of AEA and SAG-AFTRA.  He is also a published author, produced playwright and director. www.patrickriviere.com 

Aaron Tone (HENRY) Originally a fine artist painter from Detroit, MI, Aaron started studying acting in 2006 at Washington, DC's Studio Theatre Acting Conservatory.  In DC, he has appeared in "The Pillowman," "All That I Will Ever Be," "Mondo Andronicus," “The Ballad of the Sad Café,” and "Superior Donuts."  In Provincetown, he has appeared in "Take Me Out," "Our Town," "Slap & Tickle," "The Food Chain," "The Divine Sister," "The Normal Heart," and "The Tale Of The Allergist's Wife." He was also featured in the film “BearCity 2: The Proposal.”

Sean O'Connor (JACK VITALE) has had leading roles in dozens of plays in NYC and regional theatre.  Lead roles on the TV shows “All My Children” and “Another World.”  And several indie films.  As a writer, seven of my plays have been published by both JAC Publications and Next Stage Press.  They’ve all been produced several times apiece off-Broadway and off-off Broadway in NYC and regional theatre.  And five of them have won national Best New Play awards (the other two were finalists.)  I was a member, along with Lanford Wilson, of NY’s Circle Rep.  I’m presently a member of the Playwrights/Directors Unit of the Actor’s Studio, and The Project Rushmore Theatre Company, both in NYC.  My work has garnered a half-dozen grants and I’ve written a lot of film for USA Network, Nasser Entertainment and other film companies.  Hostage Negotiator, a film I co-wrote for USA Network, was made.  My new full-length, World of Sinatras, was nominated by the Southern Appalachian Rep for “Best New Play of 2013.”  It received a grant from the Pilgrim Project.  And it was recently produced in NYC by Project Rushmore.  Another new full-length,The Unraveling, was recently chosen for the Elia Kazan Festival at the Actors Studio. The Baz’Arts Theatre in France has just finished translating World of Sinatras and The Unraveling for production over there.  And I’ve just completed a TV pilot, King Dollar.  

Christopher Anthony Henry (MOUSE) is thrilled to be able to work with Myra, David and such an amazing cast. Studied Music Theatre at the Hartt School at the University of Hartford. Past credits include Naked Boys Singing (The Entertainer), American Idol (Featured Contestant), Will Roger’s Follies (Clem), My Fair Lady (Jamie), Peter Pansy (Bottom), Troll-La-La (Freddie), Death of a Saleslady (Bernard). Thank you so much for Myra Slotnick for asking me to be a part of this. 


(photo: Ride Hamilton)

CLYDE SHELBY MELLERT (SONNY COOK) has long been a Provincetown favorite. His long and varied credits begin with the song "Joanna" to his wife Joanna. His early career credits include Matt the Boy for a tour of the "Fantastiks" and traveling with The Dayton Boys Choir. After appearing on Star Search and becoming a finalist, Clyde was edged out by Sam Harris. Clyde has continued to write and perform as musician and actor in many shows amongst roles in "Cabaret" as Herr Schultz, the sheriff in "Bat Boy", "Edward II" as the assassin, Mr. Fagin in "Oliver"and Cassius in "Jesus Christ Superstar". Clyde can also be seen in the indie film, "Daniel", recently shown at the Provincetown, New York and San Diego Film Festivals. As a musician, Clyde continues to write and make music having appeared recently in Tennessee William's Beatnik Jam. 


John Long (HAP) is thrilled to be a part of THE BEACHCOMBER BOYS.  Recently, John has performed as Francis in ONE MAN, TWO GUVNORS at the Barnstormers Theater, and as Arthur in THE TRIALS OF GERTURDE MOODY at WHAT.  He has worked regionally and in New York City, holds a graduate degree from Florida State  University and an undergraduate degree from Notre Dame.  John is a proud member of Actors Equity. 


Scott Douglas Cunningham (SALVATORE FRASSO) graduated from the Stella Adler Conservatory in 1995 and spent the next dozen years doing theater, soaps, commercials, print and voiceovers. In 2008 he joined David Drake's production of Two Boys in a Bed on a Cold Winter's Night playing Fire Island,  San Francisco, Dublin, and Provincetown.  Scott stayed in Provincetown acting in and directing productions at the Provincetown Theater for Myra Slotnick's Universal Theatre Festival. Favorite roles on the Cape include Matt in David Drake's production of Poor Superman at the Art House and Dr Treves in The Elephant Man directed by Susan Greeley for Wellfleet Harbor Actors Theater. Scott currently is the owner of ScottCakes in Provincetown, splits his time between the Cape and Washington DC with his awesome husband, Dan and is psyched to be working with David and Myra again!


SOME OF THE CREATIVE TEAM

Peter Stopschinski (COMPOSER) 

Peter Stopschinski composed and recorded string arrangements and organ on Grupo Fantasma’s 2010 Grammy Award winning album La Existential.  He also composed the music for Madeleine George's play The Curious Case Of Dr. Watson that was nominated for the 2013 Pulitzer Prize in Drama.  His musical with creator E.J. Stapleton, The Calico Buffalo, was chosen top 10 in the 2014 New York New Musical Theater Festival.

Peter is Composer for Rude Mechs’ production I’ve Never Been So Happy, a western musical which was developed as a selection in the NEA New Play Development Program and played in Washington D.C. and Austin, TX and was picked up by Centre Theater Group for a 4 week run in L.A. at the Kirk Douglas Theater.

Peter's opera with librettist Kirk Lynn about Bum Phillips and the Houston Oilers premiered at the historic La Mama Experimental Theater Space this year to rave reviews: "Watching a staged depiction of the 'Luv Ya Blue' era is like biting into a deep-fried madeline. " - Texas Monthly.  "...even Rigoletto would have to doff his cap." - NY Times.  The opera was attended by Bum's son, NFL coach Wade Phillips, and former Houston Oiler Quarterback Dan Pastorini.  “I was moved to tears in the end,” Mr. Pastorini said. “I lived with the man and I knew the man and they depicted him to a T.”
 
Peter's concerto for Harp, strings and percussion was featured at the 2014 Orchestra Gala Night at the gathering of the American Harp Society in New Orleans in June.  Members of the Louisiana Philharmonic Orchestra were conducted by Peter Bay and the solo harp part was performed by Elaine Barber. peterstopschinski.com

Myra Slotnick (BOOK & LYRICS) Myra Slotnick is an award winning playwright whose work has been seen in Provincetown, NY and across the country. Her most recent play "The Weight of Water" premiered at the Provincetown Theater in 2011, and enjoyed an off-Broadway run in NYC in 2013.  Of the world premiere, The Cape Cod Times said: "Myra Slotnick's play ,The Weight of Water, opened at The Provincetown Theater with echoes of the great American playwrights who plied their craft in the small urbane town".

David Drake (DIRECTOR) is an actor, writer and director who spent the past three decades creating new theatre with a national and international profile. He is most widely known as the Obie Award-winning playwright/performer of The Night Larry Kramer Kissed Me, one of the longest-running solo shows in NY theatre history. In 2013, to celebrate its 20th anniversary, David adapted his solo show for a 12-member ensemble, directed by Robert La Fosse, to benefit Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS. The production featured the author alongside such stars as Andre de Shields, Anthony Rapp, Wesley Taylor, Rory O’Malley, Robin de Jesus, and BD Wong.

As a director, David has staged new plays and musicals in NYC at multiple theaters. He has twice been a Directing Fellow at Sundance Theatre Lab. His production of Taylor Mac’s The Lily’s Revenge world premiered at HERE in NYC, and landed on the “Best of the Year” lists of The New Yorker, Time Out/NY, Village Voice, NY Post, The Advocate, and won a 2010 Obie Award. At the Provincetown Theatre on Cape Cod, David directed Thornton Wilder’s Our Town (Cape Cod Times, “Best of the Year”) and the critically acclaimed world premiere of Myra Slotnick’s The Weight of Water, which transferred to NYC where it made its off-Broadway debut at the Producers Club in 2013. David currently teaches his “Solo Show Shop” master class at the Abrons Arts Center, in New York.

photo: Bobby Miller

Karen Billard (COSTUME DESIGN) is a designer, draper and artist with a patternmaking background in the New York fashion industry.  She works with ballets, operas and theaters across the country.  Recent credits include the 2013 season at the Santa Fe Opera, Britten's Turn of the Screw, designed by Katherine Stebbins (New England Conservatory Opera Theater), Mikko Nissinen's The Nutcracker, designed by Robert Perdziola (The Boston Ballet),  Art by Yasmina Reza (The Provincetown Theater), Sleeping Indoors by Jim Holt (PTC), First Dance by Jerry Thompson(PTC), Diff’rent by Eugene O’Neill (PTC) and Our Town by Thornton Wilder,  (CTek Arts).  Karen currently makes her home in Santa Fe, New Mexico, where she is pursuing work in film.

Photo: Bobby Miller

Mike Steers (LIGHTING DESIGN) is a graduate of the HARTT School of Music with a BFA in Musical Theater Performance whose Directing Credits BENT(1997 University of Hartford), Company and You’re a Good Man, Charlie Brown (Counter Productions), Children of Eden and Once on This Island. Mike’s Scenic Design credits include: Oliver (PTC),Blithe Spirit (Perigrine Theater Company) Oklahoma!, Lend Me a Tenor, The Tenderland (Massasoit Theater Company), The Medium (NYC/PTown) Raisin in the Sun, Fiddler on The Roof, Virginia Wolfe, Lion in Winter, The King and I, Lobby Hero (Counter Productions), 42nd Street, LaCage Aux Folles, Hair (Company Theater) Children of Eden, Once on this Island (OAHS) and A Midsummer Nights (University of Hartford University Players). Lighting Design credits: Streetcar Named Desire (University Players) , God of Carnage, Diff’rent (Provincetown Theatre Company) The Baltimore Waltz (Animus Ensemble, Boston) and the World Premier of Myra Slotnick’s The Weight of Water (NYC/PTown). Mike can  be seen in ILLUSIONS, Provincetown’s “longest running drag show” at The Crown and Anchor as Hostess and MC Anita Cocktail (You can follow him on twitter  @AnitaCocktailPT).

Ellen Rousseau (SCENIC DESIGN) is scenic designer, artist, and master carpenter. She is fascinated by the ways in which spacial relationships inform context and story. Some of her design credits include Inappropriate: The Musical (Odyssey Theater in Los Angeles), Across The Pond (world premier at the Provincetown Theater), The Weight of Water (world premier at the Provincetown Theater Company and The Producer’s Club in NYC), Tennessee Williams Songbook (Provincetown Tennessee Williams Theater Festival and in NYC at the Five Angels Theater), Auto De Fe (Provincetown Tennessee Williams Festival), Snowman In The Dunes (PTC), Arsenic and Old Lace (PTC), Reasons To Live (PTC), The Food Chain (PTC), Merry Wives of Windsor (PTC), The Story of Ibis (The Center For Coastal Studies), You’re A Good Man Charlie Brown (Children’s Theater of Maine), The Dumb Waiter (Russell Square Players), Victoria Station (Russell Square Players). She was Technical Director for The Odd Couple - Female Version at the Provincetown Theater Company. When she is not designing for the theater she can be found in her shop making art and furniture on Cape Cod. Visit her website at www.houseofrousseau.com.

Tim McCarthy (PROJECTION DESIGN) is a Gay Video Historian. He has traveled the world since 1990 with a video camera documenting LGBTIA life in 90 countries so far and all 7 continents. He is creating a visual record of this time of firsts for LGBTI people around the globe. It is both his medicine and his legacy. Tim was with the first International Gay and Lesbian Delegation to the Soviet Union in 1991. He was the first reporter credentialed by the White House for Gay TV in 1993. His second film Nocebo + Witchcraft chronicles his trip to bring HIV awareness back to it's homeland in Uganda in 1999. He was on the first Gay Expedition to Antarctica, in 2000. Most recently the film “How To Survive a Plague”, which uses some of his archival footage, was nominated for an Academy Award, in 2013.
story_txt:
Greetings Musical Theater Lovers!  "The Beachcomber Boys" is a fictional tale of the historic true-life fraternity of painters and poets and novelists and playwrights who, since 1916, have gathered each Saturday night for an evening of rollicking good fun and certain debauchery, in a not-so-disclosed decrepit location, on a spit of sand jutting out to the sea, known as Provincetown Massachusetts.  Some prominent members were:  Eugene O'Neill, Edwin Dickinson, John Whorf, Harry Kemp and Charles Hawthorn.Set in 1953, amidst the Hollywood Blacklist, major themes are art, literature, fame and family, and the disappointment of failure, in work and love.  Not only is the story driven by this, seemingly, male-dominance, but also by the powerful force of the women who orbit and confound their lives; words are tossed and hearts are wrecked...and the fog horn blows...and the wind whips...and the Town bells chime!  And art is made. It is an age-old fishing village "love storm" ...and, like many, has an emotional rip-tide, where some swim safe to shore...and others, are pulled under.~The Beachcomber Boys began as a play...and then one day this wave of music washed over it and down the aisles and it was suddenly realized, as if it were known all along, that Provincetown is nothing, if not deeply orchestral and melodic. Not to mention enchanted. The place, itself, sings!  And to the heavens!  The Beachcomber Boys is a love-letter to it...and to all its sweet, salty and strange characters, past and present. ~IT TAKES A FISHING VILLAGE!~WHY WE NEED YOU!The $20,000 we hope to raise will be one-third of the actual cost of this Production.*We will be teaming up with additional Producing Partners to be announced soon!YOUR DONATION WILL PAY FOR:Musical composition, arrangements and scoreAudition materials/and audition space rentalRehearsal space rentalTravel and housing expenses for creative team, a dozen actors, composer and musicians, for Workshop ReadingPublicity for Workshop ReadingRental of theatrical venue for Workshop Reading, with MusicAnd this is just the Development phase!~PRODUCTION:With good luck and careful planning, we will also be able to put some of your generous donations into Production, set to premiere in Provincetown!SetsLightsCostumesProjectionsOrchestraPublicityProgramsEquity contractsPay for non-union actorsPay for running crewHousing/Travel expenses for ProductionBells & Whistles & Banners!~PHEW!~Yes!  This is ambitious!  But where else but Provincetown would the sky be the limit?Please help us realize this enormous vision...and Thank You! Thank You! Thank You!~THE COMPANY 

Irene Glezos (GLORY BRYANT) has performed in theaters both regionally and Off-Broadway.  Favorite acting credits include: Maria Callas in "Master Class," Lady in "Orpheus Descending," Anna Prager in Shauna Kanter's "Legacy," Joyce/Isabella Bird in Caryl Churchill's "Top Girls" directed by April Shawhan, Fairouz in Naomi Wallace's "In the Heart of America" (directed by Tony Kushner), Collette in "Four Dogs and a Bone," Shirl the Pearl in "Criminal Genius," Sally in "A Lie of the Mind," Anna in Ron Elisha's "Two" (with Mark Hammer), Kathleen in "Terra Nova," Bo in "Criminal Hearts," and Antigone in "Antigone" at St. John the Divine (directed by Suzanne Shepherd). She has appeared in films including "Deadly Obsessions," Woody Allen's "Celebrity," "Mentor," "Skeleton Woman," "The Bittersons" and the soon to be released "Louder Than Words." She has appeared in numerous television series including "Sex and the City," "Criminal Intent," "Conviction," "Trial by Jury," "Third Watch," and "Law and Order." For her portrayal of Maria Callas in "Master Class" at MTC in Westport she was recently nominated for Outstanding Leading Actress in a Play by the Connecticut Critics Circle. She will be returning to the Tennessee Williams Festival in Provincetown in September, 2014 to play Gertrude Eastman-Cuevas in Jane Bowles' "In the Summerhouse" directed by David Kaplan.






Lori Ada Jaroslow (MABEL BRYANT) Lori has performed on Broadway, Off-Broadway, regionally, internationally and at sea. Acting work includes on Broadway: Rizzo in Grease and Tzeitel in Fiddler on the Roof, directed by Jerome Robbins.  Regional theatre and Off-Broadway includes, Grandma Sylvia’s Funeral, Nunsense, Gypsy, Othello and Broads.  Jaroslow co-produced and directed the multi award-winning CD series Tell Me a Story which features such actors as Len Cariou, Bryce Dallas Howard and PaulaPoundstone. The last CD in the series Women of Wonder won the prestigious 2010 Audie Award for best original work. The Road Theatre received an NEA grant in 2011 to produce The Baby Project, an original musical theatre piece written by Lori and composers Fonda Feingold and Noriko Olling which had a limited run at The Road Theatre in Los Angeles in 2012. Please keep an eye out for its official birth. Lori has taught acting and musical theatre to kids and teens extensively in New York and Los Angeles. She has also directed innumerable plays and musicals for kids ages 6 to 86 and has coached actors of all ages on various projects. Ms.Jaroslow is on the board at The Academy for New Musical Theatre/New Musicals Inc.  For more info please go to www.babyprojectmusical.com and www.loriadajaroslow.com 




Chelsey Jo Ristaino (CLAIRE) is a Boston native and a recent graduate from Montclair State University in New Jersey, holding her BFA in Musical Theatre.  You might have seen her recently at Cape Rep Theatre as Franca in The Light in the Piazza.  Other credits include: Next to Normal (Natalie), Jerusalem (Pea), and The Mystery of Edwin Drood (Rosa Bud).



Tom Riis Farrell (MALCOM VITALE) Broadway: Chicago; Coram Boy; Dirty Blonde (also on tour, for which he received a Helen Hayes Award and a Joseph Jefferson Award nomination); Wrong Mountain; 1776. Off-Broadway: Disaster! The Musical (St. Luke's, directed by Jack Plotnick); Caucasian Chalk Circle with Christopher Lloyd (Classic Stage Company, directed by Brian Kulick); A.R. Gurney's The Old Boy (Keen Company, directed by Jonathan Silverstein); The Resistible Rise of Arturo Ui with a cast that included Al Pacino, Steve Buscemi, Dominic Chianese, Billy Crudup, Charles Durning, Linda Emond, Paul Giamatti, John Goodman, Chazz Palminteri and Tony Randall (National Actors' Theatre, directed by Simon McBurney); Li'l Abner (Encores!, directed by Christopher Ashley); Mary Rose (Vineyard, directed by Tina Landau); The Slug Bearers of Kayrol Island (Vineyard, directed by Bob McGrath); View of the Dome (NYTW, directed by Michael Mayer). Regional: Picasso at the Lapin Agile (Long Wharf, directed by Gordon Edelstein); Betty's Summer Vacation (Bay Street, directed by Trip Cullman); Circle Mirror Transformation with Sandy Duncan (George Street, directed by Anders Cato); Rag and Bone (Long Wharf, directed by Tina Landau); Once in a Lifetime (Williamstown, directed by Michael Greif). TV: “Nurse Jackie”; “Crossbones”; “Elementary”; “The Americans”; “Blue Bloods”; “The Good Wife”; “Fringe”; “Brotherhood”; five “L&O”s, two “Criminal Intents”; “Ed”; “Spin City”; “NYPD Blue”. Film: The Bourne Legacy, All Good Things, Trust the Man, The Stepford Wives, Almost Famous, The Out-of-Towners, Devil's Advocate, Sleepless in Seattle, Scent of a Woman (upcoming: Lullaby with Richard Jenkins, Anne Archer and Terrence Howard; That Awkward Moment with Zac Efron).


Nathaniel Hall Taylor (GORDON O’KEEFE) recently stepped off stage as Polonius in Peregrine Theatre Ensemble’s critically acclaimed production of ‘HAMLET: PRINCE OF DENMARK.’ He originated the roles of painter Edward Hopper in ‘HOPPERS’ GHOSTS’ and author Vladimir Nabokov in ‘GLOVES OFF! NABOKOV VS. WILSON,’ new works by playwright Kevin Rice. Nat is thrilled to be involved in the evolution of THE BEACHCOMBER BOYS, being the grandson of Bohemian artist stock on the Outer Cape, and a huge fan of Eugene O’Neill. Beginning with The Actor’s Gang in LA, CA, he became involved with avant-­garde theatre artist/choreographer Ken Roht, and ended his tenure in the city of Angels in the development of new plays with The Echo Theater Company. Graduating from Broadway’s Circle in the Square Theater School, he worked in New York with directors Moni Yakim (THIEVES’ CARNIVAL) and Alan Langdon (THE CHERRY ORCHARD, FIVE WOMEN WEARING THE SAME DRESS) and then director Josh Fox in his WOW theater installation piece, SURRENDER, about Iraq war veterans’ reintegration into civilian life. In Boston, he premiered in the Company One’s production of Lydia R. Diamond’s ‘VOYEURS DE VENUS’ (James Bradsford). He is a proud member of Peregrine Theatre Ensemble. 


Patrick
Riviere (CHAZ FITZGERALD) most recently sang four solo performances at Tin Pan Alley and sang
back-up for Lady J in THE GOSPEL OF DOLLY as part of the Afterglow Festival in Provincetown.
He co-starred in the concert of KISS ME KATE in the spring of 2013 with the
Buffalo Philharmonic at Kleinhans Music Hall. Broadway on the Boardwalk: ANYTHING
GOES at Trump Plaza, Atlantic City (The Purser u/s Moonface); Off-Broadway:
FAMILY DINNER at The Beckett, WELCOME TO OUR CITY at The Mint, THE ROBBER
BRIDEGROOM at Theatre Off-Park and OPA!, for which he was nominated for
Outstanding Supporting Actor in a Musical. 
Regional highlights include the North American Premiere of I AND ALBERT,

Connecticut Critics Circle Award Winning Production of SOUTH PACIFIC, Sancho in
MAN OF LA MANCHA at Merry-Go-Round Playhouse, Snoopy in the tribute production
of YOU’RE A GOOD MAN CHARLIE BROWN at ECST and El Gallo in THE FANTASTICKS for
which he was nominated for Best Actor in A Musical.  He created the role of The White Baron in the
American Premiere of THE IMAGINARY LIFE OF THE STREET SWEEPER AUGUST G in Los
Angeles and is featured in several festival films including the starring role
in a Stephen King short film, A Very
Tight Place. Patrick can be heard as the voices of Doctor Einkopf and Jimmy
the Cabin Boy in the animated series Captain
Stargood (Web Series) and was cast as Forensic Expert Robert Johnson in the

playwright and director. www.patrickriviere.com

" - Texas Monthly.  "...even Rigoletto would have to doff his cap." - NY Times.  The opera was attended by Bum's son, NFL coach Wade Phillips, and former Houston Oiler Quarterback Dan Pastorini.  “I was moved to tears in the end,” Mr. Pastorini said. “I lived with the man and I knew the man and they depicted him to a T.” Peter's concerto for Harp, strings and percussion was featured at the 2014 Orchestra Gala Night at the gathering of the American Harp Society in New Orleans in June.  Members of the Louisiana Philharmonic Orchestra were conducted by Peter Bay and the solo harp part was performed by Elaine Barber. peterstopschinski.com




Myra Slotnick (BOOK & LYRICS) Myra Slotnick is an award winning playwright whose work has been seen in Provincetown, NY and across the country. Her most recent play "The Weight of Water" premiered at the Provincetown Theater in 2011, and enjoyed an off-Broadway run in NYC in 2013.  Of the world premiere, The Cape Cod Times said: "Myra Slotnick's play ,The Weight of Water, opened at The Provincetown Theater with echoes of the great American playwrights who plied their craft in the small urbane town".






David Drake (DIRECTOR) is an actor, writer and director who spent the past three decades creating new theatre with a national and international profile. He is most widely known as the Obie Award-winning playwright/performer of The Night Larry Kramer Kissed Me, one of the longest-running solo shows in NY theatre history. In 2013, to celebrate its 20th anniversary, David adapted his solo show for a 12-member ensemble, directed by Robert La Fosse, to benefit Broadway Cares/Equity Fights AIDS. The production featured the author alongside such stars as Andre de Shields, Anthony Rapp, Wesley Taylor, Rory O’Malley, Robin de Jesus, and BD Wong.As a director, David has staged new plays and musicals in NYC at multiple theaters. He has twice been a Directing Fellow at Sundance Theatre Lab. His production of Taylor Mac’s The Lily’s Revenge world premiered at HERE in NYC, and landed on the “Best of the Year” lists of The New Yorker, Time Out/NY, Village Voice, NY Post, The Advocate, and won a 2010 Obie Award. At the Provincetown Theatre on Cape Cod, David directed Thornton Wilder’s Our Town (Cape Cod Times, “Best of the Year”) and the critically acclaimed world premiere of Myra Slotnick’s The Weight of Water, which transferred to NYC where it made its off-Broadway debut at the Producers Club in 2013. David currently teaches his “Solo Show Shop” master class at the Abrons Arts Center, in New York.


photo: Bobby Miller



Karen Billard (COSTUME DESIGN) is a
designer, draper and artist with a patternmaking background in the New York
fashion industry.  She works with
ballets, operas and theaters across the country.  Recent credits include the 2013 season at
the Santa Fe Opera, Britten's Turn of the
Screw, designed by Katherine Stebbins (New England Conservatory Opera
Theater), Mikko Nissinen's The Nutcracker,
designed by Robert Perdziola (The Boston Ballet),  Art by
Yasmina Reza (The Provincetown Theater), Sleeping
Indoors by Jim Holt (PTC), First
Dance by Jerry Thompson(PTC), Diff’rent
by Eugene O’Neill (PTC) and Our Town
by Thornton Wilder,  (CTek Arts).  Karen currently makes her home in Santa Fe,
New Mexico, where she is pursuing work in film.


Photo: Bobby Miller

Mike Steers (LIGHTING DESIGN) is a graduate of the HARTT School of Music with a BFA in Musical Theater Performance whose Directing Credits BENT(1997 University of Hartford), Company and You’re a Good Man, Charlie Brown (Counter Productions), Children of Eden and Once on This Island. Mike’s Scenic Design credits include: Oliver (PTC),Blithe Spirit (Perigrine Theater Company) Oklahoma!, Lend Me a Tenor, The Tenderland (Massasoit Theater Company), The Medium (NYC/PTown) Raisin in the Sun, Fiddler on The Roof, Virginia Wolfe, Lion in Winter, The King and I, Lobby Hero (Counter Productions), 42nd Street, LaCage Aux Folles, Hair (Company Theater) Children of Eden, Once on this Island (OAHS) and A Midsummer Nights (University of Hartford University Players). Lighting Design credits: Streetcar Named Desire (University Players) , God of Carnage, Diff’rent (Provincetown Theatre Company) The Baltimore Waltz (Animus Ensemble, Boston) and the World Premier of Myra Slotnick’s The Weight of Water (NYC/PTown). Mike can  be seen in ILLUSIONS, Provincetown’s “longest running drag show” at The Crown and Anchor as Hostess and MC Anita Cocktail (You can follow him on twitter  @AnitaCocktailPT).

Ellen Rousseau (SCENIC DESIGN) is scenic designer, artist, and master carpenter. She is fascinated by the ways in which spacial relationships inform context and story. Some of her design credits include Inappropriate: The Musical (Odyssey Theater in Los Angeles), Across The Pond (world premier at the Provincetown Theater), The Weight of Water (world premier at the Provincetown Theater Company and The Producer’s Club in NYC), Tennessee Williams Songbook (Provincetown Tennessee Williams Theater Festival and in NYC at the Five Angels Theater), Auto De Fe (Provincetown Tennessee Williams Festival), Snowman In The Dunes (PTC), Arsenic and Old Lace (PTC), Reasons To Live (PTC), The Food Chain (PTC), Merry Wives of Windsor (PTC), The Story of Ibis (The Center For Coastal Studies), You’re A Good Man Charlie Brown (Children’s Theater of Maine), The Dumb Waiter (Russell Square Players), Victoria Station (Russell Square Players). She was Technical Director for The Odd Couple - Female Version at the Provincetown Theater Company. When she is not designing for the theater she can be found in her shop making art and furniture on Cape Cod. Visit her website at www.houseofrousseau.com.




Tim McCarthy (PROJECTION DESIGN) is a Gay Video Historian. He has traveled the world since 1990 with a video camera documenting LGBTIA life in 90 countries so far and all 7 continents. He is creating a visual record of this time of firsts for LGBTI people around the globe. It is both his medicine and his legacy. Tim was with the first International Gay and Lesbian Delegation to the Soviet Union in 1991. He was the first reporter credentialed by the White House for Gay TV in 1993. His second film Nocebo + Witchcraft chronicles his trip to bring HIV awareness back to it's homeland in Uganda in 1999. He was on the first Gay Expedition to Antarctica, in 2000. Most recently the film “How To Survive a Plague”, which uses some of his archival footage, was nominated for an Academy Award, in 2013.

story:
>> To get a ticket for the event, fill in the registration form here and then buy a perk for 20€ or more <<

If you see this campaign you probably heard about Hummingbird Blues already, maybe attended the last year edition or know someone, who did.

We will make our explanation quick then: Hummingbird Blues has been going on since 2015. It is a blues dancing exchange based in Cracow, where we dance mad, chill hard and share crazy. There is no regular classes and no competitions. Instead we have lots of daytime activities, lots of music and low entrance fee.

The campaign

Since we want to make our event as inclusive as possible, we try to keep the ticket prices low. We also have a desire to keep the cozy atmosphere here, so we could connect with everyone and still have time for dancing.

That is why we decided to crowdfund this event. You can support our exchange by donating some more money or buying perks. Thanks to extra donations we are able to boost up our event with more bands, better dancefloors, and generally more less dance-oriented goodies.

However cool it is to triple the suggested costs of the event and have many live bands, foods and floors that don’t leave splinters in your feet, HB2017 is gonna be awesome regardless of its price!

Check out our: Website, Facebook Page, Facebook Event.

story:
The Story of the Show

In 2015, I (show creator Brent Black) was watching a space-themed dance show when I suddenly thought of the character "Chekov" in his spacesuit from the Star Trek movie The Wrath of Khan. This sparked an idea: Could Khan work as a parody musical? Now, over four years later, the answer seems to be a resounding YES! Along the way, Dany Roth of Syfy Wire helped me to shape a framing device that included Picard and Data from Star Trek: The Next Generation.  We've now held three developmental showings to get it in shape for an off-Broadway production in New York City, and the upcoming Philadelphia Fringe Festival reading is the final step!

What Will This Pay For?

  • We're paying actors $250 apiece and would love to pay them more!
  • We'll be renting rehearsal space and performance space by the hour; it adds up!
  • Gotta pay for marketing, audio equipment, and music stands!
  • If we don't reach our goal, at least you've made a dent in our debt!

What's the point?

I'm a Trekkie and a musical theatre fan. The prospect of making people like myself laugh, celebrating their fandom, and presenting them with a tuneful score is a years-long dream, and you can help make it come true.

What are the Risks?

There's no risk! The show is happening either way. This is a fundraiser to offset costs so that we don't lose thousands of dollars.

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't contribute? Help spread the word! You can post the link to our campaign on social media, or even just tell a friend who might be interested in supporting.

story:
There is a secret underworld where the impossible still lives. Once a month at Milwaukee's Historic Miramar Theater it opens it gates for a spectacle beyond description.

During these gatherings you can see such wonders as....
 
Tradition Circus Arts
Glamorous Burlesque
Human Oddities
Impossible Magic
Insane Sideshow
Vaudevillian Novelties
One-of-a-kind Performances
 
With your contributions we will be able to.
 
-Continue our show through the 2013 season
-Film its acts for future generations
-Take the show on the road.

As with any project this large it ultimately can not exist but as a labor of love.

Everyone involved puts in efforts above and beyond time and time again. If you are unable to contribute monetarily please consider helping by spreading the word by sharing on your social networking sites.

Keep up to date on current news here

www.facebook.com/groups/deadmans

 

Thank you Kindly,

Prof. Pinkerton Xyloma

& Dead Man's Carnival

story:
This project operates under the 501c3 Umbrella of Salvage Vanguard Theater making

ALL CONTRIBUTIONS TAX DEDUCTIBLE

 

Who and What…

 

Rhododendron Descent is an evening-length dance performance inspired by Mt. Everest climbing expeditions. It is the fourth and final dance of a series. It is the piece that was visualized from the beginning but only now do we have the opportunity to realize the true vision of this work. The three related works performed so far, have gained serious momentum with audiences, technical needs and budget demands. The dancers, riggers, musicians, designers, technicians, and venue are all in place with funds to get us going. The only missing piece is you. It is your support that will get us to opening night!

 

Jennifer Sherburn is an independent choreographer and dancer. She has presented work, collaborated and studied in Honolulu, London, New York City, Tasmania and Austin. After relocating from NY to Austin nearly 3 years ago, Jennifer has been working very hard developing this project and has had great success! She is now embarking on the final stages of development and can’t move forward with out your support!

 

You are over 28,000 ft. above sea level and there is no turning back. Though breathless and even doubtful, with only a few hundred feet left to go, you must traverse impossible terrain that delivers you to the summit of the highest peak in the world. This is where you connect with the expansiveness of the universe; a place where the curvature of the earth reveals itself in the horizon.  It took over 30 years to carve a route to the top of Everest. Since then thousands have tried, countless failed and hundreds have died.

 

This project is a response to stories of climbers facing hurricane-force winds and diminishing oxygen supply, traversing impossible terrain, and the moments of recovery that fuel determination. Intrigued by man’s will to face one of the upmost physical human endeavors, Jennifer visualized a creative interpretation, a response to her findings through dance.

 

What we’ve received so far…

This project has been recognized by the City of Austin and The Creative Fund, both have awarded us grants that propel this work into its fruition. We have earned a rent subsidy that allows us to perform in the ideal venue, the beautiful St. Elmo Soundstage.  It is the perfect venue, meeting all technical specifications and truly supports the project’s innovative ideas for set design, effects, climber’s rigging and sound. There are no boundaries within this venue allowing all creative possibilities to be explored.

 

What we offer to the community…

Rhododendron Descent contributes to the diversity of arts by offering an entirely new level of audience experience. Mt. Everest climbing expeditions are typically written about in books and magazines, discussed in the news, or documented in films.  Creating an artistic expression through dance is different; it offers a new way to connect with a reality so far from everyday life. Importantly, live dance connects the physical and emotional challenges and achievements that are only imagined when hearing or reading about the subject.

 

What we need and what you get…

We need $10,000

This will secure every expense before we open the show!

This means that all money that is earned through ticket sales will afford us the opportunity to tour! Yeah Baby!

Philanthropists’ rewards are good! Check out our incentives – This is gonna be a lot of fun Y’all!

 

Your money will go directly toward

•Paying the artists & technicians!

•Publicity!

•Venue fees

•Lighting instrument rental

•Climber’s rigging (ropes, harnesses… Gear!)

•Costumes and Props

 

Get loud and make some noise! Spread the word; generate the buzz… check out Indiegogo’s share tools to do it!

story:
The Square Foot Theatre Company Mission Statement:

To establish and maintain a venue for the visual and performing arts through support and education while providing opportunities to experience the arts through observation, hands on participation and education.

Short Summary

With 26 shows under our belts in 5 short years - 850 actors have graced our stages, over 25,000 audience members have witnessed the magical talent.  Now, it's your turn!

What We Need

Moving our theatre to a warehouse space has become quite the obstacle.  With town codes and regulations constantly changing - we've been blindsided by circumstances beyond our control.  Please help us lift this burden!

The Impact

Stand up and be counted!  We are not asking for much - only one dollar to be exact.  A donation of $1 and the promise that you will share our video with your friends and family along the way.  Allow us the opportunity to give the community a venue to have our talents shine.  Our $20,000 goal is a dream in the making. Help us get the word out and keep the arts alive in the community!  Believe me, it matters! 

 

 

Much appreciated!

Jared Andrew Brown

Artistic Director

The Square Foot Theatre Company

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • Help us get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools and help us be heard!
