story:
Short Summary

 

Greetings.  My name is Daniel Patrick Fay.  I am a NYC based puppeteer, designer and performer.  Recently my creative partner, Andrew Livingston (a composer) and I were accepted to the Puppet Lab at St. Ann’s Warehouse for a piece that has been in our notebooks for some time.  The piece explored the strange events that centered around a small West Virginian town called Point Pleasant.  On November 15, 1966, two young couples from Point Pleasant, West Virginia encountered; what they described as “a large winged man with glowing red eyes.”  This would be the first of many sightings of the creature that would be dubbed the “Mothman” by local papers, and ushered in a year of terror for the small town.

A local reporter named Mary Hire prints the eye-witness accounts of the Mothman.  As the sightings intensify, and strange reports grow even stranger still, all activity comes to a screeching halt, when on a cold December evening the town suffered a great tragedy.  For seemingly no reason at all, The Silver Bridge, the main artery connecting two towns separated by the Ohio River suddenly, and unexpectedly collapsed sending dozens of people into the icy depths of the river, which would be, the climatic, and terrible end to the supernatural events that haunted the town for just over a year.    

The development of the piece is currently underway.  In the past few months we’ve taken the piece from sketches and notes into a completed script, some partially developed scenes, and some puppets.  The piece features bunraku puppetry, some miniature live feed on a scale model of  Point Pleasant, and some shadow puppetry sequences.   Aesthetically, the piece is black and white tale that employs a sketchy, grainy quality and lends itself nicely to the eerie tale being told.   It is a sensory experience, using light, sound, & puppetry to recreate some of the accounts that came from the citizens of Point Pleasant.  The piece is meant to convey the overall sentiment of this time, in this specific place: the fear, sadness, and the lack of comprehension.  It is not our intention to debate the validity of the sightings, and encounters, but rather depict through music, movement, and puppetry the experiences of the people who, encountered, and lived through this phenomena. 

We are endeavoring to raise funds to pay our talent who have helped us develop the piece thuas far.  Your contributions can support the realization of this piece and place some money in the hands of the incredible group of puppeteers and musicians that have dedicated their time and talent during the developmental process.  All of the proceeds from the fundaraiaser awill go into the handas of the people who have dedicated the better part of 6 months to this project.  Thank you for your support.  

 

Daniel Patrick Fay and Andrew Livingston

story:
EATING POMEGRANATES NAKED GETS ITS WORLD PREMIER ON AUGUST 8 2013. HELP IT LOOK AS LUSCIOUS AS IT SOUNDS!

My name is Andrea Scott and I'm a playwright in Toronto Canada. I've been writing plays for about 3 years but Eating Pomegranates Naked  has me the most excited. With support from the Ontario Arts Council, Obsidian Theatre, The Grand Theatre, Alumnae Theatre, and bcurrent, I’m happy to announce that Eating Pomegranates Naked will finally take to the stage!

In order to create the show as I envision  I need a little bit of your time and money before the show launches on August 8.

In a festival setting it is common practice to split the box office profits. However, even  sell-out shows don't guarantee a living wage. I want to give the creative team: actors, director, stage manager and designers proper compensation for taking this play to the next level.  

RELATIONSHIPS ARE HARD

This play is for women, men, and couples alike, who are facing conception challenges and endured polite faces when asked over and over again “When are you going to have a baby?”

20% of all pregnancies end in miscarriage but people still talk about it in hushed tones.  
11-15% of all couples experience infertility but nobody talks about it.

Let's open the conversation.

This play is for women, men, and couples alike, who are facing conception challenges and endured polite faces when asked over and over again “When are you going to have a baby?”

While interviewing directors for a public reading last year 3 women confessed that they had endured a miscarriage. They whispered it while furtively making sure nobody could hear them.

You know these people, they are your friends, your family and maybe, you are these people. You are giving to Eating Pomegranates Naked to spread the word that baring yourself emotionally can be the most honest and helpful thing you can do for yourself and others.

THAT'S A LOT OF CASH

I live in a tiny apartment with silverfish as pets so I completely understand if $20 is too much to donate; canned beans are my friends too! If all you can do is tell people about Eating Pomegranates Naked because you want to help out a new playwright then you've done more than enough. Use those social media wizards like Facebook and Twitter and maybe it will help this play. It's all good.
story_txt:
EATING POMEGRANATES NAKED GETS ITS WORLD PREMIER ON AUGUST 8 2013. HELP IT LOOK AS LUSCIOUS AS IT SOUNDS!
My name is Andrea Scott and I'm a playwright in Toronto Canada. I've been writing plays for about 3 years but Eating Pomegranates Naked  has me the most excited. With support from the Ontario Arts Council, Obsidian Theatre, The Grand Theatre, Alumnae Theatre, and bcurrent, I’m happy to announce that Eating Pomegranates Naked will finally take to the stage!
In order to create the show as I envision  I need a little bit of your time and money before the show launches on August 8.
In a festival setting it is common practice to split the box office profits. However, even  sell-out shows don't guarantee a living wage. I want to give the creative team: actors, director, stage manager and designers proper compensation for taking this play to the next level.  
RELATIONSHIPS ARE HARD
This play is for women, men, and couples alike, who are facing conception challenges and endured polite faces when asked over and over again “When are you going to have a baby?”
20% of all pregnancies end in miscarriage but people still talk about it in hushed tones.  11-15% of all couples experience infertility but nobody talks about it.
Let's open the conversation.
This play is for women, men, and couples alike, who are facing conception challenges and endured polite faces when asked over and over again “When are you going to have a baby?”
While interviewing directors for a public reading last year 3 women confessed that they had endured a miscarriage. They whispered it while furtively making sure nobody could hear them.
You know these people, they are your friends, your family and maybe, you are these people. You are giving to Eating Pomegranates Naked to spread the word that baring yourself emotionally can be the most honest and helpful thing you can do for yourself and others.
THAT'S A LOT OF CASH
I live in a tiny apartment with silverfish as pets so I completely understand if $20 is too much to donate; canned beans are my friends too! If all you can do is tell people about Eating Pomegranates Naked because you want to help out a new playwright then you've done more than enough. Use those social media wizards like Facebook and Twitter and maybe it will help this play. It's all good.

story:
ON CAMPUS is an original full length play by award winning playwright Steve Sherman, directed by Marc Santa Maria that reflects the pressures put upon university students who try to establish various relationships despite social and cultural differences.  Meanwhile, a precarious relationship between a student and professor throws all characters into a downward spiral, forcing everyone to help each other overcome the challenges of college life.

Starring: Caitlin Gold, Jake Millgard*, Osvaldo Plasencia*, Sarah Saunders, Steve Sherman*, Ed Stelz, and Chloe Tuttle
* Appearing courtesy of Actors Equity Association.

story:
Our Story

Pacific Coast Theatre Company was formed in 2009 by a group of high school graduates who wanted to help bring theatre to the Mira Mesa area of San Diego. The community had no active theatre group producing live theatre, aside from Mira Mesa High School. We took a leap of faith and formed Pacific Coast Theatre Company and have been trying to help schools in the San Diego Unified School District by teaching improv workshops to drama departments and lending our technical theatre expertise to students who love theatre as much as we do. PCTC, in association with Mira Mesa High School, is now presenting its first musical: The 25th Annual Putnam County Spelling Bee. Together we want to produce a musical that will bring the community together to laugh and have fun. The funding we receive here will help us produce a high quality musical that the whole community can enjoy.

The Impact

Our campaign is designed to help produce an amazing musical for Mira Mesa and beyond. Our mission is to foster, promote, and increase public knowledge and appreciation for the arts in San Diego county through theatre. We hope to expand our outreach to the community by being able to publicize our production in local news papers and radio. With the money we will be able to drastically expand our production by hiring musicians so that we can have a live orchestra. The funding from this project also helps us meet our budget goals and bolster the ability of both Pacific Coast Theatre Company and the Mira Mesa High Drama Department to bring quality theatre to our community.

What We Need & What You Get

The money you help us raise will be spent on the production of this musical production. We need the help of generous donors like yourselves to help spread the love of art, and reengage a new generation, and let them see the beauty of live theatre. Producing a show like this is not cheap. Costs include:

Rights and Royalties: $2,300.00
Marketing: $900.00
Technical Equipment: $200.00 (including sets)
Lightning Equipment: $100.00

More importantly, though, there are many things our current budget cannot provide. We would love to add live musicians as well as stipends to members of the cast and crew to this list!

If we are unable to meet our funding goal the production will still continue, we may have to cut back on certain aspects of the production. Your contribution will make a world of difference to the members of the community, the members of the cast and crew, and the staff at Pacific Coast Theatre Company.

Other Ways You Can Help

After you have contributed to our performance be sure to tell your friends and family about our cause! Remember you can use the share tools to help spread the word! Word of mouth is our most powerful tool so please be sure and help out.


And don't forget that the best way you can show our cast and crew that you care is not just donating, but also enjoying the show this September 23rd and 24th.

story:
Why is it that nice girls get walked all over?

Sweet Ashley St. Helens wants so many things—freedom, love, and a scholarship—but she’s overworked, overwhelmed, and feeling lost since her parents died. Then there’s the, um, foot problem...

When her eccentric godfather shows up, the magic begins. A soul-and-body makeover before senior prom—with just the right shoes—reminds Ashley how awesome she is. 

  • Listen to Ashley whining about not being able to go to prom.
  • Listen to how her drag-queen godfather Harry encourages Ashley to let her feelings out.
  • Listen to Harry helping Ashley choose just the right shoe to wear to prom.

NEW SONG! Listen to the newly mastered soundtrack for "A Girl Like Me!"

Love it? We thought you would!

Who We Are

Michael O'Dell is an incredibly generative musician and composer, who can play a dozen instruments and write symphonic scores from his head with just pencil and paper on a BART train. He's worked as music director for dozens (maybe hundreds?) of musicals, and he's written/produced/directed his own musical, Waiting: The Musical. His website is www.blankcanvasmusic.com. 

Kristen Caven is a multi-disciplinary creative who has written books and articles about parenting, psychology, health, humor, philosophy and creativity. A mother, a teacher, and cartoonist, her forthcoming book is The Bullying Antidote: Superpower Your Kids For Life. Better yet, she created a novella version of The Souls of Her Feet for your e-reader! Learn more about her offerings, from graphic novels to greeting cards, at www.kristencaven.com, or www.littlepig.com.

What We Want

We met the year we both turned 40, and agreed to "knock this story out" in a way that would make you forget Wicked. But time (plus patience, plus perserverance) is polishing the facets of this gem in ways we could never have imagined. We both want to be successful at our craft and have fulfilling artistic careers. The Souls of Her Feet is a wonderful project that has brought out the best in our muses, and we want to see it on stage!

We want to bring this wonderful story to the big time. And our contributors will help us to help humanity see and love itself—especially young women at that "finding yourself" age—with all of the stories in this series. 

What We Need

This is the first of several fundraising campaigns as we take our "little steps" toward the stage. This campaign will fund three little steps:

  1. A completed score (including 2 new songs!)
  2. a re-formatted script, and 
  3. Demo recordings of several songs.

Funds will be used for travel (we live 1500 miles apart) and talent—yes, you will help employ actors and musicians! All funds will go to furthering the project, whether or not we reach our current financial goal.

The other, NON-MONETARY thing that you can help us with is little stories that help fill out our backstory (see "A Penny For Your Thoughts," right). Go to www.fairytalereality.com, find a fairy tale that reminds you of you, and leave a sentence or a paragraph in the comments. YES, YOU CAN MAKE STUFF UP. This is a creative endeavor!

What You Get


If you DO choose to donate (and we need all the help we can get), you can get some great perks, such as:

  • An ebook of the novella*
  • A t-shirt*
  • A memento from the shoebox! This is actually a large basket of collectibles that devotees have offered over the years: a shoe keychain, shoe napkins, jewelled pencils, etc... fun, princessy, shoe swag!
  • A printed book of the novella

NOTE: You can donate ANY amount above the suggested amount... just pick your perk!

*also available at the website above

The Impact

This project is a real labor of love for us. Kristen wrote the first draft a dozen years ago to create a space within the princess mythologies for real girls, translating magic into reality. The story teaches us that:

  • When we're bullied, things will change;
  • Friends get us through things;
  • We can find awesomeness in our imperfections;
  • Love happens in the weirdest ways; and
  • The right shoes can make a difference.

We hope that our multi-platform expressions will help build a love of literature in all its forms in the hearts and minds of our fans, plus blast their self-esteem through the roof. (It has certainly done so for us!) In the two readings we have done in developing it, our volunteer actors have been drawn to the chewy dialogue, crisp characters and challenging music. With their help in shaping the script we hope to create a work that actors everywhere will swoon to perform.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help! Please share this page — or any of our pages (website, blog, facebook page...) with anyone who you think will enjoy the project or be able to support us in any way.

In her opening song Ashley wants to "activate the greatness in the souls of everyone I serve."

And so do we! Please join us.

story:
Help Pipe Dreams Studio Theatre, a student-run theatre company in central Illinois, raise $7,000 to purchase a new dimmer rack for our theatre.

What is Pipe Dreams Studio Theatre?

Pipe Dreams Studio Theatre is a 90 seat black box theatre located near Millikin University in Decatur, IL. With the creation of the new B.F.A Theatre Administration degree in the Department of Theatre & Dance, the faculty began to wonder how they could give students a "hands-on" approach to running a theatre. Pipe Dreams Studio Theatre was then generously donated to the students to run as a company and to produce the work we want to see.

All of our work is done by the students and entirely on a volunteer basis. Each individual student is required to do “lab hours” for the semester for those enrolled in the Entrepreneurship: Pipe Dreams Studio Theatre course. However, anyone who is interested in volunteering with us is highly encouraged and welcomed.

In the past, students have utilized our space to create the work they wanted to see: whether it be original or published work. In the Spring 2011 season we had both original and published works. In addition we took on the task of producing our first production: an original work titled Affinity.

What do we want to DO?

Last fall you helped us produce our first FULLY PRODUCED season. In a mere 3 Days you helped us reach our goal of $800 to fund the technical aspects of our productions. 

Now we are in a critical state. In theatre, the lighting is one of the most obvious design elements. Imagine seeing a show with set and costume but no light. This is the fate that Pipe Dreams Studio Theatre is now facing. 

In theatre we use dimmers to control the power that our lighting instruments receive. Recently 6 of our dimmers died. That's right. They went caput in the middle of a technical rehearsal. In order to maintain the high artistic quality we achieved last season, we need your help. 

To keep the lights on in Pipe Dreams Studio Theatre we MUST get a new dimmer rack. YOU can flip the switch; YOU can keep the lights on.

How can YOU help?

By donating to our campaign, you'll be supporting emerging artists as they create work they want to create. There's also a plethora of gifts and rewards for donating to our campaign with everything from complimentary tickets to having our light booth named after you!

 

And because Pipe Dreams Studio Theatre is a non-profit organization, your donation is 100% tax decuctable!

 

With the lights on we'll be able to produce our two fantastic productions:

RABBIT HOLE (March 2-4, 2012) and REEFER MADNESS (April 19-22, 2012)

 

Thank you! Your support means the world here at PDST.

 

Keep the Lights On!

-Pipe Dreams Studio Theatre

 

More information on Pipe Dreams Studio Theatre: www.millikin.edu/pipedreams

To view our 2010-2011 Annual Report: http://www.millikin.edu/academics/cfa/dtd/pd/about/Documents/PDANNUALREPORT10-11.pdf

story:
Our Story

We are a group of seven. We've got a playwright, a director, a producer, three actors, and a playwright's brother who helps in all ways possible. For the past couple of months we have been working on this little play called Scottish Sperm written by our very own Jacqueline McLaren. 


We've had readings through New York City, fundraisers, beer blasts, numerous amount of rehearsals, and we are about to put our New York run of the show at Pace University in downtown Manhattan. After this is all said and done, we will head over to Edinburgh, Scotland to participate in the Edinburgh Festival Fringe for the entire month of August. 


Edinburgh Festival Fringe is the largest arts festival in the world and takes place every year for three weeks in August. Our show will be one of literally thousands. We will be performing a total of 20 times at The Space @ Jury's Inn. 


Meet Us:


Jacqueline McLaren (Playwright) is a playwright known for her irreverent, cutting humor and ear for dialogue. Scottish Sperm will be Ms. McLaren's first production at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival. Ms. McLaren's previous play How to Build a Bomb won the Olga and Paul Menn Foundation Award. How to Build a Bomb was also selected for PACE University's New Works Festival in Manhattan in 2010. Two of Ms. McLaren's plays were chosen for the University Theater's New Plays Festivals in Chicago. Ms. McLaren is a writer on Tu Nite con Lorenzo Parro, on NBC/Telemundo, that network's first bilingual talk show. Ms. McLaren is a graduate of the University of Chicago. She taught at several public schools in the notoriously rough South Side of Chicago throughout her four years.


Grant Kretchik (director) holds an MFA in Acting from the New School University, and is the head of Pace University's BFA Acting Program. He has appeared as an actor Off Broadway and regionally. Film/TV: Law and Order, Guiding Light, As The World Turns, Man on the Moon, and When Harry Tries to Marry (which Kretchik also helped produce). He has worked as both an actor and director at La Mama etc., and been accepted into the Stage Directors Choreographers Society's 2010/2011 Observership Season. This past October Kretchik assisted on the first Broadway National Tour of Next to Normal, directed by Michael Grief. In September 2011, he will be directing The Parade by Tennessee Williams at the Tennessee Williams International Theater Festival in Provincetown, MA. www.grantkretchik.com


Rebecca Cunningham (Producer) - Rebecca is recent graduate of Pace University in New York City with a Bachelor of Arts degree in Directing. Directing credits include: The Vagina Monologues, Out in the Open: Stories of Queer Oppression and Empowerment, Dog Sees God: Confessions of a Teenage Blockhead, Uncommon Women and Others, How to Build a Bomb, Freshwater, romance, and With the Lights Out. AD credits: Sign Me, Who is Dan Schiller?, Gin Joint, The Beggar's Opera, and Glory of Living.


Megan Channell (Sarah) recently appeared in Spleen Theatre Company's inaugural production of Bound at New York Theatre Workshop. Theatre credits include work at Theater for the New City, The Abingdon Theatre, Manhattan Repertory, Curan Repertory, and Phare Play Productions. Film/TV: Sarina's Song, All My Children. She is a graduate of Emory University.


Dylan Lamb (Robert) is a graduate of New York University's Tisch School of the Arts and the recipient of the Chair's Award of Excellence in Dramatic Writing. He has worked for Warner Brothers Television as part of their Creative Lab and apprenticed at the Guthrie Theater in his hometown of Minneapolis, Minnesota. New York Theater: Demon Dreams (Gene Frankel), Glengarry Glen Ross (Cooper Union), John Faustus And The Overclocked Death Drive (Magic Futurebox), Ivanov (Tank Theater). Writing: Alligator Summer (New York Fringe), There Is No Isabelle (Minnesota Fringe), Rebirth of a Little Beauty (3LD), A Man Of My Word (NYU Festival of New Works).


Samantha Steinmetz (Emma) Recent credits include The Remarkable Rooming House of Mme. Le Monde (La Mama), Uncommon Women and Others, The Little Dog Laughed, The Bald Soprano, The House of Bernarda Alba, The Zoo Story, The Vagina Monologues, School, and A Piece of My Heart. Samantha moved from Kansas to New York in 2009 to study at BFA Acting at Pace University. She also trains with Ken Schatz in New York and is a recent graduate of the Circle in the Square Summer Conservatory. www.samanthasteinmetz.com



The Impact

Apparently, theatre costs a lot of money and there isn't a whole lot of it circulating around. We've got to pay for things like venues, food for the actors, advertising, props, plane tickets, living expenses, and the list goes on. 


If we don't raise enough money, there is a chance we won't all make it to Scotland. And for this show to work in it's entirety and to fullest potential, it is ESSENTIAL that we all make it there.  


The most important thing to know is that the group of has been working extremely hard to get this incredible piece to international audiences. It is a chance to show our art to people who would never see it otherwise, and for many of us, to finally begin our careers in theatre. 

What We Need & What You Get

Our ultimate goal is $5,000. In the time allotted we realize this might be an overreach but the show is incredibly important to us all and we have done everything and anything to make sure we can make Scottish Sperm succeed. After all, it is "the strongest".


Okay so here is the breakdown.


$750 - airfare which will make sure that we all get there. 

$1,000 - venue 

100-200 pounds - for food for each cast member every week. 


Anything extra goes to advertising, perishable props, shipping props from NY to Scotland,  petty cash, and anything else we run into along the way. 


As said previously, with the help of Tilicoultry Media, we've been raising money through staged readings at places like Ars Nova and TJ Byrnes Bar and Restaurant where we received generous donations from Scottish Sperm Bank Donors. We've had beer blasts in Williamsburg, Brooklyn where we raised hundreds of dollars from college students throughout NYC. We're also raising money through our New York run at Pace University, 7/21-7/23. 


But it is still not enough! 


No matter what, this show will go up in Scotland in August. We would just like all 7 of us to be there in order for it everything to run smoothly.


All new Scottish Sperm Bank donors will be added to our Generous Contributors list in our program. 


$1-$5 - A virtual high-five!


$5-$75 - You will receive a special thank you on your Facebook wall or email from one of the Scottish Sperm  cast members!


$100 - Receive a personalized video from all of us to you!


$200-$500 - A personalized video as well as an autographed Scottish program from the entire cast and team.

 

$1,000 or more - Personalized video, autographed Scottish program, and a wonderful Scottish souvenir personally picked out just for you. 


Even $1 helps us in a great way!



NOTE: None of us are getting paid for this! Our payment has been the fortunate experience of being able to go to Scotland and participate in the Fringe. 



Other Ways You Can Help

Can't afford to donate? Or just like us a ton? Share this page! Post it on your Facebook! E-mail it to your friends! Tweet about it (@ScottishSperm, #scottishsperm) Tumble about us! We hear Google+ is a thing to and if you think anyone on that site is active in anyway possible, post this page on there too! We need all the help we can get!


Big thanks to all past, present, and future Scottish Sperm Bank Donors!
story_txt:
Our Story
We are a group of seven. We've got a playwright, a director, a producer, three actors, and a playwright's brother who helps in all ways possible. For the past couple of months we have been working on this little play called Scottish Sperm written by our very own Jacqueline McLaren. 

We've had readings through New York City, fundraisers, beer blasts, numerous amount of rehearsals, and we are about to put our New York run of the show at Pace University in downtown Manhattan. After this is all said and done, we will head over to Edinburgh, Scotland to participate in the Edinburgh Festival Fringe for the entire month of August. 

Edinburgh Festival Fringe is the largest arts festival in the world and takes place every year for three weeks in August. Our show will be one of literally thousands. We will be performing a total of 20 times at The Space @ Jury's Inn. 

Meet Us:


Jacqueline McLaren (Playwright) is a playwright known for her irreverent, cutting humor and ear for dialogue. Scottish Sperm will be Ms. McLaren's first production at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival. Ms. McLaren's previous play How to Build a Bomb won the Olga and Paul Menn Foundation Award. How to Build a Bomb was also selected for PACE University's New Works Festival in Manhattan in 2010. Two of Ms. McLaren's plays were chosen for the University Theater's New Plays Festivals in Chicago. Ms. McLaren is a writer on Tu Nite con Lorenzo Parro, on NBC/Telemundo, that network's first bilingual talk show. Ms. McLaren is a graduate of the University of Chicago. She taught at several public schools in the notoriously rough South Side of Chicago throughout her four years.

Grant Kretchik (director) holds an MFA in Acting from the New School University, and is the head of Pace University's BFA Acting Program. He has appeared as an actor Off Broadway and regionally. Film/TV: Law and Order, Guiding Light, As The World Turns, Man on the Moon, and When Harry Tries to Marry (which Kretchik also helped produce). He has worked as both an actor and director at La Mama etc., and been accepted into the Stage Directors Choreographers Society's 2010/2011 Observership Season. This past October Kretchik assisted on the first Broadway National Tour of Next to Normal, directed by Michael Grief. In September 2011, he will be directing The Parade by Tennessee Williams at the Tennessee Williams International Theater Festival in Provincetown, MA. www.grantkretchik.com

Rebecca Cunningham (Producer) - Rebecca is recent graduate of Pace University in New York City with a Bachelor of Arts degree in Directing. Directing credits include: The Vagina Monologues, Out in the Open: Stories of Queer Oppression and Empowerment, Dog Sees God: Confessions of a Teenage Blockhead, Uncommon Women and Others, How to Build a Bomb, Freshwater, romance, and With the Lights Out. AD credits: Sign Me, Who is Dan Schiller?, Gin Joint, The Beggar's Opera, and Glory of Living.

Megan Channell (Sarah) recently appeared in Spleen Theatre Company's inaugural production of Bound at New York Theatre Workshop. Theatre credits include work at Theater for the New City, The Abingdon Theatre, Manhattan Repertory, Curan Repertory, and Phare Play Productions. Film/TV: Sarina's Song, All My Children. She is a graduate of Emory University.

Dylan Lamb (Robert) is a graduate of New York University's Tisch School of the Arts and the recipient of the Chair's Award of Excellence in Dramatic Writing. He has worked for Warner Brothers Television as part of their Creative Lab and apprenticed at the Guthrie Theater in his hometown of Minneapolis, Minnesota. New York Theater: Demon Dreams (Gene Frankel), Glengarry Glen Ross (Cooper Union), John Faustus And The Overclocked Death Drive (Magic Futurebox), Ivanov (Tank Theater). Writing: Alligator Summer (New York Fringe), There Is No Isabelle (Minnesota Fringe), Rebirth of a Little Beauty (3LD), A Man Of My Word (NYU Festival of New Works).

Samantha Steinmetz (Emma) Recent credits include The Remarkable Rooming House of Mme. Le Monde (La Mama), Uncommon Women and Others, The Little Dog Laughed, The Bald Soprano, The House of Bernarda Alba, The Zoo Story, The Vagina Monologues, School, and A Piece of My Heart. Samantha moved from Kansas to New York in 2009 to study at BFA Acting at Pace University. She also trains with Ken Schatz in New York and is a recent graduate of the Circle in the Square Summer Conservatory. www.samanthasteinmetz.com



The Impact
Apparently, theatre costs a lot of money and there isn't a whole lot of it circulating around. We've got to pay for things like venues, food for the actors, advertising, props, plane tickets, living expenses, and the list goes on. 

If we don't raise enough money, there is a chance we won't all make it to Scotland. And for this show to work in it's entirety and to fullest potential, it is ESSENTIAL that we all make it there.  

The most important thing to know is that the group of has been working extremely hard to get this incredible piece to international audiences. It is a chance to show our art to people who would never see it otherwise, and for many of us, to finally begin our careers in theatre. 

What We Need & What You Get
Our ultimate goal is $5,000. In the time allotted we realize this might be an overreach but the show is incredibly important to us all and we have done everything and anything to make sure we can make Scottish Sperm succeed. After all, it is "the strongest".

Okay so here is the breakdown.

$750 - airfare which will make sure that we all get there. 
$1,000 - venue 
100-200 pounds - for food for each cast member every week. 

Anything extra goes to advertising, perishable props, shipping props from NY to Scotland,  petty cash, and anything else we run into along the way. 

As said previously, with the help of Tilicoultry Media, we've been raising money through staged readings at places like Ars Nova and TJ Byrnes Bar and Restaurant where we received generous donations from Scottish Sperm Bank Donors. We've had beer blasts in Williamsburg, Brooklyn where we raised hundreds of dollars from college students throughout NYC. We're also raising money through our New York run at Pace University, 7/21-7/23. 

But it is still not enough! 

No matter what, this show will go up in Scotland in August. We would just like all 7 of us to be there in order for it everything to run smoothly.

All new Scottish Sperm Bank donors will be added to our Generous Contributors list in our program. 

$1-$5 - A virtual high-five!

$5-$75 - You will receive a special thank you on your Facebook wall or email from one of the Scottish Sperm  cast members!

$100 - Receive a personalized video from all of us to you!

$200-$500 - A personalized video as well as an autographed Scottish program from the entire cast and team.
 
$1,000 or more - Personalized video, autographed Scottish program, and a wonderful Scottish souvenir personally picked out just for you. 

Even $1 helps us in a great way!


NOTE: None of us are getting paid for this! Our payment has been the fortunate experience of being able to go to Scotland and participate in the Fringe. 



Other Ways You Can Help
Can't afford to donate? Or just like us a ton? Share this page! Post it on your Facebook! E-mail it to your friends! Tweet about it (@ScottishSperm, #scottishsperm) Tumble about us! We hear Google+ is a thing to and if you think anyone on that site is active in anyway possible, post this page on there too! We need all the help we can get!

Big thanks to all past, present, and future Scottish Sperm Bank Donors!

story:
Our Story

Two young girls, Shelley and Jessica, escaped the dolldrums of old toys and older brothers to venture on a trip to Florida with nothing but empty blue suitcases.  They quickly returned home after realizing 4 and 7 year olds were much too young for the mean streets of the city.  They vowed to one day escape for good.  Many years later, they have honoured that vow by not only committing to a life of escape (ie. acting) but by founding Empty Suitcase Theatre.  We are committed to producing plays that offer strong female roles and put the women front and center, increase community involvement, as well as engaging and inspiring the audience.  Our first production 'Some Girl (s)' by Neil LaBute will do exactly this....with your help!!


The Impact

We believe we can further community understanding and appreciation of the arts by increasing their involvement.  Including the public in programming decisions will not only engage the community, but hopefully create the desire to contribute to the growth and maintenance of Toronto's art scene.


What We Need & What You Get

We are looking to raise $5000 for our first production.  This would cover the cost of renting the venue, marketing (flyers, programs, website,etc.) Set design and lighting.  We are also committed to helping our starving artists earn an income doing what they love.  This will most likely be a small honorarium for the first season, but utlimately would like to develop a repertory company that would allow our actors to finally give up their day jobs!

By contributing, your donation ensures that regardless of whether or not we meet our fundraising goal, the production will go on.  There will also be many perks for helping us meet our goal.  Keep an eye out for what goodies are offered for each donation level. 


Other Ways You Can Help

Pay it forward: please share the link, spread the word that we're more than just 'Some Girl (s)' !!

story:
Short Summary

Who We Are:

4401 Hangashore Productions is a non-for-profit, student run production company out of Memorial University of Newfoundland under the English Department's Theatre and Film Communications Diploma, taught by Danielle Irvine.

4401 is the Producing The Play class, which allows it's students a real life experience in Producing a play, and all the roles that go with it (such as publicity, set design, stage managing, lights, etc) under the directed guidance of renowned Director, Danielle Irvine.

The Play:

This year 4401 is producing The Laramie Project under the production company Hangashore Productions.

The Laramie Project is a brutally honest play written by Moises Kaufman and Tectonic Theater Project about the 1998 murder of Matthew Shepard, a young gay man, in the small town of Laramie, Wyoming. The play itself consist of direct bits of interviews conducted by Moises and the Tetonic Theater Project with the closely knitted residents of Laramie during the year after Matthew's death.

The play will be held at The LSPU Hall, directed by Danielle Irvine, and starring: Steve O'Connell, Selena Asgar, Bruce Benton, David Feehan, Brad Bonell, Margaret Hild, Natalia Hennely, and Sandy Gow.

Why This Play Is Important:

LBGTQ related hate crimes have been plauging society for many years, but October 12th, 1998 the world stood still and all eyes landed on Laramie, Wyoming in the wake of one of the most brutal, and surprising hate crimes in America.

Matthew Shepard, an out gay man, left The Fireside bar with Aaron McKinney and Russell Henderson one night, and was driven out to the farthest reaches of the town of Laramie, and than tied to a fence, and tortured, beaten, and left to die over night. Matthew was found in a coma the next morning, and offically died a few days later on October 12th, never haven woken up.

The play itself focuses on the effects of such a violent tragedy on such a small and tight knit town like Laramie, and it's population. Laramie itself is no different than St. John's, and is no bigger than Gander. All the people know each other someway or another, and it's populous felt safe and trusting before the events. 

This play not only shows the devastating social ramifications on the States and LBGTQ human rights as a whole, but also shows the destruction of the small town mentality and the abolition of a false sense of security a tight knit town can bring, and how one simple act can change a town and it's people, forever.

What We Need And What You Get

For the production of The Laramie Project Hangashore Productions would like to raise $1000. This $1000 would go to:

  • Building sets

  • Printing of posters, build boards, and Tickets

  • Putting off a School Showing

  • Costumes

  • Giving our actors an Honorarium

  • and funding the diploma program for aspiring artist and students in the years to come.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you cannot make a monetary donation you can still help us out by spreading the word, and following us on social medias! 

Tweet us, share us on Facebook, share this IndieGoGo page, and attend our fundraisers, or just use good ol' fashion word of mouth! Anything is a great help and we really appreciate it!

Cheers and we hope to see you at the show,

Hangashore Productions.

story:
Our Story

3rd Shift Dance is a contemporary jazz project directed by Seattle choreographer Xaviera Vandermay. Based on Capitol Hill, 3rd Shift strives to push the physical boundaries of the dancers, to push some buttons, and celebrate our freedom as artists to do what gets us off.

Queens of the Nano-Performance; small in cost, in audience capacity, and time span, yet boasting big flavor and huge talent.  We are presenting two concerts for our spring season; The Battle for the (dance) Belt April 22nd and Whacked: An Evening of Killer Dance May 20th at Velocity Dance Center in Seattle, Washington.


What We Need & What You Get

With three choreographers, 10 dancers and over 9 new dance works to present, we folks are in serious need of help getting our dancers costumed!  100% of the money earned via this campaign will be going directly into offsetting the costs of costumes and make-up.  We are seeking to raise $2500 ($250 per dancer) and know with your help we can realize these pieces fully!


Other Ways You Can Help

Don't have the financial resources to help us?  No fear!  We are always in need of help spreading the word and encourage you to share this campaign as well as information about our events!  Check us out on Facebook, www.facebook.com/3rdShiftDance and follow us on Twitter @3rdShiftDance!  Love and Dance, 3rd Shift Dance Management

story:
Short Summary

As comedians in Chicago, we've witnessed success of our friends on both coasts and a brain drain of our highly talented city.  We think that Chicago deserves the opportunity to stand on its own as a hotbed and incubator of comedic talent.  With this showcase, we hope to represent the level of stellar female and queer talent we have to offer.  With your help, we will produce a monthly showcase at one of the most prominent comedic theatres in Chicago and accompanying video anthology to show all aspects of the life of a comedian. 

If you are a fan of comedy then your contribution will bolster numerous important careers and provide a timeless document of emerging talent in one of the hardest working cities in America.

What We Need & What You Get

We need to pay our comedians.  This generation of comedians has heard stories of their predecessors making a living by performing in Chicago; these days, it’s not that easy.  People in the city are working hard to demand and provide pay for comedic performers, and with your help we can continue that trend.

We need to provide a venue.  The right venue is crucial to the success of a show, and they come at a cost.  

We need to film our anthology.  We have a capable videography and post-production team which deserves to be paid in accordance with their skill level.  These folks will film the comedians on stage and off and help us creating the final product.

PERKS

No matter what, all of our comedians will be paid.  This is a huge step in the right direction and will be an effort to start a precedent.  Your contribution will help greatly on this front.  Further funds will go toward video quality, production support and staff, and decking out our venue.

The Impact

It's going to pay people.  It's going to be a kick ass show that will get people around the world excited about these new talents.  It will be a place for comedians to grow and experiment.  It will be a highly enjoyable experience for audience members both present at the venue and viewing our anthology from anywhere in the world.

In our current era, many important voices are being silenced and it is our goal to amplify as many underrepresented groups as possible both to bolster their careers and provide a platform where they feel represented as performers and audience members see someone like themselves on stage.

Our performers have graced the stages of every reputable comedic theatre in Chicago.  Through programming smaller shows and web series we've gained the skills necessary to see this project to completion.  Our team believes in and is dedicated to this vision and their skills are unmatched.

We are all hard working creatives in an economy that undervalues and over consumes our work.  We have day jobs.  We burn the midnight oil performing at open mics and showcases and traveling the country for festivals.  Our particular performers face sometimes insurmountable odds against bookers and clubs that don't find their voice valuable.  This showcase is not gilding the lily; it is an honest attempt to take back control of our careers and our art and let our voices resonate with a much larger audience without having to wait for permission.

Risks & Challenges

Paying for the venue.  We are booked in advance through the end of the year with a highly reputable theatre in Chicago.  This is where you come in.  With you help, we can secure these performances and focus on advertising and promoting our show in other ways.

Paying our production team.  After our comedians are paid and our venue is solid, funding will go towards paying our production team.

Consistently booking talent.  There is a wealth of talent in the city of Chicago, but the stars don’t always align and people aren’t always available on the nights you need them.  We think our message with the show, our mission to anthologize Chicago comedy, and our determination to pay our performers will be attractive to our potential performers.

Getting audiences.  With an abundance of shows to see in Chicago, it might seem daunting to fill a theatre on any given night.  Again, our mission is unique, and we think audience members will jump at the chance to be a part of something bigger.  Beyond that, we intend to purchase and set aside a select number of tickets for the Chicago Diversity Comedy Community to attend each show free.

Distributing the work.  Again, overabundance of options.  We plan to host the show online, share on social media (facebook, instagram) with our tag #NotYetFamous, and create a sell merchandise.  With the participation of our cast, there is a potential to submit work the show to festivals and expand to a possible touring show.

Other Ways You Can Help

Share our campaign.  Use Indiegogo share tools to get the campaign in front of as many people as possible.

Local street team.  Be our distributors outside of the theatre.  Spread the word to coworkers, family, or friends.

Online distribution.  Share share share.  Help us get views.  Share our content with the tag #NotYetFamous. 

Come to shows.  Our first show is September 1 at the iO Comedy Theatre, 830PM. 

Spread the word on social media.

Send us recommendations for comedians you’d love to see in the next run of the show.

story:
Hello!

Hello and welcome to our very first crowdfunder! For those who don’t know us so well, we are Little Bulb Theatre and we've been making and touring devised and physical theatre since 2008.  We are about to embark on our first U.K tour with our biggest show to date, a gypsy jazz opera, called Orpheus, a Little Bulb and Battersea Arts Centre co-production. We're very excited to be taking this show to a number of incredible cities and venues around the country, and we need your help with the last little bit of funding to make the tour the best it can be. 

With your help, we will buy a piano to take out on the road, as well as better cases to protect and maintain all of the instruments used in the show. Investing in our kit now will make a huge difference to this tour, and to our company. Owning our own piano, and ensuring the longevity of the other 15+ instruments used in Orpheus will help us to share this much loved show with new audiences, both on this tour and in the future. 

Be you a stranger, family, friend or fan we would like to say thank you in advance for taking the time to read this, and a further thank you to those who feel they can contribute to this crowdfunder.  

Every penny is appreciated - so whatever you can spare, even if it is just the time to share the link, we will be eternally grateful.  

With love and gratitude, 

Little Bulb


Who we are

Little Bulb Theatre is an award-winning national touring company based in the South East of England. We are committed to developing devised and physical theatre performances which explore and illuminate minute human details that, in a world so big, are easily swallowed up.  Combining innovative character work, beautiful imagery and exciting homemade music, we aspire to create performances that with humour and sadness will touch, startle and entertain.


About the show

Be transported to 1930s Paris where legendary musician, Django Reinhardt, has been cast as the lead in a new production of Orpheus.

Your host for the evening is the charismatic songstress Yvette Pépin. With her troupe of operatic players she performs the thrilling tale of Orpheus’s ill-fated descent into the underworld to reclaim his lost love, Eurydice.

Set to a live score of hot club jazz, opera and French chanson, Orpheus is a musical re-imagining of the Greek myth. 


“Heartrending" 

★★★★THE GUARDIAN 

“Sweet humour, unexpected gravitas and unpretentious beauty" 

★★★★★THE TIMES 

“Fizzes with musical talent and comic esprit" THE OBSERVER


Following two sold-out runs at Battersea Arts Centre and at the world-renowned Salzburg Festival, we are now gearing up for a UK tour ofOrpheus. This will be our largest tour to date, enabling us to reach new audiences of over 8,000 people across 27 performances in five incredible venues: Birmingham Repertory Theatre, Bristol Old Vic, Liverpool Everyman, Royal Opera House Linbury Studio and Nuffield Theatre Southampton.  Needless to say we're incredibly excited and thrilled to be taking the show out on the road, but there are huge costs involved in making a tour-able version, and this is where we look to you for help.


What We Need

Music has played an integral part in all of our past productions, but Orpheus puts it right at its heart.  For this crowdfunding campaign we are aiming to raise £6,000 to enable us to buy the necessary equipment to make the show a more sustainable outfit, for this tour and subsequent outings. 

Money you donate will enable us to:

a) Buy a new piano that the company would then own and tour with (saving us from the logistical nightmare of hiring pianos at every venue). This piano will become a brilliant asset for the company as we plan future tours.

b) Buy hard cases for instruments - accordion, double bass and harp - which currently don’t have them, ensuring their longevity for this tour and beyond.

c) Fix and maintain all of the instruments in the show (of which there are 15+). Though we love our instruments and are as careful with them as possible, touring and performing in a high octane production means that they incur inevitable scrapes and bumps that can affect the sound and tuning.  Your support will enable us to ensure our instruments are cared for and serviced by experts so that we can make the best sound possible.

d) In additional to these costs we would use any remaining funding towards rebuilding an adaptable version of the set that can be easily transferred to fit any appropriate venue. Our original bespoke set was designed for Battersea Arts Centre’s Grand Hall, and as such needs to be completely re-designed for touring. We aspire to make a structure that is able to adapt to any venue with the capacity and desire to house Orpheus.


The Impact

With a cast of 8 and a production team of 6 on the road,Orpheus is by far our largest-scale production to date. The response to the show both at Battersea Arts Centre and in Salzburg was something neither we or BAC had seen before or anticipated. Audiences returned several times to see the show in 1930’s inspired get-up; we received critical acclaim in the national press and people rose to their feet to dance in the aisles during the interval. This tour will enable us to share this much-loved show in venues we have never performed in before. Your support will mean we can create a truly special experience for every single audience member, using our instruments to transform spaces and transport people to 1930’s Paris and the mythical underworld beyond. 

Orpheus is a Little Bulb Theatre and Battersea Arts Centre co-production, in association with Farnham Maltings. 

Orpheus will play at the Royal Opera House Linbury Studio Theatre (15-19 Sept), Bristol Old Vic (23-26 Sept), Nuffield Southampton (29 Sept-3 Oct), Liverpool Everyman (20-24 Oct) and Birmingham Repertory Theatre (28-31 Oct) on its first-ever UK tour.  

For more information please visit:

www.bac.org.uk

www.littlebulbtheatre.com

Hello!
Hello
and welcome to our very first crowdfunder! For those who don’t know us so well,
we are Little Bulb Theatre and we've been making and touring devised and
physical theatre since 2008.  We are about to embark on our first U.K tour
with our biggest show to date, a gypsy jazz opera, called Orpheus, a Little Bulb and
Battersea Arts Centre co-production. We're very excited to be taking this show
to a number of incredible cities and venues around the country, and we
need your help with the last little bit of funding to make the tour the best it
can be. 
With your
help, we will buy a piano to take out on the road, as well as better cases to
protect and maintain all of the instruments used in the show. Investing in our
kit now will make a huge difference to this tour, and to our company. Owning
our own piano, and ensuring the longevity of the other 15+ instruments used in Orpheus will help us to share this much
loved show with new audiences, both on this tour and in the future. 
Be you a
stranger, family, friend or fan we would like to say thank you in advance for
taking the time to read this, and a further thank you to those who feel they
can contribute to this crowdfunder.  
Every penny is
appreciated - so whatever you can spare, even if it is just the time to share
the link, we will be eternally grateful.  
With love and
gratitude, 
Little Bulb

England. We are committed to developing devised and physical theatre
performances which explore and illuminate minute human details that, in a world
so big, are easily swallowed up.  Combining innovative character work,
beautiful imagery and exciting homemade music, we aspire to create performances
that with humour and sadness will touch, startle and entertain.

story:
Who we are

Parachute Dance is a new UK-based arts company, currently preparing our contemporary dance piece 'Entrails' for the 2016 Edinburgh Fringe.

Róisín O'Brien is the director and choreographer. 'Entrails' is her brain child. She's completing a Diploma in Dance Studies at Trinity Laban Conservatoire of Music and Dance in London.

Laura Jones is a co-producer. She's currently based in Edinburgh and is a book production and promotion freelancer.

Aran Ward Sell is a co-producer. He currently works in Digital Resources for the School of Advanced Study in London.

Yui Ming (Emily) Wong has a BA (Hons) Ballet Education and was awarded the Licentiate of the Royal Academy of Dance. She has a Masters in Dance Performance and has toured internationally with MapDance.

Kayla Tomé is a performer and community dance artist in London with 10 years experience in teaching dance and has trained in contemporary, jazz, hip hop, African and Latin dance.

Jenny Geertsen has a HND in Performing Arts, a BA in Musical Theatre and a MA in Physical Theatre. She has performed at the London Paralympics Ceremonies, IYAF, Queens Jubilee at Royal Festival Hall, Kingston Connections, the Edinburgh Fringe and more.

Emily Neighbour is a dancer in Third Row Dance Company and Scatter Dance Company and has worked for Big Dance 2016 and Dance Umbrella Festival.

You can find out more detail about the team on our website.


The show

'Entrails' is a contemporary dance theatre piece inspired by Joseph Heller's Catch-22, a book that has remained with Róisín long after a first reading. She was inspired by this particular quote:

“Yossarian was cold, too, and shivering uncontrollably. He felt goose pimples clacking all over him as he gazed down despondently at the grim secret Snowden had spilled all over the messy floor. It was too easy to read the message in his entrails. Man was matter, that was Snowden’s secret. Drop him out a window and he’ll fall. Set fire to him and he’ll burn. Bury him and he’ll rot, like other kinds of garbage. The spirit gone, man is garbage. That was Snowden’s secret. Ripeness is all.”

The show will confront our fragility, our messiness and our transience and present a dark and absurd look at our human bodies. Bodies that malfunction yet persist. Bodies that are denigrated and manipulated. Bodies that resist.

'Entrails' will run from August 12 - 27, 12:50pm - 1:40pm at theSpace @ Venue 45.


Where the money goes

£600 will cover a single instalment for our venue hire which is costing £2,000. We have already paid £1,000 by this point through our own savings and the final £1,000 is due at the beginning of July. It's a big ask so we very thankful for every single contribution which helps bring us closer to securing the venue and putting on our dream show!

The perks

Whether you can help us out with a penny or several pounds we want to give everyone at least a small personal thank you. Particular highlights include:

  • Personalised thank yous from us in emails, on the website, on social media and in ye olde handwriting posted right to your door.
  • Help us out and receive merch: pin badges, signed flyers and posters.
  • Original dance and artwork specially commissioned just for you.
  • And, of course, there's free tickets and an invite to our launch celebration in Edinburgh for the extra generous.

Risks & challenges

The main risks and challenges:

  • If we are unable to meet the payment deadline we risk losing the venue.
  • If we lose the venue we also lose the £1,000 already put down and in all likeliness, the show itself will have to be cancelled.
  • We'll be overjoyed if we come out of August having broken even and this will be a challenge in itself. Your pledges bring up a step closer to bringing us out of the red.
We're scraping together every hard-earned spare penny we have to make this happen but with your help we can meet our payment deadline sooner and focus on making 'Entrails' an unmissable and unforgettable show.

Share, share, share!

Facebook, Twitter, Tumblr, Instagram, sharing on any and all of these platforms helps us massively by spreading the word to people who might be interested in our show. Why not bung the hashtag #Entrails on there too? Click on the share buttons on the left side or at the bottom of the page.

Thank you

It's going to be hard to do this without you so thank you so much for backing us or sharing the project.
THANK YOU. :) 
- Parachute Dance


www.parachute-dance.com
Facebook | Twitter
Entrails on the Fringe website

story:
Summary

Listening Raven Productions has been hard-at-work planning our full production of "Last of The Caucasians", written by Erich L. Ruehs!

"Last of The Caucasians" features four intelligent, free-thinking and independently minded Native American lead characters. This play is a fast-paced dialogue-driven, comedic satire featuring hip, young and strong willed Native lead characters in a modern day setting.

This two-act comedy, and satirical drama, demonstrates a sense of humor, and quick wit that would leave Jerry Seinfeld in the dust. The four "Indians" are fiercly diverse; all hailing from different tribal backgrounds as they confront, debate, and even conflict with each other, and, everyone around them; both Native and non-Native. 

The exchanges are open, honest and take place in a comedic and satirical manner, all while the characters are trapped in a New York City Pub in the "East Village" section of Manhattan. The pub is called "Rezzetti's".

Our play passionately leaps into the lexicon of languages. Since this play encompasses the concept of "oneness," and the universality of all people, we include words and brief phrases from 15 different languages, not including English. Six of these languages are Native American. They include: Shawnee, Iroquois, Mohican, Muskogee, Navajo and Mohawk.

We have our staged-reading coming up on May 2nd, 2016, at 7:00 p.m. at The Producer's Club, 358 W 44th St, New York, NY 10036. Please come and see our work before we move into full production!

What We Need!

In order to properly fund our full production, we are kindly, and appreciatively, asking for $10,000 for the following costs:

- Theatre space, space insurance, number of performances

- Payment for cast and crew (lighting, sound, etc)

- Set Design and construction

- Manpower to reach out to organizations and foundation to help deliver our play's important message

No matter the financial situation, our entire team is 100% dedicated to putting on this important show, so all donated funds will be for the above listed costs.

The Impact

Your contribution will change the lives of not only our cast and crew embarking on this passionate mission, but it will get the word out there in New York City and respectively, the rest of the world. It is important to bring awareness to the lack of Native American roles in this industry today, and with this incredible, enjoyable script it will be a remarkable and memorable experience for all.

Past productions with members of our team have consistently and always have been about bringing light to topics around the world; most recently off-Broadway's "Somewhere on The Border", produced and assistant directed by our own Director and A.D. This past production shed light on the lack of knowledge on Africa's Angolan War.

Black Elk once said that, "Humankind has woven the web of life." And continued, "We are but one thread within it. Whatever we do to the web, we do to ourselves."

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Attend our staged-reading May 2nd, 2016, at 7:00 p.m. at The Producer's Club, 358 W 44th St, New York, NY 10036!
  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about "Last of The Caucasians!"
  • Please use the Indiegogo share tools!

THANK YOU FROM THE BOTTOM OF OUR HEARTS!

story:
About The Show

A homeless veteran, chewed up and spit out by war, stumbles into a city park. An encounter with a butterfly-collecting Professor triggers a vivid hallucination of the trivial tragedies of the lives of insects. These “insects” play out parodies of our lives. The vain poet Butterfly, the capitalistic Dung Beetles, the bloodthirsty warmonger Ants--no one is safe in this ruthless one-act comedy.

From the original inventors of the word “robot,” The World We Live In by Josef and Karel Capek is far outside the realm of realism, and pushes its audience to be complicit in the rules of this world, as harsh and unforgiving as they are. The Capek brothers were heavy critics of capitalism, nationalism and the eventual rise of dictatorship. You’ll be confronted by jarring imagery, unforgiving humor, and painful truth. 

What We Need

Our budget is a modest one. We need:

$75 stipends for our producer, costume, lighting and sound designers (x4 = $300)
$100 for costumes
$100 for scenery
$60 for posters/promotion
Total: $560 - Anything we raise more than this will go to buying food for the cast. :)

The PERKS 

$5-10 Gets you a special thank you in the program!
$15 Gets you a reserved seat at the show and your name in the program!
$30 + Gets you a reserved seat, your name in the program, AND up to two tickets to any one Cornish show in the Fall season. For a complete list of the upcoming season, please check out http://www.cornish.edu/calendar/t/performance/ 

The Impact

Why this play now? This play has been in my dreams for four years now. I chose The World We Live In because it’s got a sense of danger to it. I wanted to compress this powerful play into something explosive. With the political world in an uncertain (and in many ways frightening) state, it’s important to take a step back and look at ourselves in the mirror - or to quote Hamlet,“to hold, as 'twere, the mirror up to nature.”  Too often we delude ourselves into thinking the way we live our lives is without consequence. From social media to the infamous “Seattle freeze,” we have become so self-involved in our idea of life that we forget what it means to live. This play reminds me to open my eyes and look for light in the world, and I can't wait to share it with you.

Track Record

In the past six months I have workshopped and directed a concert-style staged reading of a new musical by Leah Erickson Webster You: & Other Things That Shouldn’t Matter But Do. It was a huge success and went on to become a studio recording and radio play--all made possible by small contributions from people like you! I assistant directed  main stage plays in both the Fall and the Spring seasons at Cornish. As I make my directorial debut, all of my experiences with peers, artists and directors I admire have given me the courage to create something truly meaningful. I have the distinct privilege of working with some of Seattle’s most talented up-and-coming actors and designers, and this play has given them a platform to foster a sense of agency and professionalism. When given the opportunity to create something big with me--they said yes. 

Why Support Student Art?

Young artists often have the most challenging time getting their work up and out into the world, and this show provides a perfect platform. 
Your support shows your dedication to educating the artists of the future.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word about this campaign, and come see our show September 8th-10th at Raisbeck Performance Hall!

It was a huge success and went on to become a studio recording and radio play--all made possible by small contributions from people like you! As I make my directorial debut, all of my experiences with peers, artists and directors I admire have given me the courage to create something truly meaningful. I have the distinct privilege of working with some of Seattle’s most talented up-and-coming actors and designers, and this play has given them a platform to foster a sense of agency and professionalism. When given the opportunity to create something big with me--they said yes. 
   Why Support Student Art? Young artists often have the most challenging time getting their work up and out into the world, and this show provides a perfect platform. Your support shows your dedication to educating the artists of the future.
    Other Ways You Can Help Please spread the word about this campaign, and come see our show September 8th-10th at Raisbeck Performance Hall!

story:
Our Story

About seven years ago Noah Davis wrote a little six page two-hander play called Different,  which won a short play contest and was awarded a run at the Beaumont Studios in Vancouver.  Noah and his close friend Mylène Dinh-Robic took the stage to give the play life.  The audience‘s reaction to the play was profound, it seemed to open the door on all sorts of discussion and debate, and many asked the question:  “What happens next with these characters?” 

 

Noah balked at the idea that Different should be a longer play, indignantly stating that the piece was meant to stand alone.  The reality is he was scared of how much work, energy and heart would be required to tell this complete story. 

 

However, as time passed Noah got over himself and sat down to turn Different into a full length play.  Those original pages were expanded, massaged and built into the first of three scenes which follow two characters, Scott and Susan, as their relationship is thrown into turmoil by the tectonic shifting of buried trauma.  The new play, Point No Point, is now ready to take the stage for the first time. 

 

In a beautiful twist of fate Noah & Mylène have found themselves together again, this time in Toronto, eager to dig into the new material.  One of the first people Noah met off the plane was David Tompa, who is a fixture in the independent theatre scene in Toronto.  David’s talent, style and enthusiasm for Point No Point make him the perfect fit for directing this piece. 

 

Under the Chainsaw Theatre Co-op, Mylène, Noah and David have come together with creative lust to build a simple, poignant, compelling, relevant piece of theatre. 

 

Point No Point is a landmass on the West Coast of Vancouver Island.  It is a place of beauty.  It is a place which juxtaposes the serenity of misty rainforest with the violence of the Pacific thrashing dark jagged rock.  It is this place which puts a crack in the dam that contains the story of our play. 

 

ABOUT: DAVID TOMPA

David Tompa has gained great acclaim for his directorial work with Red One Theatre (Diving Normal, Sexual Perversity in Chicago, Tape), helping to earn them a spot in BlogTO’s Top Ten Theatre Production Companies.  David is a versatile and unique actor and has performed with some of Toronto’s best companies (Red One, Praxis, etc.) and developed a solid career in film and television (Flashpoint, Murdoch Mysteries, etc).  David has created several shows with The Second City Touring Company and the award winning web sketch series Making Funny Stuff.

www.davidtompa.com

www.makingfunnystuff.ca

 

ABOUT: MYLENE DINH-ROBIC

Mylène Dinh-Robic is known internationally for her work as Dr. Olivia Fawcett on The Listener and as Rita Mah on  DaVinci’s City Hall.  Mylène was born and grew up in Montreal and began her career on stage with the independent Queen Mary Theatre, namely in their productions of Pygmalion, Lady Windemere’s Fan, and Noises Off. While in Vancouver, she performed at The Beaumont Studio in Different and Pikefly’s Beirut.  Mylène’s TV credits include Smallville, Battlestar Galactica, Stargate Atlantis , The Border and Toute la Vérité.  She was directed by Ross Weber in the Vancouver feature film Mount Pleasant and by Spencer Maybee in the indie short L’oiseau Mort and more recently worked opposite Ashley Judd in Sandra Nettlebeck’s feature film Helen.

www.mylenerobic.com


ABOUT: NOAH DAVIS

As an actor Noah has been seen onstage with Los Angeles’s oldest not for profit theatre company,  The Company of Angels (Children of the Night, Lost & Found in the Underground).  Also in Los Angeles he has performed with the LA Opera (Tosca, The Magic Flute), as Casey in 13/30 with Upper Reaches, as Rahm in Aziza, and Boy in A Hint of Romance at the Republic.  Noah played two versions of the same character in the feature film The Arrow & The String which recently premiered at the Windsor International Film Festival to sold out audiences.  His TV credits include LA Forensics, Breakout, Mayday, and CBC’s A Long Story Short.  As a writer Noah’s play Different won the Brand New Shorts contest through Beaumont Studios in Vancouver.  He is currently work-shopping a four-hander You Said Love.  Noah has also worked as a treatment writer for music videos and commercials, a lyricist and a script doctor. 

www.noahdavis.com

 

The Impact

This play, Point No Point, is a deep look at love.  Love at its messiest.  Love at its hardest.  The play asks more questions than it answers.  It lives in the gray area between love and logic, right and wrong, joy and pain. 

 

The characters, Susan and Scott, are real and accessible giving audiences a moment to reflect on their own lives, relationships and adversities.

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need to cover the costs of production for Point No Point.  Rental of the venue, material for set build, technicians, lighting design, props, promotional material and insurance are some of the more significant costs.

 

Our goal of $2500 is only a fraction of the funding needed to properly mount this show.  We are investing our own money and holding fund-raising events to make up other costs which will likely exceed $8000.  SO, if we can exceed our Indie GoGo goal, that would take the pressure off us tremendously.  Either way this show will go up on stage!  We are in rehearsal and the theatre is booked.  Please help us by taking some of the financial pressure off and allowing us to do everything we can to give this play the production it deserves. 


The more we can raise, the better.  Extra funds will go towards a strong publicity campaign, and setting up future productions of Point No Point (Montreal, Vancouver, Los Angeles, New York?).

 

We have several perks of helping our campaign, including the chance to come see Point No Point on stage, copies of the script and early drafts, and even holidays involving the play!  Check out our Perks section for more details. 


Please ACT NOW!  We have a very limited time-frame to get funded, as our show premiers on July 21st.  

Other Ways You Can Help

Come see the play!  We are doing theatre for you.  If you can’t make it, send a friend. 

Also, Sharing = Caring.  Share the info about our play.  Spread the word.  “Like” us on Facebook, follow us on Twitter.  Repost, retweet, respond. 

www.facebook.com/ChainsawArts

www.twitter.com/ChainsawTheatre

story:
Help me become a working actor!

I am an aspiring actor in the San Francisco Bay Area who needs more training to further my skills and my career. My dream is to study with Shakespeare & Company in Lenox, Massachusetts.

The full tuition is nearly $10,000. Between grants, savings and financial aid, I've been able to accrue almost $6000, but I'm still $4000 shy. And the training starts this Fall!

So, how about it? Can you help me make my dream a reality?

This is my story

I've been acting semi-professionally for more than a decade now, working with amazing artists and getting to play amazing roles. Most of my acting career thus far has been spent learning on the job and supporting myself with other skills but, basically, I've have come to the realization that my career as it stands is simply not sustainable. Living paycheck to paycheck. Missing work to attend auditions that won't even pay minimum wage if I book them. I've gotten to the point where the theatres that pay a living wage see me for auditions fairly often, yet I've never booked one of those gigs.

When I learned that Shakespeare & Comapany offered an Acting Conservatory for a dozen actors to study intensively for three and a half months, I knew that if I could get there it was likely to give my abilities just the push they needed to help me break into the ranks of working professional actors. So I applied, was accepted, and even got a tuition break, but can still only cover a roughly half of what I owe. So I am launching this indiegogo campaign to fundraise the balance of my Conservatory tuition. Which in turn will certainly change my life, but also give me a better shot at acting full-time and supporting myself with my art.

So, what the heck is Shakespeare & Company?

Shakespeare & Company is a thirty-five-year-old theatre company in the Berkshire Hills of western Massachusetts. They strive to create "theatre of unprecedented excellence rooted in the classical ideals of inquiry, balance, and harmony...[performing] as the Elizabethans did — in love with poetry, physical prowess, and the mysteries of the universe" while also producing new plays. "Actors, directors, writers, and teachers from all over the world come to work with the Company's faculty... training their voices and bodies with demanding classes, while delving deeply into their own imaginations, intellects, and emotional lives." While this sounds pretty far out, I have watched the Shakes faculty work and I have to say, they are one hundred percent for real. And although they use exclusively Shakespearean text, their training prepares you to be a better actor on stage or screen, with classic or contemporary texts. For evidence, check out some Shakes & Co. alums that are on my super short list of freakin' awesome, including Richard Dreyfuss, Bill Murray, Oliver Platt, Sigourney Weaver, and Anna Deavere Smith, to name but a few.

Let me break it down

The tuition for the Acting Conservatory is $9800. Between financial aid, grants and my savings I have come up with more than half that total, leaving me $4000 short. Up until very recently I had hoped to bring that number down with work-study, but I was informed only yesterday that there are no work study positions available at this time. This campaign is for $4350: enough to pay the balance of my tuition ($4000) and the related indiegogo fees (4%-9% indiegogo + 3% credit card/paypal). In the inconceivable event that I raise MORE than my goal, my head will explode. After reassembling the pieces, I will use any additional funding to buy the airfare to get there and my groceries while I study, instead of resorting to a credit card. But the tuition is the thing. Reaching my goal here would mean my tuition is taken care of in the nick of time (The program starts September 10th, yikes!), and I can focus on squeezing every scrap of learnin' from them thar Berkshire hills.

So here goes...

My modest proposal is that we make a deal: You hire me to do something for you in 2013 (after I return from the conservatory), but pay me now. Then, for the fall of 2012, I can go to Lenox, Massachusetts and change my acting career and my life. Or think of it this way: I want to trade you the skills I want for the skills I have.

In exchange for me receiving world class training in acting, Linklater voice work, Shakespearean text analysis, rhetoric, Elizabethan dance, clowning, stage combat and a role in King John on the Shakes & Co. mainstage, I can offer sewing, office work, editing, research, drawing, painting, organization, cleaning, horrible jokes, life coaching, cooking, babysitting, photojournalism, make up artistry, and hairstyling. And other things I'll remember later. Think about it. I've almost certainly mentioned something you'd either pay for anyway or wish you had an excuse to. Well, blessedly, my future is a fabulous excuse!

The perks to the right are some concrete examples of work I can do for you, but it's just to get you started. I'm really excited to get out there and get the skills to be a better actor who works more and I am going to find a way somehow. And if we trade my services for the funding that will get me there, then everyone wins.

You can't give $ but you can give <3

Of course, not everyone can throw down benjamins but everyone can give the love! Sharing this post on your facebook page or twitter feed (or just good old-fashioned telling someone about it) will help bring my campaign to more folks attention. Even giving me a call to convey your support would be downright awesome. If you're especially swamped, telepathy is totally cool, too. Yowza, I can feel it now...

That's all folks!

Thanks so much for your time. Really. You are AMAZING, and I am so grateful.

Wish me luck!

 

*Hidden Perk/Bonus for reading the whole campaign!

Amount: $5-$5,000

Name: Choose Your Own Adventure

Description: Hopefully I've given you a good idea of the things I can do well. Drop me a line with a job you'd like me to take on, I'll hit you back with a labor estimate and if you like it, buy it here!

story:
Our Story

Warren Productions was launched in 2006 by husband and wife team Brent D. and author Tiffany L. Warren. This couple filled with passionate dreams to reach Broadway has put together an Off Broadway worthy show in the form of "The Replacement Wife". The show opened on June 29, 2012 in Dallas, TX and stars Shirley Murdock and Tommy Ford from Martin and was received with a standing ovation.

We Need Your Contributions Once you get the ball rolling the show will be able to carry itself.  Your contributions of $50,000 will aid in getting this show into professional theatres around the U.S. and will pay for: our cast, marketing, and an upgraded set.

You Can Also Help By sharing our campaign with your friends and family through email and social media.
