story:
THEATRE FOR CHARITY 

My name is Ed Nash and I'm the artistic Director of Fraser Nash Management.

Fraser Nash Management has set its self a challenge. We want to make a devised piece of theatre (Completely from scratch) to raise money for charity on the 18/7/14 19/7/14 9:30pm. 

We have decided to raise money for a charity very close to my heart which is Cancer Research. 

You're donation will help us book a rehearsal space and the The Etcetera Theatre in Camden for two nights. Any money left over will go to Cancer Research. All profits from the project will also go to Cancer Research! 

After last years brilliant 5 star performance of Tin Can Riots we hope once again to fill the theatre and also make a difference! 

Please, Please Donate anything you can and hopefully we'll see you there! 

Ed Nash

Artistic Director 

Fraser Nash Management

story:
Hi everybody!

Juanita and Andrew here. We are renovating and re-opening the old movie theater in Alvin on E. House Street. We all believe every small town needs it's own movie theater, and Alvin is no different. We also really love what is going on in the downtown district and on Gordon Street and want to be a part of it.

You may not know this, but for the first 100 years of cinemas, movies were projected on mechanical film projectors. Starting in the last 10 years, the movie studios have been pushing cinemas to move to digital projection as they save millions of dollars in distribution costs by not having to create the very expensive film prints anymore. Digital movie prints come on cheap hard drives and are 15-25 times cheaper per print over film projection. The movie studios are going to start phasing out film prints later this year and should be completely out of the film based distribution by the summer of 2014

This is why we need your help. We can't get the money the traditional route, so we are going to try crowd sourcing the funding by selling discounted gift cards, t-shirts, posters, and more.

The stuff we need

As we said, we need to retrofit the projection booth with all new equipment.

Here is what we will be purchasing and the associated costs.

 

Series 2 Projector DLP projector (Barco, NEC, Christie)    $40,000

Digital Cinema Server System                                   $10,000

Digital cinema audio processor                                    $2,200

Accessories for projector system (cables, mounts, etc)      $8,000

 

The more cash we raise, the more screens we can convert upfront, which means more movies, and we will get them sooner as digital print availability will continue to grow and film availability sink. Our other option is to source used equipment. This is a more difficult (and time consuming task), but we can save as much as 50% of these costs by going the used route. Our first choice is to get good used equipment as we can convert 2 screens for the price of 1 new system.

We set the funding goal at $15,000, but could use significantly more!

Why we think this is important

We really do think it is important for every town to have its own movie theater. The movies have always been a place for everybody, from the youngest to old, richest to poorest, native born or immigrant. Everybody goes to the movies! The problem for Alvin residents is that they have to drive 12-15 miles to the closest theater, which limits both your likelihood of going as well as raises your total cost of a night out (gas prices being what they are, and all!). We love that the House Street theater is smack dab in the middle of Alvin, no more than 10 minutes from any resident to get there.

If we don't move fast, the space will continue to deteriorate and become increasingly expensive to renovate. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We know some folks can't contribute directly, but we can still use your help to spread the word about saving the Alvin theater! Link people to this page in e-mail, on Facebook, Twitter, etc. You have no idea how valuable this can be for us!

Thanks for checking us out!
story_txt:
Hi everybody!
Juanita and Andrew here. We are renovating and re-opening the old movie theater in Alvin on E. House Street. We all believe every small town needs it's own movie theater, and Alvin is no different. We also really love what is going on in the downtown district and on Gordon Street and want to be a part of it.
You may not know this, but for the first 100 years of cinemas, movies were projected on mechanical film projectors. Starting in the last 10 years, the movie studios have been pushing cinemas to move to digital projection as they save millions of dollars in distribution costs by not having to create the very expensive film prints anymore. Digital movie prints come on cheap hard drives and are 15-25 times cheaper per print over film projection. The movie studios are going to start phasing out film prints later this year and should be completely out of the film based distribution by the summer of 2014
This is why we need your help. We can't get the money the traditional route, so we are going to try crowd sourcing the funding by selling discounted gift cards, t-shirts, posters, and more.


The stuff we need
As we said, we need to retrofit the projection booth with all new equipment.
Here is what we will be purchasing and the associated costs.
 
Series 2 Projector DLP projector (Barco, NEC, Christie)    $40,000
Digital Cinema Server System                                   $10,000
Digital cinema audio processor                                    $2,200
Accessories for projector system (cables, mounts, etc)      $8,000
 
The more cash we raise, the more screens we can convert upfront, which means more movies, and we will get them sooner as digital print availability will continue to grow and film availability sink. Our other option is to source used equipment. This is a more difficult (and time consuming task), but we can save as much as 50% of these costs by going the used route. Our first choice is to get good used equipment as we can convert 2 screens for the price of 1 new system.
We set the funding goal at $15,000, but could use significantly more!


Why we think this is important
We really do think it is important for every town to have its own movie theater. The movies have always been a place for everybody, from the youngest to old, richest to poorest, native born or immigrant. Everybody goes to the movies! The problem for Alvin residents is that they have to drive 12-15 miles to the closest theater, which limits both your likelihood of going as well as raises your total cost of a night out (gas prices being what they are, and all!). We love that the House Street theater is smack dab in the middle of Alvin, no more than 10 minutes from any resident to get there.
If we don't move fast, the space will continue to deteriorate and become increasingly expensive to renovate. 


Other Ways You Can Help
We know some folks can't contribute directly, but we can still use your help to spread the word about saving the Alvin theater! Link people to this page in e-mail, on Facebook, Twitter, etc. You have no idea how valuable this can be for us!

Thanks for checking us out!

story:
Our Story

Founded in 2004, Baker & Tarpaga Dance Project is comprised of two artistic directors, a husband and wife team, Esther Baker-Tarpaga and Olivier Tarpaga. BT Dance Project previously was based in Los Angeles, CA, but relocated to Ohio as Esther Baker-Tarpaga, the company's co-artistic director, accepted a position as an Assistant Professor at the Ohio State University Department of Dance. The number of performers varies from project to project ranging from three to eight including live musicians.


We are seeking funding for two upcoming projects: "Beautiful Struggle" directed by Esther Baker-Tarpaga and premiering at The King Arts Complex April 13-15th 2012 in Columbus, Ohio and "DeClassified" directed by Olivier Tarpaga and premiering at Centre Development Choreographique Dialogue De Corps Festival 2012 in Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso.

 

As cultural ambassador for the Department of State, they have presented their work as Cultural Envoys in Morocco (2011), Senegal (2011), Guinea (2007) Burkina Faso (2006), South Africa (2006) and Botswana (2006).  In the USA they have performed at REDCAT Los Angeles, Cornell Ithica, Highways Santa Monica, The Ailey Theatre NYC, and the Ford Amphitheatre Los Angeles. They both toured/performed with David Rousseve/REALITYâ€™s project â€œSaudade.â€  Their company has received numerous grants including the Coca Critical Difference Grant (2011), Battelle Endowment for Technology and Human Affairs Award (2010); the Lester Horton Award â€“ Special Jury Award (2009); Durfee Arc Grant (2006, 2007, 2008);  The Flourish Foundation (2008).


The Impact

Baker & Tarpaga Dance Project tackles challenging themes that deal with personal and global memories of violence, tenderness, and discrimination. This live music and physical dance theater needs to be heard and experienced in the Midwest and in Columbus, Ohio. There's no other company like BTDP in the area.

What We Need & What You Get

We need $5000 to pay dancers, musicians, and tech personnel including lighting, set, and design collaborators for both projects. Plus, you'll get an opportunity to get to know our family when you donate!


Other Ways You Can Help

You can support our mission by telling other people about us and what we're doing. Use the links above to share on Facebook and Twitter! Send an email to friends and family. We want to get the word out, but we can't do it without your help!

story:
Mrs Gucci The Musical - Milan 2014

The aim of this campaign is to fund a concert performance of Mrs Gucci The Musical in Milan in order to attract investors and producers for a fully fledged West End run. After a sell out concert performance by Doris Productions of The Musical at the Arts Theatre in London in October 2013 and after an extraordinary amount of international media coverage Doris Productions felt compelled to take this project further.

Entirely based on court transcripts and verbatim reports, Mrs Gucci is the amazing true story of Patrizia Reggiani Martinelli, daughter of a truck driver, who marries Maurizio Gucci, the shy son of the famously bullying Milan Fashion clan. He rejects his father to marry her and is excluded from the company. For ten years they are happy and live a fairy tale life, becoming an iconic couple in Italy, akin to Elisabeth Taylor and Richard Burton, or Aristotle Onassis and Jacqui Kennedy.

Then, thanks to the death of his father and the machinations of his cousin Paolo Gucci, Maurizio is dragged back into the Gucci company and its lethal boardroom politics. Meanwhile, superstitious and fearful, Patrizia comes under the influence of a self-styled Neopolitan ‘neuromancer’ and ‘psychic advisor’,Pina Auriemma. Soon the marriage flounders, and after ten years separation, Patrizia and Maurizio are divorced. But Patrizia couldn’t let go of her anger or her love, and – recovering from an operation for a severe brain tumour –she asks for Maurizio to be killed…

We aim to stage The Milan Premiere Concert Performance of Mrs Gucci at the Filodrammatici Theatre, on Monday 24th February 2014 the last day of Milan Fashion Week.

The cast:

Julie Atherton - Patrizia Reggiani

Graham MacDuff - Paolo Gucci

Sophie-Lousie Dann - Pina Auriemma

Maurzio Gucci  - TBA

In this age of jukebox musicals or big Hollywood titles it is nearly impossible for new and original productions to get the support and funding required to have a run in the West End or the provinces.

The creative team and cast feel passionately about getting the musical in front of a larger audience of investors, sponsors, patrons and producers all we need now is your help.


What we are raising the funds for

We need £20,000 to put on the concert performance of Mrs Gucci The Musical in Milan.

Your money will be used to pay for the Theatre, flights, hotels, projections, translators, actors, staff, transport, equipment hire, a grand piano, technical staff, crew, marketing, rehearsals and everything else needed to put on a production in another country! All in order to attract investors and producers for a fully fledged West End run later in 2014.

As a thank you for your support we have some amazing unique perks including a digital download or CD of the London concert performance, a hard copy of the current script and if we raise more than our target we aim to stream the concert live from Milan to a browser near you.

In the event that we do not reach our goal we will use the funds raised to do a workshop/showcase in London for angels, investors and producers.

The Impact

In this age of jukebox musicals or big Hollywood titles it is nearly impossible for new and original productions to get the funding required to have a run in the West End or the provinces. 

This is your chance to genuinely bring about much needed development in the New British Musical Theatre scene, by helping this production reach out to a bigger audience your contribution no matter how small could make a really BIG difference.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute and even if you have made a contribution then please help us by spreading the word and making some noise about our campaign by sharing our Indiegogo page using the Indiegogo share tools. If you have been convinced that this project is worth your money, please help us find more supporters.

If you would like to donate more than £5000 to the project or would like to be an angel investor please contact the production team directly by emailing alice@dorisproductions.co.uk.

story:
Short Summary

The performers and production team ofThe Great American Trailer Park Musical represent many degrees within The University of Michigan's School of Music, Theatre, and Dance. Our production is an independent project within the University and completely student-run.

The Great American Trailer Park Musical is a country-rock and blues musical, about agoraphobia, adultery, 80s nostalgia, spray cheese, road kill, hysterical pregnancy, a broken electric chair, kleptomania, strippers, flan and disco. The musical comedy centers on a regular guy and his agoraphobic wife, whose marriage is threatened by a hot young stripper who just shows up one day in Armadillo Acres. The trailer park also plays home to a trio of women, each dysfunctional in her own right.   

Members of our production include: 

Cast:

Jordan Andre – Norbert

Jordyn Norky – Jeannie

Marina Kondo – Pippi

Tyler Leahy – Duke

Sara Frost – Betty

Emma Boyden – Pickles

Riley McFarland – Lin

Production Team:

Matt Kunkel - Director 

Andrew Callahan – Musical Director 

Aidan Ziegler-Hansen - Choreographer

Leia Squillace – Associate Director 

Alison Hacker- Producer

Eleanor Howell Shryock- Scenic Designer

Abbey Kojima- Lighing Designer

Michayla Van Treeck- Costume Designer

Jon Pal- Associate Producer

What We Need & What You Get

We are seeking a minimum of $500 to pay for different elements of our show such as:

  • Production Rights 
  • Costumes
  • Scenic / Props 
  • Wigs 
  • Lighting 
  • Musicians
  • Publicity Materials
  • and IndieGoGo fundraiser fees
To thank you for helping out our production you will receive different benefits such as primary seating for one of our performances and credit in the program (See "Perks" column for more information).

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot personally donate to our show you can help out by sharing the link to this fundraiser and video on social media.

We hope to see you December 11-13 in Studio 1 of the Walgreen Drama Center for our production of The Great American Trailer Park Musical!

story:
Short Summary

The In the House Festival believes that arts and culture are essential to a vibrant and community-oriented society. Music, dance, theatre, spoken word, circus, puppetry are all art forms that make the world go round. Trouble is,  most of the time it's not readily accessible. The In the House Festival changes all that by bringing all these things and more right to your doorstep - literally!

Over the 3 days of the festival (June 1-3, 2012), 13 houses open their doors to live performances of all genres. People get to explore the vast amount of talent that exists in Vancouver - discovering new bands, taking in breathtaking dance, gasping at dare-devil acrobatics. Whatever you're into, it's there!

The In the House Festival is going into its 9th year! It has become a cultural beacon for many - both audience members and performers alike. 

Your contribution to the festival not only allows it to continue being a reality but also supports the over 80 acts that perform at the festival. You become a part of the cultural landscape of Vancouver in a very real and concrete way.

 

What We Need & What You Get

We are striving really hard to be able to pay fair rates for the artists and the production team. With the major funding cuts the province and the country have perpertrated, this is getting harder and harder to do and we increasingly need the public's support. Last year, we lost 11,000$ in funding. This year is not looking any better. As you can imagine, that's a huge loss to a grass-roots, community festival.

What do you get for donating to the In the House Festival? Well other than a warm, fuzzy feeling of yumminess for having bettered the world one note and one dance step at a time, we've got tax receipts, CDs, t-shirts, promotion opportunities in our program and website and the big kahoona of a grand prize: Your very own house concert for you and your friends!

 

The Impact

Don't take it from us. Here's what people have said about the festival.

From the performers:

"This was my 7th year performing at this wonderful event. I have had a notable career in music, being signed to a record deal for 6 years, touring endlessly and playing for thousands of people. This quaint festival is still and always will be one of the highlights of my musical career. In The House is an East Vancouver gem. It’s one of the events in Vancouver that are so unique and hip that it reminds me of why I love living here. It’s wholesome and expresses our vast diversity in the most harmonious way... The fact that people open up their homes to strangers for these performances only shows the trust, love and connection people have in the East Van community."        -Yvette Narlock, musician

"I've had the opportunity to participate with 'In the House Festival' over the past several years in 3 capacities: performer, host & audience. In each case I've been thoroughly delighted and impressed by the festival, its organisation and scope." - Simon Kendall, musician

"Each year, I attend the Festival as I regard it as one of the significant performing venues in Vancouver because of its excellence in artistic performances, its ability to create a sense of well being and, most of all, for its achievement as a community builder." - Mary Gavan, storyteller

From the media:

"It's a fresh approach to the festival model, and one that seems particularly vital given the shortage of smaller live music venues in Vancouver." - Jennifer Moss, Vancouver Sun

"Creative triumph: Initiative of the In the House model opens doors to the future." Stuart Derdeyn, The Province

"In The House Festival is the kind of festival that could and should happen in many more communities." - Life is a Festival

"Vancouver's underground arts economy is booming. Tired of stuffy concert halls and exorbitant ticket prices, cultural entrepreneurs are hosting high-calibre performances in their living rooms" -Adriana Barton, BC Business

"One of the most satisfying aspects of In The House Festival is to see the seperation between artist, host, and audience break down in the informal settings." -Tony Montague, Georgia Straight

"While you'd be wrong to think that house shows faded away around the same time as cassette tapes, the idea of invading a stranger's home for a show might seem too cozy. It is this very coziness that makes Vancouver's In The House Festival unique." - Carly Lewis, Exclaim!

From audience members:

"I have been very impressed with the range of programming offered in a format that is truly inviting and engaging to the general public.  The mix of genres and disciplines provides audiences with exposure to art forms that they may not normally experience, and in an environment (House) that allows for a breaking down of barriers between audiences and artists and host venues/producers.  Most arts presentations today, whether they be not-for-profit or commercial, tend to separate audiences from the artistic world (including the producer), creating false barriers.  The In the House Festival succeeds in breaking down these barriers, and always providing a positive experience for both artists, audiences, and host Houses." -Robert Benaroya

From hosts:

"For two years now I’ve opened my home to the circus.  The Circus!  In my house! My kids and I watch the yard be transformed from its everyday place of play and hockey and gardening and dinners at the picnic table into a sparkling magical stage." -Marnie Goldenberg

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to help out financially, here are some other ways you can help:

1) Spread the word about this campaign. Post the video and the link on any and all social media you are a part of (Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn, etc). Include a personal note of encouragement to incite your friends and colleagues to help out.

To make it easy for you, Indiegogo has a bunch of share tools. Click away, use them!

2) Volunteer for the festival. We need tons of help leading up to it and even more on the days of. Send us an email to info@Inthehousefestival.com if you're interested.

3) Donations in-kind are also greatly appreciated. Useful and necessary things include the loan of sound equipment, food for the green room, printing, photocopying, blank t-shirts, thank you gifts for the hosts, office supplies (paper, ink, pens), festival supplies (name badges, tape, pop-up canopies, staging, lighting.

To make it easy for you, Indiegogo has a bunch of share tools. Click away, use them!

story:
THE PROJECT -

I Love You But We Only Have Fourteen Minutes To Save The Earth is a quintet of fourteen minute live and video performances by some of the UK’s foremost queer and cabaret artists to be developed and directed by Nathan Evans at the Oval House Theatre, London in March 2011. 

Contributing artists are (live) David Hoyle, Fancy Chance, Timberlina and (on film) Kate Pelling and Bette Bourne. Each will have fourteen minutes to tell us how they might save the planet. Their solution may be environmental, political or spiritual. They may not want to save the earth at all. But whatever they choose to do, we can’t do it without you...

NB: This is a conceptual not a campaigning work, so we aren't raising funds or awareness for any particular cause.

THE TEAM - 

Nathan Evans is a writer, director and performer living in London and working in cabaret, theatre and film. His work has been funded by the Arts Council and toured by the British Council, broadcast on Channel 4 and archived by the British Film Institute, been awarded a few statuettes, described as ‘pure genius’ by Time Out and presented around the planet. www.nathanevans.co.uk

David Hoyle is a performance artiste living in Manchester, with a career spanning decades and continents. As The Divine David he had an eponymous Channel 4 series, he also appeared The Velvet Goldmine and, recently directed his debut feature film. www.davidhoyle.info

Fancy Chance is a burlesque clown and comedienne who made her way to UK via Korea and the USA to be crowned the Alternative Miss World and London’s Top Tranny. http://fancychance.wordpress.com/

Timberlina is a bearded lady with a penchant for home-spun philosophy who runs a National Trust kitchen garden in Rye. She’s appeared at many prestigious UK venues and was recently introduced to the nation in The Weakest Link’s drag special. www.timberlina.co.uk

Kate Pelling is an experimental video artiste currently doing her Phd at Chelsea School of Art. She’s very tall and beautiful and lives outrageously in London with a seraglio of handsome, young men. www.katepelling.com

Bette Bourne is an actor and activist, founder of the Obie award-winning drag-troupe Bloolips and original member of the Gay Liberation Front. He lives in London, where he’s appeared at theatres including the National and the Globe (as he has in nations and theatre across the globe). http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bette_Bourne

THE FUTURE -

After the initial performance on March 20th there will be further development and fundraising: there is a three week run at the Oval House pencilled for early 2012, following which the project will tour the UK and internationally. Let us know if you'd like us to bring the show to you.

WHAT WE NEED NOW -

We need to raise $2,750 to cover our fees and expenses for the development of this project. We have until Valentine's Day, February 14th 2011 to do this. We hope that you can help us. 

The total budget for the project is around $10,000: $6,000 to be spent on artist’s fees, $1,500 on production expenses, $1,500 on marketing and $1,000 on administrative costs. All fees are based on the Independent Theatre Council's recommended weekly rates.

There's an Arts Council England application currently pending which would fund about 75% of the development process. We'll know whether we've been awarded this by mid-january and will keep you updated. 

Assuming, for now, that we are successful in obtaining the grant we need to raise $2,750 (£1,750) to supplement it. Which basically equates to the development costs of two of the five projects. So, if we raise $1,375, for instance, we could develop only four of the projects. 

WHAT YOU GET -

Every contributor will receive a thank you credit in the program for the March performance.

Most contributors will also be able to make a conceptual contribution (should they wish) and tell us how they'd like to save the earth. These suggestions will feed into the development process.

Higher contributors will receive tokens of our appreciation. Please see 'perks' for more information.

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP -

If you like the idea of this project please tells other people about it and send them the link.

Lets's face it, no-one else is going to save us. We've got to save ourselves. x

story:
8/1/2011 Update ***

Thank you everyone for your incredible generosity! I reached my goal within 5 days!
 
The campaign will remain open for the rest of the run so contributions are still welcome. Any additional funds will go towards accommodation while in transit (I need to overnight in Oslo on my way to Longyearbyen and back), equipment (an audio recorder for interviews, a tripod, Arctic-worthy boots, etc.), and fees associated with this campaign.

 

The Big Picture

The inescapable reality of our changing climate will have a significant impact on how we organize ourselves in societies, what resources we exploit and how we respect and honor each other in a world where increased interconnectedness has collapsed the traditional six degrees of separation into one. Nowhere is this more apparent than in the Arctic where warming temperatures are displacing entire ecosystems and changing local populations' way of life. However, although there is a wealth of scientific data to explain these disruptions, we still lack the narratives that can help us organize these facts into stories of personal significance and turn a chaotic moment in human history into an opportunity for growth.

The Arctic Cycle -- a six-play cycle which explores the six regions of the High Arctic: United States, Canada, Greenland, Iceland, Norway, and Russia -- is my way of addressing this situation. The Cycle will look at the different facets of the Arctic and investigates how theatre can address the many challenges faced by communities on the frontline of climate change. Each play will focus on issues of significance to that particular region as well as examine how those connect to the rest of the world. 

 

The Project

The first play of The Arctic Cycle, SILA, was commissioned by Mo`olelo Performing Arts Company in San Diego and focuses on Canada. It was workshopped at Mo`olelo and at Playwrights' Workshop Montréal, was presented as a public reading at the York University Conference Staging Sustainability: Arts, Community, Culture, Environment in Toronto, was a finalist for the New York Coalition of Professional Women in the Arts & Media Collaboration Award and is scheduled for a more extensive workshop at the University of Connecticut in the spring of 2012.
 
The second play of the the Cycle, FORWARD, will focus on the Svalbard Archipelago (located midway between Norway and the North Pole) and investigate how Arctic sea ice has impacted human imagination throughout history. Taking its title from Norwegian explorer Fridtjof Nansen's ship Fram, which translates as Forward in English, the play will juxtapose three see voyages taking place at three different times in history: Nansen's 1895 North Pole expedition, a present-day luxury cruise retracing Nansen's steps and a cargo ship journey set in the future.
 
Now the exciting part: Research for the writing of FORWARD will take place during an upcoming 17-day sailing expedition organized by The Arctic Circle (www.thearcticcircle.org). Taking place from September 29 to October 16, 2011, the program invites artists, scientists, educators and architects to collectively explore a region of the Arctic and respond to this experience in their work. As I develop the story, the expedition will give me the opportunity to deepen my knowledge of the region, immerse myself in a maritime Arctic environment, and have access to artists who have similar interests and might become collaborators. It will also provide an intensely focused period of time to concentrate on this new play and learn about the people and geography of the Norwegian Arctic.

 

What I Need & What You Get

The cost for participation in The Arctic Circle program is $5,800 with an equal amount subsidized by The Farm, Inc., the not-for-profit organization that administers the expedition program, plus airfare. I was awarded a $5000 Jerome Foundation Travel & Study Grant which pretty much covers my expedition costs. I am now looking to raise $1,500 to pay for roundtrip airfare between New York and Longyearbyen, Svalbard, our port of departure. 

Your donation is tax-deductible. And depending on the level at which you give, you will receive various tokens of appreciation in return. (My own special way of saying thank you!) I also hope you'll get pleasure from knowing you are participating in a special project and supporting a worthy cause.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

"Like" this page. Link to this campaign on Facebook or Twitter. Invite your friends to visit my website (www.cbilodeau.com) and join my mailing list. And contribute anything you can. If 150 people donate $10, I will meet my goal in no time!

story:
8 Acts, 5 Venues, 37 Performances....Now We Need YOU!

What Is The BEAT Festival?

We are creating an event unlike any other in Brooklyn, which will celebrate our home grown emerging artists and the communities that support them.  I am here to ask for your help to make this a reality.

The BEAT Festival will feature 8 uniquely talented and diverse artists/groups from the media of theater, dance and voice performing in 5 different venues across Brooklyn from September 12-23, 2012, our inaugural season.  Each artist either lives or works in Brooklyn.  There is no festival like this in the borough currently, making now an extraordinary opportunity to make this happen.

Brooklyn is the 4th largest city in the United States and holds some of the most renowned performing arts institutions in the world (BAM, St. Ann's Warehouse and The Billie Holiday Theatre, to name a few).  The borough is currently undergoing a massive cultural renaissance as it becomes the destination for contemporary emerging performing artists.  Manhattan has become about product, commerce and entertainment while Brooklyn now stands for development, process and art.  The BEAT Festival honors the cultural diversity of the borough and reveals the stunning array of talent living and working here. 

We have a great idea, now we need a great place to make it happen! 

The Irondale Center

The $10,000 we are raising with this campaign goes directly to funding our flagship venue for the BEAT Festival, the stunning Irondale Center in Fort Greene.  Located squarely within the BAM Cultural District, The Irondale is a 300+ capacity, full light/sound operable theater space.  Imagine this space filled nightly with extraordinary performance art created by a BROOKLYN artist.  Your gift will enable us to present talented Brooklyn artists, while also having a wide variety of other special events such as: workshops for kids, roundtable discussions on important art & community topics, open rehearsals, Q&A with the artists and other activities designed to open the festival and the artwork to the community.  ALL artists presented at the 2012 festival will perform at The Irondale.

Community

Our goal is large, yes, but so is our vision.  We absolutely need your help to see this project through.  As I say in the video, festivals exist in dynamic and vibrant communities.  Brooklyn is certainly one of the most culturally thriving cities in the world, and it's time we had a festival celebrating US.  Your contribution will go directly to providing a meaningful platform for Brooklyn-based emerging artists while also creating an event that will build community all across Brooklyn.  Please help us lock-in The Irondale Center by making a donation to BEAT today!

How To Give

See the green-shaded box to the right?  Go to the top of that and choose which level you want from the drop down menu.  Then, click the "Contribute Now" button.  You will then be taken to a fully secure page where you can make your contribution.  (NOTE: you can give any amount you wish, the totals listed are simply the minimum levels to receive each perk)

Then...Share This (VERY Important!)

FINALLY - once you give, PLEASE share this on Facebook (look under the video above, that is where you can share this with your friends).  The viral effect of social media is not only critical to our fundraising, but also to our audience building.  By simply sharing this on Facebook, you will do wonders for our visibility by enabling your friends to learn about the BEAT Festival.

It is hard asking for money, particularly in these times.  But, I hope you can see here that we have now a special opportunity to create an event that will benefit many people across the great borough of Brooklyn.  Your gift will go directly to making this happen.  Will you help us please? 

Thank you!





Stephen Shelley
Artistic Director
The BEAT Festival
stephen@beatbrooklyn.com

Follow Us:
Facebook
Twitter

story:
Dixon Place presents
                                          in association with Ampersand Productions

THE SLEEP OF REASON PRODUCES MONSTERS

adapted by emily kaplan
directed by emily kaplan & alex shaw
choreography by alex shaw
lighting design by drew vanderberg
sound design by benjamin weiner
costume design by lydia fine
the stage is managed by heather englander

featuring lauren glover, emily kaplan, mark junek, stephanie lane, siobhan burke, and rowan magee

thursday, february 23
9:30pm

TICKETS AVAILABLE NOW!
https://web.ovationtix.com/trs/pe/9603925
$12 advance / $15 at the door

Welcome to the estate of Bly, where thereâ€™s no shortage of secrets and no escape from desires. This new dance-theatre adaptation of Henry Jamesâ€™ Turn of the Screw asks: which do you like more, watching or being watched? Will you give in to what you want most, or deny it until it ruins you?

And, most importantly, have you been bad? 

We hope so.

________________________________________________

Dixon Place, a non-profit organization, was founded in 1986 to provide a space for literary and performing artists to create and develop new works in front of a live audience. Our mission to support and nurture the development of new work and work in progress  from diverse artists and to build new audiences for the work.


THE SLEEP OF REASON PRODUCES MONSTERS is presented by Dixon Place as part of their Works In Progress series.


_______________________________________________

HOW YOU CAN HELP

The Sleep of Reason team is interested in building a community of supporters to fund this exciting dance-theater project. We have an incredible opportunity to work with Dixon Place, one of the premier experimental theater venues in New York City. As the project progresses, we'd love to remain engaged with this community, offering opportunities to donors to stay up-to-date with each iteration of the project.


For the February 23 presentation, rehearsal space is crucial to the development of the piece. We're also using this opportunity to build an audience through Dixon Place, so our marketing campaign is a major priority.


With your help, we can create an original piece of theater that challenges audiences and engages a new community of artistic supporters.


Financial support of ANY denomination is GREATLY appreciated :)


Thank you in advance for your time!

story:
THE STORY

Seventeenth is a new, student-written work produced by students at Emerson College (Boston, MA), and set to premiere at the Boston Center for the Arts on March 26th, 2015.  The story, written by junior Writing for Film and Television major Mechi Lakatos, delves headfirst into the taboo subject of sexual abuse with a rawness, honesty, and strength that is rare for a first work.  The story revolves around a seventeen-year-old girl named K who has just returned home after being sent away to protect her family's image after word gets out of her father's sexual abuse.  K is forced to dive back into the high pressures of her senior year, all the while still grappling and struggling to come to terms with the aftermath of the intense trauma that has left her altogether voiceless.

The show follows a gang of wayward teenagers as they navigate relationships, abuse, and recovery within the decadence and dysthymia of Southern California.  Around K, her best friend, Lily, is hyperanxiously awaiting her decision from Brown.  Her quasi-ex-boyfriend, Nat, is (not) dealing with a family crisis.  And K's younger sister Joey, is just beginning to enter into all of it, and entering into the horrors of K's past.  

Seventeenth is a snapshot of those teetering moments on the threshold of adulthood, and an exploration of how loud your own voice can really be, if you learn to really speak up.

The cast and production team of Seventeenth are made up entirely of students.  We are interested in using this piece as a platform to begin conversations on campus and break down the taboos that make victims of abuse afraid to speak out.

Your financial contribution will help fund

The main reason we need financial support is to pay for our space rental - a $1000 investment.  We have already secured space and made a security deposit and down payment on a theatre at the Boston Center for the Arts, with show dates planned for March 26-28th.  We have had to search for outside space although we are part of a college because we have been met with so many closed doors when seeking space and support at Emerson as an independent production.  We hope to see changes to this climate, but in the meantime, we are really needing this support so this show can see the stage and this important conversation about sexual assault and abuse can persist and be looked at in new and important ways within the Emerson community and the Boston community as a whole.

Contributions will also help fund our intricate multimedia set, costumes, props, and set pieces.  They will allow us to design and print programs, posters, and other advertising, which is important to us because we want to get the word out to as many people as possible.  Although this is a small show, it has a big message, and we want it to reach as many people as it can.

We are aiming to do all we want to do on the smallest budget possible, and pulling a lot of strings in order to make it all happen, but even a small amount of funding will really help to create the world of Seventeenth more colorfully and more wholly, and certainly impact the impression that the show will therefore leave on its audience after the curtain falls.

Any funds raised beyond our goal will be donated to the Boston Area Rape Crisis Center to benefit victims of sexual assault in the Boston area.

Why this show?

This show is especially important because the voices that get to speak through the words of this show and the messages that are opened up for dialogue and discourse are ones that are often silenced. Since collegiate matriculation, we have met so many survivors of abuse and have seen so many of their voices silenced.  This play is a fight back against all of that, and your support is the final stepping stone to really get those voices heard.

Thank you to all who have helped to make this show a reality!

Reserve your tickets in advance:

Tickets for Seventeenth
story_txt:
THE STORY
Seventeenth is a new, student-written work produced by students at Emerson College (Boston, MA), and set to premiere at the Boston Center for the Arts on March 26th, 2015.  The story, written by junior Writing for Film and Television major Mechi Lakatos, delves headfirst into the taboo subject of sexual abuse with a rawness, honesty, and strength that is rare for a first work.  The story revolves around a seventeen-year-old girl named K who has just returned home after being sent away to protect her family's image after word gets out of her father's sexual abuse.  K is forced to dive back into the high pressures of her senior year, all the while still grappling and struggling to come to terms with the aftermath of the intense trauma that has left her altogether voiceless.The show follows a gang of wayward teenagers as they navigate relationships, abuse, and recovery within the decadence and dysthymia of Southern California.  Around K, her best friend, Lily, is hyperanxiously awaiting her decision from Brown.  Her quasi-ex-boyfriend, Nat, is (not) dealing with a family crisis.  And K's younger sister Joey, is just beginning to enter into all of it, and entering into the horrors of K's past.  Seventeenth is a snapshot of those teetering moments on the threshold of adulthood, and an exploration of how loud your own voice can really be, if you learn to really speak up.The cast and production team of Seventeenth are made up entirely of students.  We are interested in using this piece as a platform to begin conversations on campus and break down the taboos that make victims of abuse afraid to speak out.Your financial contribution will help fundThe main reason we need financial support is to pay for our space rental - a $1000 investment.  We have already secured space and made a security deposit and down payment on a theatre at the Boston Center for the Arts, with show dates planned for March 26-28th.  We have had to search for outside space although we are part of a college because we have been met with so many closed doors when seeking space and support at Emerson as an independent production.  We hope to see changes to this climate, but in the meantime, we are really needing this support so this show can see the stage and this important conversation about sexual assault and abuse can persist and be looked at in new and important ways within the Emerson community and the Boston community as a whole.Contributions will also help fund our intricate multimedia set, costumes, props, and set pieces.  They will allow us to design and print programs, posters, and other advertising, which is important to us because we want to get the word out to as many people as possible.  Although this is a small show, it has a big message, and we want it to reach as many people as it can.We are aiming to do all we want to do on the smallest budget possible, and pulling a lot of strings in order to make it all happen, but even a small amount of funding will really help to create the world of Seventeenth more colorfully and more wholly, and certainly impact the impression that the show will therefore leave on its audience after the curtain falls.Any funds raised beyond our goal will be donated to the Boston Area Rape Crisis Center to benefit victims of sexual assault in the Boston area.Why this show?This show is especially important because the voices that get to speak through the words of this show and the messages that are opened up for dialogue and discourse are ones that are often silenced. Since collegiate matriculation, we have met so many survivors of abuse and have seen so many of their voices silenced.  This play is a fight back against all of that, and your support is the final stepping stone to really get those voices heard.Thank you to all who have helped to make this show a reality!Reserve your tickets in advance:Tickets for Seventeenth

story:
Help us support the thesis production of graduating Columbia University MFA playwright Tabia Lau!


THE DETAILS - 


JOHN 8 by Tabia Lau

Directed by Jesse Jou


'JOHN 8' is the thesis production of Columbia University MFA playwright Tabia Lau. One of the winners of the annual Infinithéâtre Write-On-Q competition, which honors new plays by Québec playwrights, 'JOHN 8' will be presented for 3 performances only in April 2015.


Shaped with the guidance of thesis mentor Sarah Ruhl, Tabia Lau's 'JOHN 8' is the first entry in the Columbia Stages 2015 NEW PLAYS NOW Festival at the Pershing Square Signature Center.


Columbia Stages is pleased to present the first fully staged production of 'JOHN 8' after its successful reading at The Pipeline in 2014.


WHY WE NEED YOU - 


We are thrilled for the opportunity to bring JOHN 8 to life, and to do it, we need your support. From sets to lighting, costumes, sound, and props, we want to give our incredible designers the ability to create the world of JOHN 8. With your help, we will also be able to compensate our dedicated cast and crew.


ABOUT JOHN 8 -


'JOHN 8,' is an exploration of madness in the mundane. In the near future that curiously resembles today, five people check into work each morning, alienated from one another by written rules, confident that today will be like any other. Their tasks are simple, almost mindless, and as their days drag on, impatience and boredom begin to take their toll. For hidden from them under layers of bureaucracy and classified information above everybodys' paygrades is an experimental program much more sinister, working as diligently as them, for the greater good. 'JOHN 8' is a play about unquestionable authority and collateral damage in a faded grey, nondescript downtown building.


For more about Tabia:

http://www.tabialau.com/

For more about Columbia Stages:

http://www.columbiastages.org/


MEET THE TEAM -


THE COMPANY:

Nick DeMarco

Grace Denoncourt

Charity Farrell

Ethan Nguyen*

Alex Teicheira*


PRODUCTION:

Playwright - Tabia Lau

Director - Jesse Jou

Stage Manager - Julian Silverman

Scenic Designer - Christopher Cancel

Costume Designer - Annie Simon

Lighting Designer - Jennifer Reiser

Sound Designer - Ien DeNio

Fight Director - Adele Rylands

Producer - Erik Kaiko


*These Actors are appearing courtesy of Actors' Equity Association.

Equity Approved Showcase.


THEN, COME SEE THE SHOW! - 


Thursday, April 16 at 3:00 PM

Saturday, April 18 at 7:30 PM

Sunday, April 19 at 2:30 PM



The Ford Foundation Studio Theatre

at the Pershing Square Signature Center

480 W. 42nd St.

New York, NY 10036



For general admission tickets: http://columbiastages.org/

For industry tickets: e-mail newplays@columbiastages.org

story:
Short Summary

Cold Fusion is a timely play about alternative energy, trust, and paranoia. We have four performances scheduled this June as part of the 2015 Hollywood Fringe Festival in Los Angeles.

The story: All Trevor has to do is answer a few questions. All the patent clerk has to do is sign a piece of paper. But when the answers aren't forthcoming, neither is the pen. As the investigation gets more intense, it becomes obvious they both have something to hide.

As the play cuts between the invention of "the machine" and the final meeting with the patent office, a story unfolds that reminds us who has the power in the fight for clean energy.

What We Need & What You Get

The $3,500.00 we're raising goes to cover production expenses, including:
  • Venue rental
  • Rehearsal space
  • Payment for our director, stage manager, and actors
  • Marketing
  • Wardrobe, props, set design
All contributors receive tickets to the show, and day one contributors get a perk upgrade - anyone who contributes on day one gets the perks for the next highest level. Look through the contribution amounts and their related perks, we have some great stuff for you!

Obstacles & Opportunities

As with all productions, finances are the biggest challenge. We're funding Cold Fusion from our personal finances, and this crowd-funding campaign will help us recoup the costs. 
We're positioned to produce a great play. This is our second year participating in the Hollywood Fringe Festival, and between us we've produced a number of other outstanding shows. David Henne (The Lying Game) brings his theatrical experience to the project, and David Harper brings a wealth of experience having produced a number of award winning films and plays.

Other Ways You Can Help

Obviously, your financial support is gold to us. But you can also help by spreading the word! Share this campaign on social media. Tell your family. Tell your friends. Tell strangers in the elevator. Tell everyone! And together, let's create Cold Fusion.

story:
The Impact

Kilusan’s work has always been rooted in servicing the needs of the larger community and empowering youth throughout the country. It’s the community that helped fund a successful fundraising campaign back in 2012 to bring the Universal Self Production to the Sahabhaga: Festival of Participatory Performance in Bagalore, India. Since then, numerous performances of Universal Self have brought together thousands of people from various ethnic and socioeconomic backgrounds into one space to build cross cultural unity & empowerment. Kilusan is appealing to the community once again to help fund the production of Universal Self to the FringeNYC Festival stage and to bring to light his story onto a national stage. Your contributions matter because individuals like you are making a powerful statement with their dollars that reinforces innovation & originality in the performance arts.  Universal Self is valuable to the world because it is a story about healing from personal experiences, while simultaneously celebrating a multicultural reality in the 21st century.

Summary

International performance artist, humanitarian & entrepreneur, Kilusan Bautista, is an emerging voice for the Filipino American community and diasporic communities raised within the Hip Hop Generation. Kilusan means movement in the Philippines and he was given this name in 1999 as a reminder to live as a conscious and caring global citizen. Originally from San Francisco, CA and currently based in New York City, Kilusan combines the performance elements of theater, spoken word poetry, martial arts and interpretive movement. With over fifteen years of experience as a performance artist and playwright, Kilusan has performed Universal Self in over 50 different venues across the United States, reaching over 20,000 diverse audience members. With your help, Universal Self made its first international debut in November 2012 at the Sahabhaga: Festival of Participatory Performance in Bangalore, India and received rave reviews from the local theater community.

The goal of this campaign is to raise funds for the production of Universal Self at the New York International Fringe Festival (FringeNYC- http://www.fringenyc.org/) for a five night run in August 2013. FringeNYC is the largest multi-arts festival in North America, with more than 200 companies from all over the world performing for 16 days in more than 20 venues. Out of hundreds of submissions, the Universal Self production was selected to play at this highly prestigious festival.  It’s a pivotal launching point for upcoming Broadway shows that attracts investors, producers, Broadway industry people for the upcoming off/on Broadway productions. Universal Self’s five night run will be at The Theater at the 14th Street Y in New York City – August 11th,  14th, 16th, 19th, and 23rd. For more information on show times and ticket sales, please visit http://www.fringenyc.org/basic_page.php?ltr=num.

Your contributions will help bring Kilusan one step closer towards his goal of bringing Universal Self to a Broadway stage as the first contemporary Asian Pacific American production that crosses over into all communities throughout the United States and around the world. Help us bring to the national stage a story of the real life experiences of Filipino American youth in urban American.

What We Need & What You Get

The goal of this campaign is to raise $3,000.00 for production costs. Costs include salaries for the production team including the Animation Director and Theater Director. Funds will also be used for marketing and promotional materials such as programs. 

Director Stipends: $2000

Marketing Materials: $1000

In return for your support, Universal Self will provide perks from the $20 - $400 contribution levels. Perks include shout outs on all social media platforms, a Kilusan T-shirt, a DVD copy of Universal Self performed at the 2013 FringeNYC festival, two front row tickets to Universal Self at the 2013 FringeNYC Festival and a live performance/workshop by Kilusan Bautista.

 

Here’s what people have said about Universal Self:

"FINALLY THERE IS HOPE OF A FILIPINO UNITY DAY WORLDWIDE--LET'S SUPPORT KILUSAN'S UNIVERSAL SELF! THE BIG BOSS BROUGHT US TOGETHER!"

-Joe Bataan, King of Latin Soul

 

"Collaboration with Kilusan was actually the first live performance I've had at my fight. The professionalism he showed during preparation and leading up to my fight was exceptional and only gave me added confidence when he stepped in the ring and held the microphone......Kilusan is an inspiration through his word and music to all walks of life."

-Nonito Donaire Jr., Top Rank Boxing, WBO Super Flyweight Champion

 

“Kilusan Bautista captivates audiences with his multi-character exploration of the Filipino-American experience. Bautista employs monologue, music and martial arts to construct an engaging and evocative saga.”

-Daniel Gallant, Executive Director of the Nuyorican Poets Cafe, NY

 

“I'm honored that Kilusan Bautista performed an excerpt from his solo show Universal Filipino in his San Quentin State Prison class. The students were moved by a story that resonated so well with their own struggles. And we had another great discussion on masculinity, in relation to Frank Chin’s “Chickencoop Chinaman,” that preceded and connected with Kilusan’s performance.”

-Terry Park, Prison University Project

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If money’s tight, you can help the Universal Self production by helping us getting the word out and telling your family/friends about Universal Self’s five day run at the FringeNYC festival. Please visit www.fringenyc.org for more information. It’s also as easy as using the Indiegogo share tools.

We hope you consider making a contribution to this worthwhile project! Much love, peace, and blessings to you all.  Onward to Broadway!

 

Universal Self Production Team

Kilusan Bautista – Actor and Playwright

Lia McPherson – Artistic Director

Tony Santa Ana – Theater Director

Chuck Mays – Music Director

Richard O’Connor (Ace & Sons Moving Pictures LLC) – Animation Director

Chauncey Velasco – Stage Manager/Photography

Kairi Bautista – Technician

Nse Obot – Media Documentation

Ken Songco/ Rose-Ann Ubarra-Cunanan/ Maisha Rodriguez - Community Consultants

story:
The Tampa Repertory Theatre, recently named Best of the Bay New Theatre Company by Creative Loafing, and Hat Trick Theatre Productions, in their first season back in Tampa, are teaming up to bring Hamlet to the Studio Theatre at HCC Ybor City. 

Directed by C. David Frankel, TampaRep's artistic director, and starring Jack Holloway, Hat Trick's artistic director, Hamlet is part detective story, part psychological profile, part swashbuckler, part romance, and part comedy. The play mixes genres as rapidly as Hamlet switches moods.

Although it’s one of the most famous plays of all time, Hamlet still can surprise; it's an exciting story that twists and turns, and veers from the sublime to the comic and back again -- and it's been a dream for both theatres to put it on stage.

Now, we're doing so -- but we could use your help.  If you're in the Tampa area, we'd love to have you in the audience:

Hamlet opens April 25, 2013 and runs through May 12. You can get all the production information and also purchase tickets on our website: www.tamparep.org.

Whether you can come or not, though, you can still help us out, and get one of our great perks, by donating to the production.  Your support will help us pay the artists -- some of Tampa's best actors and designers, something closer to what they deserve.  Everything we earn goes into the production, and beyond the actors there's rent, scenic and costume material, advertising -- all those things that a theatre company needs to do.

Hamlet brings TampaRep's second mainstage season to a close, following the company’s critically acclaimed production of The Glass Menagerie in January.  Hat Trick turns its attention to Neville's Island to close out their season. Then it's on to next year, and another season of bringing great plays to great audiences -- with, we hope, your great support.

Here are some other ways you can help:

  • Spread the word about Hamlet, and about our IndieGoGo campaign
  • Contact us to volunteer your time and expertise (info@tamparep.org)
  • Bring a friend to the Studio Theatre for the production

See you at the theatre, and thanks.

C. David Frankel, Jack Holloway
and everyone at TampaRep and Hat Trick Theatre

story:
With the ALL GIRL PROJECT, the Chicago Mammals are committed to creating extreme and unique opportunities for Chicago actresses to play roles that are rarely if ever performed by women. 

The stories that we have produced thus far were 2 classics from the Western Canon with either none or relatively few female characters (ALL GIRL MOBY DICK and ALL GIRL FRANKENSTEIN).  Sold out houses and immense critical acclaim made producing both ALL GIRL MOBY DICK and ALL GIRL FRANKENSTEIN among the most rewarding experiences that this theater company has been a part of. The next phase of this project is a festival of one acts in October 2014 (ALL GIRL EDGAR ALLAN POE). Also, we are beginning to workshop a full length production for next year (ALL GIRL DRACULA).

The ALL GIRL EDGAR ALLAN POE project provides even more opportunity for women within our Chicago Theater community. Whereas our previous productions provided exceptional opportunities for women on stage, ALL GIRL EDGAR ALLAN POE provides those same opportunities behind the scenes as well. Not only are the shows fully cast with women. Each of these projects has been conceived, written, directed and led by amazing women artists in our community. 

We need your support to keep working in this "vein".

Realizing classic literature such as E. A. Poe's which uses elaborate elements of sci-fi and fantasy requires resources. We need your help getting the costumes, a new video projector, lighting equipment, additional technical tools and design elements. Also we need your help to keep our Zoo Studios doors open, a safe place to mold and shape this amazing play and share it with our audience. Thank you for helping us realize this goal. 

Your support will also go into our initial workshop of ALL GIRL DRACULA. That support is essential so that we may bring a quality to this project that equals or exceeds our last project, ALL GIRL FRANKENSTEIN. That show was a "monster" to produce, but with the help of our friends and fans, it came together wonderfully. We hope that you’ll help us once again to continue in that "vein" with ALL GIRL DRACULA ;)

That support is essential so that we may bring a quality to this project that equals or exceeds our last project, ALL GIRL FRANKENSTEIN. That show was a "monster" to produce, but with the help of our friends and fans, it came together wonderfully. We hope that you’ll help us once again to continue in that "vein" with ALL GIRL DRACULA ;)

story:
The 11th Asheville Butoh Festival

We are pleased to welcome Paul Michael Henry from Glasgow, Scotland and Ken Mai from Japan via Helsinki, Finland. Both of these seasoned butoh dancers, have toured their work throughout the European festival circuit, including Edinburgh Festival, WOMAD Festival UK, Moving Bodies Festival in Italy and Ireland, FLOW Festival in Helsinki, and various butoh festivals worldwide.

New work by local butoh dancers Sara Baird, Jenni Cockrell, Constance Humphries and Julie B Gillum will highlight the festival as well. The 2017 Asheville Butoh Festival will include 4 evenings of performance April 20 - 23 Thursday through Saturday at 8:00 PM and Sunday at 7:00 PM.  

Workshops will be on Saturday April 22 and Sunday the 23rd, 1:00 - 4:00 PM All events will take place at the BeBeTheatre, 20 Commerce Street in downtown Asheviille.

Production costs for the 4 evening-length shows are $3200. Your tax-deductible donations are going toward the cost of presenting these important performances at the BeBe Theatre. All funds raised will contribute to the costs associated with presenting this unique and important festival.

Contact ACDT at office@acdt.org if you would like to make your donation tax deductible.

Meet the Dancers

Paul Michael Henry - paulmichaelhenry.com
Ken Mai - kenmaibutoh.blogspot.com
Julie Gillum - ashevillebutoh.org
Sara Baird - anemonedance.org
Jenni Cockrell - strangedaughtersbutoh.com
Constance Humphries - constancehumphries.com

story:
I am thrilled to have recently been offered the most incredible life changing opportunity - a place at Mountview Academy of Theatre Arts to complete a Postgraduate Diploma and Masters in Musical Theatre.

I have worked all my life for a chance like this but I cannot afford to accept my place. 

Since I graduated from the Royal College of Music in 2011 I have been working six days a week as a teacher, inspiring young children and teenagers to do what I love to do best - performing. Now, having the chance to attend Mountview Academy of Theatre Arts would give me the opportunity to get closer to achieving my own career ambitions and I would be honoured if you would consider supporting me.


Course Fees

Postgraduate Diploma in Performance: Musical Theatre (UK/EU) - £14,950

MA Registration Fee (Fee additional to Postgraduate Diploma) - £1,550

TOTAL:      £16,500


About me... 

My name is Christina (Stina for short). I am one of seven musical children and grew up in a little village called Burley in the New Forest. I began learning the cello and piano from an early age and attended Stage Door School of Dance & Drama. When I was 12 I was awarded a scholarship to attend Chethams School of Music in Manchester, where I also began training classically as a singer. In 2007 I became a scholar at the Royal College of Music, where I specialised in cello and began gigging around London as a singer songwriter. Alongside this I started teaching singing, songwriting, cello and piano to young people to support myself. Last year I became a BBC Introducing artist after uploading my debut EP to the BBC Uploader and I am thrilled to have had airplay on BBC National Radio. I am now trying to do everything I can to be able to have a career in performing and to make a living from what I love to do best - being on stage.


Share my link: http://igg.me/at/stinamountview

If you are not in the position to be able to help me, I would be so grateful if you could forward this onto anyone you think might be. If you could also share the link to this page on Facebook and Twitter, this would really help me to spread the word and find the funding I need.


Course information

Fees: http://www.mountview.org.uk/applying/fees/curre...

Postgraduate Diploma in Performance - Musical Theatre: http://www.mountview.org.uk/performance/mapg-mu...

Masters - Musical Theatre: http://www.mountview.org.uk/musical-theatre/1-y...

story:
WedRepCo – an innovative theatrical Company that's been active since 2011.

Our goal is to raise money to help cover costs like theater space, lighting & tech designers and all the usual expenses related to theatrical productions.

With your contribution, we will be able to continue providing the NYC+ community with stage productions that entertain, enrich & move audiences...

Shows are at: The Paradise Factory - Theatre A | 64 E 4th Street  NYC

Performance Dates/Times:

Wednesday Nov 15 - Saturday Nov 18 @ 7pm

Saturday Nov 18 @ 2pm (matinee)

Sunday, Nov 19 @ 5pm

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Sometimes the timing doesn't work for contributing, but you can still help:

  • Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • There are cool Indiegogo share tools - please use them!

story:
Our PLAY

It’s been said that there is a power struggle whenever two people walk into the same room. This power play is often innocent and accidental between strangers, but it has also been known to be deliberate and dangerous among our more intimate relationships. Set against the backdrop of the sexual fetish world of S&M, Role Play examines the insecurities and jealousies that can naturally arise in a gay relationship and the unnatural revenge tactics that they bring. After all, there’s a thin rope between love and hate. Please be advised, Role Play features graphic and adult subject matter.   
 
Role play is written by Greg Turner and Directed by Sara Sahin. With: Ryan Barry and Max Rhyser.

 

Your ROLE

The funds we receive will help us get to Dublin! We'll be rehearsing here in NYC and travelling to Dublin for 10 days. What does all of this entail, you ask? Imagine putting on a show here - we'd need actors, rehearsal space, props, scenery, etc... Well, we still need all that - but we also have to get everyone to Dublin! So add on airfare and housing for five! All money raised will go directly towards getting us to Dublin and mounting our World Premiere at this year's festival!

 

The DETAILS

2013 marks the 10th anniversary of a groundbreaking international gay theatre festival in Dublin. We feel very fortunate to have been selected to a part of this years anniversary festival! 

We will have 7 performances over 6 days: May 13th - 18th. Performances will be held at the Players Theatre at Dublin's renowned Trinity College. 

If you'll be in Dublin, please do join us - here's a link to more info on our show: http://bit.ly/160TyLd

For more information on the festival: http://www.gaytheatre.ie/

Thank you for your support! We raise our glass (of Jameson!) to you! Sláinte!

story:
EPPIC's mission is to extensively and strategically use the performing art of mime as an educational and outreach tool locally, nationally and internationally. To accomplish this mission we serve to help initiate charcter education programs in public and private schools and provide in-depth training towards developing and equipping fully functional mime crews.

EPPIC Ministries is a unique organization with a specific focus. The organization exists to bring to the field a visible, easy to use tool that bridges age, language and cultural barriers. This tool is used in two main venues; schools and churches.  In schools we use original charcter education sketch material specifically developed for use in public and private schools to help initiate and support character education programs.  In churches we use what we generically refer to as "The Gospel in Mime".  “The Gospel in Mime” is a repetoire of over 60 Biblical sketches that are used to produce programs of various lengths from 15 to 90 minutes.  These programs are used effectively all over the world, captivating the imagination of all age groups.

Today we need your help in the first step towards developing a Ukrainian national mime crew.  The two week tour we are raising funds for will positively impact thousands of Ukrainians and serve as the beginning of a two year process to establish a team like EPPIC's in the Ukraine.

As an incentive to help, we are offering you, the donor, some perks.

And if you can't give at this time, please, please, pass this on to those in your sphere of influence. Use the tools at this site to help you with that.  We would greatly appreciate it!

Christopher Erickson -Director

story:
About DNCB The Dallas Neo-Classical Ballet (DNCB), a non-profit organization, was founded in August 2011, under the direction of Emilie Skinner and Victoria Dolph-Tran, to create opportunities for experienced professional dancers looking to utilize their classical ballet training. DNCB also seeks to work with DFW-based visual artists and musicians to create a link between the art communities.

The DNCB Mission Working with young professionals, DNCB seeks to establish a supportive, healthy environment in which dancers, artists and musicians can express their passion for the arts and institute a sound future for classical ballet in Dallas.

What We Need & What You Get 

ALL DONATIONS WILL GO TOWARDS FUNDING OUR SPRING PRODUCTION OF SHEHERAZADE. This production will feature costume and set design by Dallas-based artist, Danielle Georgiou and new choreography by DNCB founders, Victoria Dolph-Tran & Emilie Skinner. 

Where your donations will go

• Funds for theatre rental and crew. 

• Custom-made costumes for our dancers and sets. 

• Dancers pay: the more we make, the more the dancers receive in the end - and they deserve a lot for their hard work and dedication! 

• Back to you! - We will provide wine and hors d'ouevres at our events and offer rewards for donating! 

• All donations are tax-deductible! 

Other Ways You Can Help 

• Spread the word and share the link, even if you cannot afford to donate. 

• You can easily help us using the Kickstarter share tools! 

• Come see us perform! June 6, 2014 at the Courtyard Theatre in Plano.

story:
Any contribution helps! You even help us by sharing this with your friends!

About Discoverie of Magic:

Appearing in both the Hollywood and San Diego Fringe Festivals; Jackson uses the tools of theatrical magic and the psychology of the unknown to combine equal parts “show” and “think” to create an experience of magic that truly begins after the show ends. A mystery awaits us all, the only question is: when will we find it?

About the Artist:


Camp Kesem, CA

Jackson Ridd is a sleight-of-hand Magic Castle Magician and Artist that has performed at the Magic Castle of Hollywood, in international TV, and at fundraisers for national charities (The Jordan Farmar Foundation, City of Hope, Relay for Life). His artistic mission is to enhance thought and renew positive perspective through the art of magic. This Fall he will be speaking at a TED Conference on the importance of mystery.

What your Contribution Will Do:
- Help provide a lasting and unique magical experience for every audience member.
- Increase the production value of this special performance series and allow more people to come and experience it.
- Keep the arts alive by allowing more funding to be distributed to theatrical venues and those who work in and assist the arts.

How Your Contributions Fund the Production:
- Fulfillment of registration fees, venue fees, ad space, tech crew and marketing materials (it all adds up!).
- Enhanced props and materials for the audience.

Hollywood | Show Dates & Location:
The Underground Theatre
1314 North Wilton Place
Hollywood CA, 90028
  • Sunday: June 15 2014, 4:00pm
  • Thursday: June 19 2014, 8:00pm
  • Sunday: June 22 2014, 5:00pm
  • Saturday: June 28 2014, 8:00pm
San Diego | Show Dates & Location:
The 10th Ave. Theatre ― Cabaret
930 10th Ave.
San Diego CA, 92101
  • Thursday: July 3 2014, 8:00pm
  • Friday: July 4 2014, 6:30pm
  • Saturday: July 5 2014, 9:30pm
  • Sunday: July 6 2014, 11:00pm
  • Friday: July 11 2014, 2:00pm
Your Impact:
- This show is very important to magic and to theatre.  It blurs the line between a cerebral experience of magic and the visceral thrill of entertainment.  Every audience member will remember this show as something they have never experienced before.
- Your contribution will help us achieve our vision, and most importantly, increase the enjoyment of every single member of the audience.

story:
Carrie: The Musical

50% Fruit Theatre, under the direction of Zachary Parsons-Lozinski, is an independent theatre company dedicated to producing fierce, shocking and thought provoking interpretations of well known, and cult-classic theatre. 

Last August, they brought you a punk-rock exploitation b-film interpretation of August Strindberg's naturalistic tragedy "MISS JULIE", which was met with excited reactions: 

"Parsons-Lozinski is full of sexual tension and sexual menace as the predatory, would-be-puppet-master Jean. Janine Hodder gives her Christine a controlled edge of menace which is gripping. And Kerry Johnson is a revelation as Miss Julie... one of the finest things I've seen all this Fringe Festival." - Paula Simons (Edmonton Journal)

Pick of the Fringe - Paula Simons (Edmonton Journal)

"Inexplicably odd..." - Mel Priestley (Vue Weekly) 

This Summer, 50% Fruit Theatre brings you one of Broadway's most talked about productions:

CARRIE: The Musical

Lyrics by: Dean Pitchford

Music by: Michael Gore

Book by: Lawrence D. Cohen

Based on the Novel "CARRIE" by: Stephen King.

Directed by: Zachary Parsons-Lozinski

Stage Manager: Erika Grace

Musical Director: Daniel Belland

Choreographed by: Amanda Neufeld 

Fight Direction: Chance Heck

Starring: Alyssa Billingsley, Amanda Neufeld, Jaimi Reese, Zachary Parsons-Lozinski, Hillary Gillett, Brennan MacGregor, Kerry Johnson, Adam Mazerolle-Kuss, Abigail Collins, Chance Heck, Bethany Hughes. 

Band: Daniel Belland, Justin Moes, Jennifer Skoleny, Martin Hagen

A Night You'll Never Forget

Unfortunately, as excited as we are to be bringing you this incredible piece of theatre, the truth of the matter is that producing a big budget musical is expensive - that is where YOU come in. 

Your contributions would go towards:

  • Performance Rights
  • Venue Costs
  • Sound Equipment 
  • Promotional Materials
  • Props
  • Costumes 

This production, due to the nature of the company, is being paid for completely out of our Artistic Director's pocket - your generosity means the world to us and will be met with gifts! Including:

  • Posters signed by the cast, crew and band.
  • Complimentary tickets to the show.
  • 50% Fruit Theatre official t-shirts.
  • Costumes from the show.
  • Private Q&A's with the artistic team
  • Entertainment at your next public event.

The Best Prom Night Ever 

50% Fruit Theatre is a collective of local artists, banding together to create fierce, and shocking art. 

It is our love of theatre which propels us forward in our journey to construct exciting interpreatations of popular theatre...

Your donations would go towards all costs involved with putting together a big budget, two-act musical at the Edmonton International Fringe Festival - ultimately make it easier for the creative team (actors, tech, and band) involved to be guaranteed some form of payment at the end of the process.

Please consider making a donation towards CARRIE: The Musical, and PLEASE share this page with anyone you think might be interested in contributing towards this exciting production.
