story:
Only Heaven Knows How Glory Goes, What Each Of Us Was Meant To Be. In The Starlight, That is What We Are. I Can See So Far.

That is a quote from the show Floyd Collins that I had the privledge of playing Floyd in. As an actor, I truly understand this line, in that I don't know where my journey will take me, but I know its the only path I could ever be on.

Hello, my name is Jonathan Elliott Coarsey, and I am an Actor. I have been all my life, and hope to keep performing until the day I die. I have been traveling around for the last four years working at every theater that would give me a job. Luckily for me, a lot of them gave me jobs. Now my travels have found me in the city of Philadelphia. I am working towards becoming an Equity Actor so that I can acheive my lifelong dream of working on Broadway. (Watch the video above to get to know a little more about me)

I have started this campaign because I am having to accept some very time consuming but very low paying jobs in an effort to earn enough credits to get my Equity card. I am currently working as an understudy at the Walnut Street Theatre in their production of An Ideal Husband. While this is an amazing experience that I am learning a great deal from and advancing my position within the company, I make very little money from it. 

I am asking for the help and kindness of any one who has ever had a dream that they wished to pursue. I am asking you to help me achieve my dreams so that I may in turn, help others on their path. All donations will go to help me provide for my very basic needs such as food and shelter, as well as allowing me the time to go audition, prepare for roles, and network. To show my appreciation, I will be glad to send any one who donates a signed head shot along with a thank you card. Any donations of $25 or more will receive an I Heart JEC sticker, and donations of $100 or more will receive an I Heart JEC coffee mug. I will also try to get anyone who donates, tickets to what ever project I am working on at the time if you are in the area. 

I thank you for taking time to read my story and for your support in my pursuing my dream. If you would like to help in other ways, please feel free to visit my personal website at www.JonathanElliottCoarsey.com and support whatever project I am working on at the time. Thank You
story_txt:
Only Heaven Knows How Glory Goes, What Each Of Us Was Meant To Be. In The Starlight, That is What We Are. I Can See So Far.

That is a quote from the show Floyd Collins that I had the privledge of playing Floyd in. As an actor, I truly understand this line, in that I don't know where my journey will take me, but I know its the only path I could ever be on.
Hello, my name is Jonathan Elliott Coarsey, and I am an Actor. I have been all my life, and hope to keep performing until the day I die. I have been traveling around for the last four years working at every theater that would give me a job. Luckily for me, a lot of them gave me jobs. Now my travels have found me in the city of Philadelphia. I am working towards becoming an Equity Actor so that I can acheive my lifelong dream of working on Broadway. (Watch the video above to get to know a little more about me)
I have started this campaign because I am having to accept some very time consuming but very low paying jobs in an effort to earn enough credits to get my Equity card. I am currently working as an understudy at the Walnut Street Theatre in their production of An Ideal Husband. While this is an amazing experience that I am learning a great deal from and advancing my position within the company, I make very little money from it. 
I am asking for the help and kindness of any one who has ever had a dream that they wished to pursue. I am asking you to help me achieve my dreams so that I may in turn, help others on their path. All donations will go to help me provide for my very basic needs such as food and shelter, as well as allowing me the time to go audition, prepare for roles, and network. To show my appreciation, I will be glad to send any one who donates a signed head shot along with a thank you card. Any donations of $25 or more will receive an I Heart JEC sticker, and donations of $100 or more will receive an I Heart JEC coffee mug. I will also try to get anyone who donates, tickets to what ever project I am working on at the time if you are in the area. 
I thank you for taking time to read my story and for your support in my pursuing my dream. If you would like to help in other ways, please feel free to visit my personal website at www.JonathanElliottCoarsey.com and support whatever project I am working on at the time. Thank You

story:
Your contribution will fund The Eclectic Company Theatre's upcoming Spring production, opening April 11, 2014.  ECT is a not-for-profit theatre company dedicated to bringing new work to the San Fernando Valley at an affordable price.  In this day of $75.00 - $100.00 tickets, please help us offer a quality evening of Theater for less than $20.00 to students and the general public. 

We are raising funds that will go directly to providing professional costumes, lighting and set design in our intimate black-box space on Laurel Canyon Boulevard.  

THE MINISTER’S BLACK VEIL by Nathaniel Hawthorne (author of The Scarlet Letter and The House of the Seven Gables)

Adapted for the stage by Timothy Sprague

An adaptation of the short story by Nathaniel Hawthorne, first published in the 1836 edition of The Token and Atlantic Souvenir. It later appeared in Twice Told Tales, a collection of short stories by Hawthorne published in 1837.… Set in a small Massachusetts village circa 1700, the town’s Minister, Reverend Hooper, unexpectedly shows up at Sunday service wearing a black veil over his face.  This creates a stir among the townspeople, who begin to speculate about his veil and its significance.  They become even more flummoxed when they realize that Reverend Hooper has no intention of removing the veil during a funeral and wedding ceremony later the same day, or ever. They eventually turn to Mr. Hooper’s fiancee, Elizabeth, to reason with him but even she cannot convince him to remove the veil or explain why he has chosen to wear it at all times.  Hawthorne's tale of guilt, superstition and fear still rings true today and reminds us how much influence the attitudes of America's Puritan settlers still hold over our contemporary beliefs.  

“Literary critic Edgar Allan Poe proposed that the issue of the minister's self-veiling was a mystery conceived to be solved or inferred by the reader. While Poe proposed this, Hawthorne never lets the reader know the reasoning behind the veil. While the veil is the main symbol in the story, it is also ironic. Hooper, in his stubborn use of the veil parable of one sin, is unconsciously guilty of a greater sin: that of egotistically warping the total meaning of life. In addition to standing for a man's concealment or hypocrisy and for Hooper's own sin of pride with its isolating effects, it stands also for the hidden quality of second sin.” … Wikipedia

The Eclectic Company Theatre (ECT) is a collaborative collective of actors, writers, directors, producers, and technicians whose vision is to nurture individual artistic expression and to present innovative, socially relevant work to the Los Angeles theatre community. Through new works and reinterpretation of established works, the ECT explores, questions and challenges the status quo both in society and theater while striving for productions of the highest quality.

This production is intended to illuminate the work of one of America's greatest authors, Nathaniel Hawthorne.  Much of Hawthorne's writing centers on New England, many works featuring moral allegories with a Puritan inspiration. His fiction works are considered part of the Romantic movement and, more specifically, Dark romanticism. His themes often center on the inherent evil and sin of humanity, and his works often have moral messages and deep psychological complexity. His published works include novels, short stories, and a biography of his friend Franklin Pierce.

Ralph Waldo Emerson wrote that "Nathaniel Hawthorne's reputation as a writer is a very pleasing fact, because his writing is not good for anything, and this is a tribute to the man".[97]Henry James praised Hawthorne, saying, "The fine thing in Hawthorne is that he cared for the deeper psychology, and that, in his way, he tried to become familiar with it".[98] Poet John Greenleaf Whittier wrote that he admired the "weird and subtle beauty" in Hawthorne's tales.[99]Evert Augustus Duyckincksaid of Hawthorne, "Of the American writers destined to live, he is the most original, the one least indebted to foreign models or literary precedents of any kind".[100]

story:
We are Parrot's Beak Theatre, a brand new theatre collective dedicated to making the most visually innovative, thought provoking and strikingly relevant verbatim theatre in the world.

We are five recent graduate theatre makers who would really appreciate your funding for our debut show Too Far Right. 

About the show:

In response to the rapidly evolving, multi-cultural and multi-faith Britain, Parrot's Beak playfully thread together questions of home, belonging and community through original writing, verbatim text and a dynamic visual experience. 'Too Far Right' raises one of the toughest debates woven into the fabric of our diverse society: how far can the right to freedom of speech extend before it becomes a threat to that society?

Any funding we raise will be spent on the cost of hiring the venue, promotion of the show, props and costume. Any amount is helpful so please donate what you can even if its only a little bit! Even if you can't donate anything you can help us by spreading the word about Parrot's Beak and Too Far Right.

Follow us on twitter @ParrotsBtheatre #TooFarRight to see how your funding is helping us to achieve great things!

story:
NXG COMPANY


The NXG Family was created in 2009 by a young dancer named Alexander Chung. Since then, Alex has been training and creating, selecting some of the best dancers in the city to team together and make moves in the dance community.


In April 2014, NXG Company flew to Montreal to compete for the first time in the Canadian preliminaries for Hip Hop International. With an age from 11 to 27, their hard work resulted in achieving first place in the nationals. They are now one of three megacrew groups representing Canada at Hip Hop International in Las Vegas. 
NXG Company has won many titles locally and internationally; most recently World of Dance Hawaii 2013 champions and first place in the All-Stars category at Represent. Members of NXG Company are constantly training their craft. They have also trained as a unit in Seattle, Los Angeles and Vancouver, and trained under the guest direction of choreographers such as David Moore, Christopher "Pharside" Jennings, and Kolanie Marks. 

We are extremely humbled and lucky to have such an amazing community to cheer and support our endeavours. Thank you for your generosity and for supporting our journey to HHI 2014! 
- NXG Company

story:
Ten Years of Halloween Marionette Magic

"Driveway Follies" is a professionally staged Halloween marionette show performed each year in an Oakland driveway and is accompanied by an outstanding scary yard haunt.  The locally recognized shows are enjoyed by over 1,000 Halloween revelers annually.  From its start in 2007, response has been enthusiastic.  Now all seats are filled and audiences overflow into the closed-off street. 

The show includes dozens of elaborate and intricate figures, backdrops, props, period music and sets – all built by hand by Driveway Follies artists. Director Larry Schmidt often adds new sequences so each year Driveway Follies presents a unique never-seen-before show comprised of vignettes about our now beloved characters. Beginning in 2007 with three puppeteers performing three acts, the show has grown to five acts performed eight times a night for three nights by seven puppeteers. The acts each depict a unique aspect of Halloween - sometimes having an educational twist.

Sustaining a Lost Art

In a time of computer generated entertainment, Driveway Follies offers a rare opportunity to see the nearly lost art of puppets and marionettes in an intimate setting. Because of his commitment to proving free performances to the community, Director Larry Schmidt has self funded the shows since inception.  However growth has resulted in increased production and safety costs and has prompted us to think about sustainability.  Seeing increasing costs and fearful that he can no longer support them alone, the Director decided to reach out to the community for help.  

We asked Fractured Atlas to serve as our fiscal sponsor which allows us to accept tax- deductible donations.  In addition to local support we are using crowd- funding and seeking grant funding to keep the show available and free to the public.  So this year, we are both fund-raising and friend-raising.  We are asking you to become a Friend of Driveway Follies through your contributions, and to stay in touch with us in years to come.   

Driveway Follies is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non­profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Driveway Follies must be made payable to “Fractured Atlas” only. Any contribution above the value of the goods and services received by the donor is tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.      

About the Director 

“I don’t feel like I’m using Halloween to express my individuality; I feel like Halloween uses me to express itself”, Director Larry Schmidt.

Larry founded Driveway Follies and has been its creative force since the beginning.  Driveway owner and master puppeteer, he grew up in Oakland in a time when there was a lot of trick-or-treating and he made his first yard haunt as a child. As an adult, Larry noticed that the neighborhood celebrations of Halloween were disappearing.  People weren't putting out jack-o-lanterns, or trick-or-treating like they used to.  Larry views Halloween as a wholesome, inter-generational, neighborhood activity.  Driveway Follies is an alternative to the gore and commercialism that is part of many modern Halloween attractions.

Larry received a Bachelor of Fine Arts at California College of Arts and Crafts.  He was introduced to puppets by his grandmother and it has been a lifelong hobby.  He has created costumes for the Oakland Ballet and has mentored budding puppeteers.  

Driveway Follies Future Magic

Larry and his crew are currently working on a new show based on a traditional Irish legend of the origins of the Jack-o-Lantern.  The new show will add to the over half dozen sequences.  Please join us in support for this year’s show and future Driveway Follies Future magic.

story:
Short Summary

The Awake and Alive Project is a series of monologues and scenes written by and about real people who are affected or infected with HIV. Sad, funny, and poingant, Awake and Alive really brings to light the stories and lives of those infected.
 
A&A is a project to raise awareness for HIV/AIDS through theatre and other means through college campuses across the world.  Our mission is to raise awarness and money( to go to the AIDS Institute) to find a cure for the virus, and talk about how to protect yourself.

What We Need & What You Get

In July of 2012, I(Emerald) started to write a play based on the experiences people have had surrounding the virus HIV/AIDS. The first production of that play, Awake and Alive, will be in December, in Bethany, West Virginia. We have two wonderful directors and a flurry of actors willing to spend the time and energy needed to originate a role.

But here's the thing, the Awake and Alive Project (A&A) is bigger than a small town in West Virginia. The Awake and Alive Project is about sharing life experiences, and moving people to become aware in their communities. We want A&A to become something that's shown on college campuses all over the world- because my generation has the highest rate of infection- because my generation perpetuates this disease- and it's time to do something about it. Our hope is to become a non-profit organization dedicated to first of all hearing the stories of victims who are HIV+ and their families, and second of all offering communities and colleges the chance to make a difference in their community- customized to be what their campus hears the loudest. Eventually, we want so many stories coming into our fold that each campus can choose which pieces they would like on campus, with a certain number required in each production.

We're trying to raise $1000 for the Awake and Alive Project, to cover the cost of  starting the process of becoming a non profit organization, to build a website, to cover outreach cost to other people affected by AIDS who want to share their stories and to reach out to colleges and campuses across the globe to tell these stories and end AIDS.
 

Our perks are listed on the right, but we want to thank you for just watching our video and reading what we're doing. Truly, without you caring and supporting us- we would just be a group of passionate, overworked students.

The Impact

Once we get this up and running, who knows where it can go? Our hopes and dreams and plans for this things are huge. We want it to change the way people look at HIV postivie individuals(No Stigma), how HIV Positive people look at themselves, and to raise awarness about protecting yourself from the disease.

Other Ways You Can Help

So, if you can't donate but are interested in helping(or producing the show on your campus) PLEASE

Share our Indiegogo page and facebook page.

Share your story about how HIV has affected your life

  • Are you or someone you know positive?
  • Have you been involved with a community outreach program for HIV?
  • Are you a testing counselor or health care providor?

Contact us! We would love to talk with you about getting rights for the show and ideas for how to make an STD/HIV awareness week on your campus.

story:
Short Summary

Tera Zarra has been a valued contributor to the West Coast performing scene for years, as a musician, actor, acrobat, and coach and teacher. She recently found out that she has a rotator cuff tear which prevents her from doing acrobatics or aerial, which is her livelihood!  

She has contributed greatly to this communty through her art, her performance and teaching.  She has also volunteered performances and services for a variety of benefit events and even coordinated an entire benefit performance when acrobatics coach Stefan Furst had a similar medical disaster.  It's our turn to help her out!

What We Need 

 - The MRI alone cost $1300, and that's just for the diagnosis...

 - From here, she will receive PRP injections which cost between $500-$1000 per injection!  It's not yet clear how many Tera will need.

Tera doesn't have medical insurance, and is paying for all of this out-of-pocket, which is made increasingly challenging as the injury prevents her from doing her work!  Any little bit helps!

Other Ways You Can Help

 - Let other people know about this campaign!  Share on Facebook, over email, word of mouth...

 - Send Tera some loving thoughts!  Make her a card or bake her a pie.  Feel free to communicate via campaign coordinator Jacki Ward here: jacki.ward@gmail.com.  

Testimonials:

From Stephanie Lopes and Gemma Adams, of Night Flight Aerial:

"Tera Zarra is a powerhouse of a performer. She is an acrobat, aerialist, singer, strongwomen and ninja.  As a teacher she is kind and knowledgeable. Tera is also an extremely generous person who rallied our entire community, when Acrobatic Coach Stephan Furst was injured. She created a whole benefit show to aid him with his medical costs. As Tera's entire livelihood rests on her abilities as a performer and acrobatics teacher, and as she has no medical insurance to pay for treatment for her injury, let's all please come together to support Tera with her medical needs. Let's help pick her back up the way she has picked up others."


From Jenn Cohen, founder and director of The Circus Project:

"I've had the pleasure of working with Tera as a performer and a volunteer for the Circus Project.  Tera is incredibly gifted, but more astonishing than her talent is the remarkable generosity of her spirit.  In 2010, Tera volunteered to compose an fundraising song for the Circus Project (watch it at the end of this video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TGSQKXozhvw) to help fund our outreach programs for homeless youth.  I hope that our community can come together support Tera, as she has done for so many of us."

 

From Ari Rapkin, school director of DoJump!

"I have known Tera as a friend and fellow performer, student, teacher, co-creator for about four years now. I can not begin to describe how fortunate I am to have the honor of her friendship. Tera is one of the most driven, talented, generous and compassionate people who I have had the pleasure to work with. She strives to improve herself as a performer and a person with a rare dedication, and at the same time exhibits a deep compassion and enthusiasm to find common ground with those around her across a breadth of interest and experiences. Tera is highly focused on her own development as a performer, and recovering as quickly and soundly as possible from this shoulder injury is critical to her livelihood and the way she lives her life on a daily basis. I hope that you will join me in supporting her recovery so that she can get back to what she does so brilliantly. Having the support of the community will make all the difference in allowing her to continue sharing her talents so generously."
story_txt:
Short Summary
Tera Zarra has been a valued contributor to the West Coast performing scene for years, as a musician, actor, acrobat, and coach and teacher. She recently found out that she has a rotator cuff tear which prevents her from doing acrobatics or aerial, which is her livelihood!  
She has contributed greatly to this communty through her art, her performance and teaching.  She has also volunteered performances and services for a variety of benefit events and even coordinated an entire benefit performance when acrobatics coach Stefan Furst had a similar medical disaster.  It's our turn to help her out!


What We Need 
 - The MRI alone cost $1300, and that's just for the diagnosis...
 - From here, she will receive PRP injections which cost between $500-$1000 per injection!  It's not yet clear how many Tera will need.
Tera doesn't have medical insurance, and is paying for all of this out-of-pocket, which is made increasingly challenging as the injury prevents her from doing her work!  Any little bit helps!


Other Ways You Can Help
 - Let other people know about this campaign!  Share on Facebook, over email, word of mouth...
 - Send Tera some loving thoughts!  Make her a card or bake her a pie.  Feel free to communicate via campaign coordinator Jacki Ward here: jacki.ward@gmail.com.  
Testimonials:
From Stephanie Lopes and Gemma Adams, of Night Flight Aerial:
"Tera Zarra is a powerhouse of a performer. She is an acrobat, aerialist, singer, strongwomen and ninja.  As a teacher she is kind and knowledgeable. Tera is also an extremely generous person who rallied our entire community, when Acrobatic Coach Stephan Furst was injured. She created a whole benefit show to aid him with his medical costs. As Tera's entire livelihood rests on her abilities as a performer and acrobatics teacher, and as she has no medical insurance to pay for treatment for her injury, let's all please come together to support Tera with her medical needs. Let's help pick her back up the way she has picked up others."
From Jenn Cohen, founder and director of The Circus Project:
"I've had the pleasure of working with Tera as a performer and a volunteer for the Circus Project.  Tera is incredibly gifted, but more astonishing than her talent is the remarkable generosity of her spirit.  In 2010, Tera volunteered to compose an fundraising song for the Circus Project (watch it at the end of this video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TGSQKXozhvw) to help fund our outreach programs for homeless youth.  I hope that our community can come together support Tera, as she has done for so many of us."
 
From Ari Rapkin, school director of DoJump!
"I have known Tera as a friend and fellow performer, student, teacher, co-creator for about four years now. I can not begin to describe how fortunate I am to have the honor of her friendship. Tera is one of the most driven, talented, generous and compassionate people who I have had the pleasure to work with. She strives to improve herself as a performer and a person with a rare dedication, and at the same time exhibits a deep compassion and enthusiasm to find common ground with those around her across a breadth of interest and experiences. Tera is highly focused on her own development as a performer, and recovering as quickly and soundly as possible from this shoulder injury is critical to her livelihood and the way she lives her life on a daily basis. I hope that you will join me in supporting her recovery so that she can get back to what she does so brilliantly. Having the support of the community will make all the difference in allowing her to continue sharing her talents so generously."

story:
Our Story

ALL OVER is a play with Blues music about a father and son.  In life, Red-Eyed abandoned his son, Clive to pursue a career as a Bluesman.  Clive, determined to be a better man than his father, went to the Gulf war promising to return home a hero.  Instead, he returned home with Gulf War Syndrome.  ALL OVER takes place in Red-Eyed’s room in Purgatory, where the dead Bluesman relives his life’s mistakes over and over again.  When Clive dies suddenly, both men find themselves together again, stuck in Purgatory with a stranger called Usherman.  Now the Bluesman must answer for leaving his only son.  Both men will have to face what their decisions did to the women who loved them.  ALL OVER weaves together original & standard blues music and poetic dialogue into a searing tribute to the lost. 

 

Hello IndieGoGo!  I'm glad to be here.  My name is Jamie J. Brunson.  Please call me Jamie J.  I am a female playwright and prose writer

story:
Our Story

The idea behind our company is to create a cultural bridge between Spain and the United States by having Spanish and Hispanic artists in New York collaborate, using Spanish as a meeting ground.  The “La Strada” project is the first step in this collaboration, to promote a cultural and artistic exchange between the two countries, strengthening, on the one hand, the Spanish language’s place in the artistic scene of the United States, and on the other, creating opportunities to enrich the artistic scenes of both countries.

Impact

This project is unique because it means a first step towards enriching the cultural exchange between the communities of Spanish-speaking artists in the United States and the artistic community in Spain.  This is only the beginning of many more similarly-aimed projects!

 

What We Need and What You Receive

As the first step in this endeavor, La Strada Company, together with the acclaimed IATI Theater, has chosen to produce the stage adaptation of Federico Fellini’s famous movie “La Strada” in Spanish.

This production will open towards the end of February-March 2011 in New York City, under the direction of the celebrated René Buch (Artistic Director of Repertorio Español), and with the collaboration of another great director, Jorge Merced (Artistic Director of Pregones Theatre). The production will be presented at the IATI Theatre—an essential reference point for Spanish language theatre in New York.

The play will be performed by the members of La Strada Company (Spanish actors Irene Aguilar, Israel Ruiz and Luis Carlos de La Lombana).  We are planning a subsequent tour to Washington D.C. and Miami in 2011.  After that, we have been invited to take our production to Spain and Italy in the summer of this same year.

The chance to bring to the stage a work by a film genius is not an opportunity that comes every day. Nor is it a simple task.  La Strada is a universal work that tackles current problems, such as violence and abuse, as well as showing the “Fellini-esque” universe.  We aim to bring the richness of this work to the stage and provide another platform to reflect on these still current themes.

 But to make this a reality, we need your help!

 

We want to pay Fellini the tribute he deserves with a production that is as fully realized as possible.  We have been working on this project with great hopes for almost two years, and know that it will be reflected in our work onstage.  Thus, we are confident of success!

Together with the funds raised so far, to complete the financing phase of the production we need to come up with an additional $20,000.  And your collaboration will be crucial for the project to move forward. 

On this first online fundraising campaign, our goal is to raise $5,000 by February 1, 2011. We count on your help! 

Other ways in which you can help

Help spread the word about our project! Resend this message to your friends; follow us on Facebook http://www.facebook.com/#!/pages/La-Strada/1579... And don’t miss our monthly parties!

Don’t forget to visit our website (In Spanish): www.lastradacompany.com

story:
For the past year and a half, long-time musical collaborators Lucas Papaelias (a.k.a. LPfunK) and Deborah C. Smith have been creating a new rock musical called Pyramidica: Songs of Freedom.  This Summer, we have been invited to take Pyramidica to the New Writers. New Plays. Festival on Martha's Vineyard. As writers, this month-long artist-residency, culminating in 3 public readings, is a dream coming true. In order to continue on this journey we've started, we need your financial support.


THE MUSICAL


Pyramidica: Songs of Freedom is an ironic, humorous, and fast-paced rock musical featuring an original score of hard-hitting, melodic tunes, with a throbbing pulse and infectious hooks, that takes its audience on a exploration of the power of the pyramid scheme’s role in the pursuit of the new American Dream:  to achieve success, and ultimately, freedom, by working “Smarter, Not Harder.”


Pyramidica takes place at the "free" orientation for a pyramid-scheme company, called "Pyramidica", which has created an algorithm that can quantify freedom.  Company members and clients use the algorithm to make choices in their lives based on the calculated amount of "Freedom" their actions will produce.  We follow several characters at various levels of the pyramid scheme on their individual journeys to discover their Freedom. 


The moral of our story is that Freedom, in any form, cannot be obtained without some sort of a compromise.  Once we can figure out what it is that makes us feel free, and can learn to compromise along the way, we will be better prepared to make our own choices and find balance and meaning in our daily existence. 


THE FESTIVAL


New Writers. New Plays. is an annual festival of new works by emerging playwrights. Hosted by Vineyard Arts Project and Art Farm, and situated in the gorgeous setting of Edgartown on Martha's Vineyard, the playwrights, directors, and actors team up for the first time to focus on the creation of the new play or musical. The month-long residency culminates with a three-day festival of public readings.


THE CAST


We are thrilled to be collaborating on the script and songs with a cast of incredibly talented professional theater artists, all with extensive Broadway and Off-Broadway credits, including Jenni Barber, Damon Daunno, Erica Nadera, Flaco Navaja, Kevin Mambo, Anne Nathan, Matthew White, our Music Director John Pratt and Director Lou Moreno. 


Through this workshop, we will prepare Pyramidica for the next phase of development:  a presentation in New York for prospective producers and agents, with hopes of gathering support for another workshop and/or a production at an Off-Broadway or regional theater. 


THE MONEY


To best support ourselves in this opportunity, we are starting a campaign to raise funds for the following crucial elements of production:


  • Music Director, to help transcribe all of our writing to sheet music ($1000)
  • Sibelius music notation software  ($500)
  • ZOOM H3 audio recorder, to archive the rehearsal process and keep track of musical changes in real time, and be able to enter these developments quickly into the scoring software.  ($300)
  • external hard drive, to save and preserve all of our new work ($250)
  • recording microphones ($250)
  • MIDI keyboard ($250)

We are prepared to contribute what additional funds we can to reach our goal, and are extremely grateful for any contributions towards our efforts.  If we reach only part of this funding goal, it will be applied directly to purchasing the software to create the score, and the professional music director who we are hiring to help us do it.  With our music scored, it will be easier for us to move forward with any future development process. 


THE PERKS!

Find your place in the Pyramid!

Help us lay a strong foundation for our Pyramid... and revel in some of these exciting perks to supporting our project!


$10- Be a Builder!

Get your name in our N.W.N.P. Festival program as a sponsor of Pyramidica


$25- Be a Brewer!

Get a copy of the festival program signed by the Pyramidica cast!  PLUS...

Get your name in our N.W.N.P. Festival program as a sponsor of Pyramidica


$50- Dance with the Concubines!

Get a one-of-a-kind Pyramidica Company tee shirt!  PLUS...

Get a copy of the festival program signed by the Pyramidica cast!

Get your name in our N.W.N.P. Festival program as a sponsor of Pyramidica


$100-  Craft with the Artisans!

Get copies of the ITHACA E.P. (LPfunK's original rock musical) and Stay Awake (Deborah's original solo CD)!  PLUS...

Get a one-of-a-kind Pyramidica Company tee shirt, a copy of the festival program signed by the Pyramidica cast, and your name in our N.W.N.P. Festival program as a sponsor of Pyramidica! 


$250- Join the Advisors!

Get a new audio recording of the songs from Pyramidica! PLUS...

Get copies of the ITHACA EP (LPfunK's original rock musical), Stay Awake (Deborah's original solo CD), a one-of-a-kind Pyramidica Company tee shirt, a copy of the festival program signed by the Pyramidica cast, and your name in our NWNP Festival program as a sponsor of Pyramidica!  


$500- You Will Be Appointed as our Pharaoh!

Get a private living room concert of the entire piece, performed by Deborah & Lucas!!!  PLUS everything above!  And you will be a Pharaoh!

Invite your friends over and blow their minds with a live performance of a new original rock musical happening in your own home!


Other Ways You Can Help

NO contribution is too small...If you can't contribute financially at this time, please consider helping us by forwarding the link to this page to anyone that you think may be interested in our project and willing to support, post it on Facebook or Twitter and spread the word!  Even just setting an intention for us to succeed is helpful and we thank you in abundance for your positive thoughts!  

The CLOSER

In this day and age, taking an original creative idea from concept to production takes more than just will power and stamina. It takes work, experience, time, money, support, love, practice, dedication, a profound belief in what you are doing and the energy to press on despite all obstacles.

We are so grateful to all who have helped us to get this far already, and we thank you in advance for your generosity, your belief in our ability to achieve our goals and your willingness to support us further.

ROCK ON and we'll see you at the Orientation!

xo

Deborah & Lucas

story:
The Chance of a Lifetime!

Beacon Charter High School for the Arts, opened in 2003, has grown to become one of Rhode Island's most successful charter schools.  We have a rich and vibrant artistic community consisting of 225 student artists.  Over the years, our students have received many accolades. Now a group of our theatre students have the opportunity to represent Beacon and our state at the 2014 International Thespian Festival in Lincoln, Nebraska! 

  • 20 Student-Artists will be accompanied by three chaperones and have the ability to immerse themselves in this week-long festival.  They will bring this experience back to their peers at the school.
  • Our Theatre program has repeatedly received international recognition.  This is an opportunity to allow our students to reap the rewards of their hard work!
  • The school is paying for the air travel for students.  We need your support for conference registration and lodging!

What We Need & What You Get

The Details:

  • The registration fees total over $15,000.  Student artists and their families are paying over $9,000 on their own.  That leaves us with an unmet need of almost $6,000!
  • As part of our fundraising efforts, we will be holding performances of the show,  First Encounters of the Quirky Kind, in late May.   You will have the opportunity to be recognized in our show program and/or receive a poster of the show,  For contributions of $100 or higher, you receive an autographed poster and one free ticket to the show.
  • If we don't meet our entire goal with this Indiegogo campaign, we will continue our fundraising efforts throughout the rest of the school year.  Failure is not an option!

The Impact

This is a once-in-a-lifetime experience for our student artists!

  • Even with the smallest donation, you bring our student artists one step closer to their dream!
  • We've conquered Rhode Island, now, with your help, we're ready to take on the world!

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Ananepho Productions and R.E.P Productions Presents

 

A Cloud of Women - A dramatic stage presentation 

"A Cloud of Women" is an ensemble stage presentation that  gives voice to women from the Bible in a way that uniquely depicts their strength, influence, leadership, and faith. Set to an African and Jazz music score by Stanley Stubbs the play covers several millennia from the Creation of the first woman Eve, who serves as the play's narrator; to the years immediately following the death of Jesus in the beginning New Testament Church.

They were Sisters, Aunts, Mothers, and Nieces, but also Queens, Warriors, Businesswomen, and Activists.

This campaign is to raise part of the production costs that total $10,000, and allow life be given once again to this dramatic story of Biblical women who persevered through issues of rape, abuse, and abandonment while impacting Biblical history in every arena  

Many may not realize what lies in these Bible stories. We not only appreciate your thoughts, prayers, and encouragement, but also the way you step out in faith through your contributions.

This cast of women is as talented as a Director could ask for! 

Help us!!  Pass this on to your Family and Friends...and see you at a Performance!!

    

           Written by: Diane Proctor Reeder 

             Directed by: Tim Cross

 

Performance Dates:

March 16th - New Life Christian Fellowship

April 20th - ICE Theatre - Chicago

April 27th - Prairie State College- Chicago Heights

story:
Our Story
In 1838, Edgar Allan Poe began a journey with a short story about the beautifully haunting Ligeia, and in 1845 he inserted a macabre verse about the tragedy of man using imagery of madness, sin, and human gore. This visionary act of romanticizing death would set forth an unstoppable path to the current resurrection of Poe's monster. In 2010 Jade Bartlett of the Wonderland Robbers and Elyssa Samsel (BMI Lehman Engel Musical Theatre Workshop) picked up Edgar's quill and fulfilled his dark plans to walk the razor's edge of beauty and death... More accurately while chugging from a bottle of absinthe, they ripped the quill from his cold dead hand and kicked him in the face. Written in booze and blood the new musical Ligeia is a combination of classically influenced music and a gothically charged ghost story.
2011 in NYC, we arrive ready to bring you into our Dark Education. On March 14th it is time to draw back the curtain and arrange a glimpse into our world of obsession, beauty, addiction, and ultimately death. At the Metropolitan Room in concert form with 6 incredibly talented performers, we will conjure a new genre in musical theater, the horror musical. Forget what you know about the Sweeney guy, the music of the night, or that cute little plant that talks and sings. We take the next step in a journey that began 163 years ago, a journey to make you fall in love with evil, a journey to embrace the darker words.     
The Impact
Tired of pretty musicals with bright lights and happy endings? How about ironic musicals where each line is just an attempt to be cleverer than the next, or possibly sick of everything being a rock musical? Yeah I'm not sick of those musicals either. In fact I love musicals of all kinds, but man I am ready for a change! I also love horror movies; more accurately I love a good ghost story where suspension of disbelief is just as crucial as when everyone in a musical happens to know the same song and dance routine. We aren't trying to save the world, hell we aren't even trying to save musical theater.  We just want to open up the playing field for all forms of storytelling. A new audience is queuing outside the latest horror movie just waiting to be moved by a new form of visceral entertainment. Moved by a world where the ghost is not safe on the screen, but lurking in the room. So real you could almost touch it or it could touch you. They want more than rock operas, jukebox musicals, movie adaptations, and mocking comedies. They want to take a risk.
You can always remain in the safe worlds you are used to, where musicals are only about pretty people singing pretty songs prettily, where movie monsters obey the rules of cinema and are only allowed to walk among us while the camera is rolling. Or you could follow us and dare to be haunted. Open your world to the possibilities that the monster behind the door is real and you helped to create it.
What We Need & What You Get
While being awesome does not cost anything, showing New York that same awesomeness can get pricey. Let’s face it, the economics of producing a concert in New York are astronomical, but that's the world we live in. Without your help we will… well we will find some way to get it done because the date is set, venue booked, and cast ready. However, with you behind us we become invincible. There are practical things we need to pay for like rehearsal space, equipment rental, venue fees, marketing materials, musicians, music director, and orchestrator. There are also incidentals that we must take into account like insurance for all the minds that will be blown and paper towels to clean up the drool from the audience members who wish they were cool enough to support us at the beginning. Consider how much difference you could make in the world of New York City theater by giving a little (or a lot). Everyone involved is pitching in and making monetary sacrifices. This concert is not about making money for anyone, it is about spreading a new vision.
 Our goal is just a beginning of the funding we will need, as the concert is only the beginning of our revolution. We will continue beyond to bring Poe’s obsession to anyone who will hear. We know that you want to be the first to brag about your support and we want to let everyone know that you started the band wagon by giving you credit on our website and at the concert. We're also offering some limited addition perks. These perks are your way to say “I supported the creation of a monster, and have the swag to prove it!"        
Other Ways You Can Help
Money is the root of all evil which in this case is a good thing because Ligeia is a whole lot of evil. But I know you're asking yourself, “What do I do after I donate?” or in the rare instance “I am about to get evicted so I don’t have any money.” Tell everyone you know about the birth of the revolution! The good folks at this website have made it easy by providing you with buttons to connect us with your social media tools. Tell everyone you know to drop by this site and our website and to follow us on twitter and facebook and to go to the concert that you just helped finance. Tell them to read Poe’s short story, tell them to seek out the samples of our music, do whatever you can to get the word out that Ligeia is coming and there is no stopping her. The best thing everyone can do is to submit to her and become a follower. The end will hurt less if you pay her off either with money or adoration but hopefully with both.
story_txt:
Our Story
In 1838, Edgar Allan Poe began a journey with a short story about the beautifully haunting Ligeia, and in 1845 he inserted a macabre verse about the tragedy of man using imagery of madness, sin, and human gore. This visionary act of romanticizing death would set forth an unstoppable path to the current resurrection of Poe's monster. In 2010 Jade Bartlett of the Wonderland Robbers and Elyssa Samsel (BMI Lehman Engel Musical Theatre Workshop) picked up Edgar's quill and fulfilled his dark plans to walk the razor's edge of beauty and death... More accurately while chugging from a bottle of absinthe, they ripped the quill from his cold dead hand and kicked him in the face. Written in booze and blood the new musical Ligeia is a combination of classically influenced music and a gothically charged ghost story.
2011 in NYC, we arrive ready to bring you into our Dark Education. On March 14th it is time to draw back the curtain and arrange a glimpse into our world of obsession, beauty, addiction, and ultimately death. At the Metropolitan Room in concert form with 6 incredibly talented performers, we will conjure a new genre in musical theater, the horror musical. Forget what you know about the Sweeney guy, the music of the night, or that cute little plant that talks and sings. We take the next step in a journey that began 163 years ago, a journey to make you fall in love with evil, a journey to embrace the darker words.

story:
HOW IT ALL BEGAN ... 

The Santa Monica Pier Corporation has joined forces with Tony Award winning actor/director Paul Sand (that's me) to present live theater on The Santa Monica Pier, appropriately named:

THE WEST END THEATER

That’s about as far west as you can get in L.A. This is how it happened. 

I was taking a walk on the pier with a couple of friends one night and I suddenly thought... Wouldn’t this pier be a perfect place to have live theater and present a vivid production of KURT WEILL’S dark, theatrical waterfront songs all about revenge, murder and broken hearts? The next day I contacted Jim Harris, Deputy Director of the pier, and pitched him the idea. He smiled and said, “Okay, we’ve been wanting to add live theater to the pier, and I happen to have an available space at the far west end. It hangs out over the ocean and gets pretty wild up there sometimes... would that suit you?” “You bet it would!” said I. Jim wound up the conversation with, "What do you think of calling it The West End Theater?" I could think of nothing better.

I then tracked down a few beautiful, powerful and intense actors, who can also sing, which I had placed in my… “remember that talent” part of my brain. Happily they all agreed to play. I called my friend Carol Sills, wife and widow of the legendary director Paul Sills who created Second City and Story Theater. Paul and I had worked closely together my entire adult life. Carol Sills found Michael Roth, the musical director, who happens to be a Kurt Weill expert living right here in Santa Monica (!) a block away from Bertolt Brecht’s old house on 26th street (!!). Roth accepted (turns out the guy is brilliant). So did Marie Lalanne, the extraordinary surrealist painter, who came aboard to design costumes and sets, creating the murals on huge canvas panels in keeping with the carnival atmosphere of the pier. The entire company was formed in two weeks. 

We are calling it.  

“KURT WEILL AT THE CUTTLEFISH HOTEL”


The list of Mr. Weill’s songs (so far) to be performed by the “dreamy” ensemble includes:  

MACK THE KNIFE and  SURABAYA JOHNNY... Performed by the beautiful, tall and angry (in a good way)  SHAY ASTAR. 

PIRATE JENNY and BARBARA SONG... Performed by the beautiful and incandescent redhead MEGAN RIPPEY.

LUCK SONG aka ON THE INSUFFICIENCY OF HUMAN BEHAVIOR... Performed by SOL MASON, a tall, lanky, attractive kid on the wisely cynical side. He plays the host in this shady waterfront cabaret.

A FINAL AND HORRIFIC VERSE OF MACK THE KNIFE... Performed by PAUL SAND as MACK, a man obsessed with his own version of  justice and an insatiable desire for revenge.

THE ALABAMA SONG... Performed by the whole company as a goodnight lullaby to the audience from under a red spotlight.

The preview night is December 5th 2013, and the Opening Gala will take place on the 6th of December 2013.  There are two 45-minute shows each Friday and Saturday night, starting at 7.30 and 9pm, throughout December. 

WHERE THE MONEY GOES ... 

(Remember, all donations are 100% tax-deductable.) 

  • Printing costs for programs for one performance
  • Printing of scripts for workshop and rehearsal
  • Photography
  • Lights
  • Technicians 
  • Sound
  • Publicity 
  • Scenic design materials and labor 
  • Rehearsal space

For those of you wishing to donate by check, please make it out to "Santa Monica Pier Corporation" with "West End Theatre" in the memo line. Checks should be mailed to:

Santa Monica Pier / West End Theatre
200 Santa Monica Pier, Suite A
Santa Monica, CA 90401

THANK YOU!  SEE YOU SOON AT 

THE WEST END THEATRE!

story:
Our Story

Zeitgeist Theatre Collective is a group of talented and dedicated Montreal-based theatre artists coming together on a project-to-project basis to create theatre that speaks to issues here and now.

 

Our collective features a dedicated team of local talent, including performances by newcomer Emilia Alvarez, Rosa Ruby Kagan (Buddha & The Rock Star), Catherine Lemieux (The Birth of Weza or Go F@#$ Your Mother, Jesus Jello), Vanessa Schmit-Craan (For Coloured Girls, Macbeth) ), as well as sound design by Dave Luciak, set design by Brendon O’Neill (Icarus Redux, Nextstage Theatre Festival) and lighting by Mee Youn (Segal Centre, Persophone Productions), Dramaturgy by Jeffrey Blatt. Assistant Direction and Production Management by Koby Rogers Hall (Mischief Theatre, The Wrecking Ball Series). Technical Direction by Raphael Grosz-Harvey. Directed and written by Julia Ainsworth (P4W workshop, Blight, The Way - Summerworks)

 

Our Project

Where/How it Started

 

"This project started the day I knocked on the doors of the now closed, Prison for Women in Kingston, Ontario in the spring of 2006. A security gaurd/retired P4W correctional officer answered and told me the prison was closed and that he was overseeing the property until a decision was made as to how the building would be used. Before he could close the door in my face, I proceeded to ask him a thousand and one questions and begged him for a tour of the property.Maybe he wanted to get rid of me, or maybe he needed to share his stories. After a bit of resistance, he answered my questions and I stepped inside. He gave me a tour of the prison, and in the dark empty halls, he told me stories about the women who served their sentences there.

 

This was the first step of this work that would eventually involve interviews with former p4w inmates and correctional officers, lawyers and advocates and inspired me to conduct creative arts workshops with young women on the inside. What I learned through this process moved me to tears and outrage, but most importantly, inspired me to create a vehicle that would share these stories - to somehow make this invisible dimension of our society visible." - Julia Ainsworth (Playwright/Director)

 

Fast forward five years to Montreal, 2011. With support from Montreal's incredibly supportive community of organizations (i.e. Playwrights Workshop Montreal, Quebec Drama Federation, Quebec Writer's Federation), cycles of workshops and a dedicated collective of talented theatre artists, Unfit for Bears will premiere September 14th, 2011.

 

 

 

About the Play:

 

Our upcoming project, Unfit for Bears - Beyond the Walls of Canada's Prison for Women offers a glimpse into an aspect of Canadian Society seldom acknowledged .

 

Until 1995 the only federal penitentiary for women in Canada was the Prison for Women (P4W). Notorious for the countless human rights violations that took place within its walls over the course of its 70 year history, the Archambault Commission once described P4W as “unfit for bears, let alone women.”

 

Written and directed by Julia Ainsworth, this original script is inspired by real interviews with incarcerated women and correctional officers.Building on its successful workshop run in 2010, this full-scale production illuminates stories of survival and rebellion from within Canada’s infamous federal prison for women.

 

In September 2011, as our federal government advocates harsher sentencing and expands our prison system, Unfit For Bears goes beyond the walls of P4W and into the hearts and minds of the women who experienced it first hand.

 
“"Too Hot for CBC"”- – CBC Radio One

 

"Focuses the mind on what it means to be incarcerated. Is anyone likely to be corrected by the

correctional system"? - Pat Donnelly- Montreal Gazette

 

The Impact of Giving

We invite you to contribute to this very special project by making a donation that will help this production reach its full potential. Whatever you can give is appreciated beyond words and reflects your desire to support work that will inspire reflection and dialogue about this timely issue.

 

Our indieGoGO campaign will help to cover the costs of mounting this original production in a site-specific space and cover the production costs (i.e. transforming our phenonenal factory space into a prison, paying our incredibly dedicated and talented artists).

 

It is our hope that this theatrical piece will create awareness and inspire dialogue about the injustices and human rights abuses facing women in the Canadian Prison System.

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

Share our campaign with your friends and contacts. Come see the show. www.zeitgeisttheatrecollective.com

story:
We Reached our Goal, but We Still Need Your Help!

The Artistic Home's production of The American Plan is set to open July 22, 2012. 

Thanks to you we not only closed the gap on the funds to pay our performers, we also managed to do the same for our designers and technical staff! 

But it's not too late to help!  Send us a message to learn how your futher contribution can help us get all the technical elements in place.  

 

The Play

Set against the backdrop of the Catskills during a 1960s summer, The American Plan tells a brutally funny, heart-rending tale of love and loss. American playwright Richard Greenberg (winner of the 2003 Tony Award for best new play for Take Me Out) brings us into the lives a Lili and Eva Adler, a mother and daughter living lives on the fringes of the fabulous Jewish society families frolicking across the lake. A darkly brilliant young woman, forever waiting for her white knight. A mother, unwilling to relinquish her hold on her beautiful, damaged daughter. Both of them forever bound by the twisted mother-daughter bonds of love and hate. When Lili’s white knight actually appears in the form of Nick Lockridge, complete with secrets of his own, three lives are forever altered. 

The Team

The American Plan makes us take a long hard look at the price we pay for love, for personal happiness and what lengths we are willing to go for those we love.

At the helm will be acclaimed Chicago director Robin Witt, recently nominated for a 2011 Jeff Award for best direction for the play Stage Door.

Playing the lead role of Eva Adler is Artistic Home Artistic Director Kathy Scambiatterra, returning to the AH stage on the heels of an appearance as Amanda Wingfield in Steppenwolf's NEXT UP production of Tennessee William's The Glass Menagerie. Her most recent role in an Artistic Home production in the long-running, critically-acclaimed Sweet Bird of Youth earned her a Jeff Award nomination for Principal Actress in a Play.

Joining Robin and Kathy are Artistic Home ensemble members Nick Horst (The Tallest Man, Skin of Our Teeth, and Look Homeward, Angel) in the role of Nick Lockridge and Tim Musachio (Sweet Bird of Youth, How To Act Around Cops) in the role of Paul. They will be joined by guest artists Margaret Katch (Lili Adler) and Tonya Simmons (Olivia).

Michael Mroch (Scenic Design) designed our productions of House of Yes, The Tallest Man, Sweet Bird of Youth, and Tea and Sympathy) since graduating from Columbia College with a BFA in Directing and Scenic Design. Other recent design credits include The Sea with Theatre Mir @ Theatre Wit, They Are Dying Out and The Word Progress on my Mother’s Lips at Trap Door Theatre, Ironmistress with Oracle, Old Times with Strawdog, and Brand with Red Tape.

Emily McConnell (Costume Designer) is new to The Artistic Home, though she is company costume designer for O’Malley Theatre Productions and Head Costume Designer for the National High School Institute. She has worked in Chicago with Steep Theatre, Gift Theatre, Griffin Theatre, Theatre Mir, American Theatre Company, Remy Bumppo, About Face, and others since receiving her M.F.A. in Costume and Set Design from Northwestern University. 

Garvin Jellison (Lighting Designer) designed our productions of Marisol and Tea and Sympathy. You may have also seen Garvin's work in Sweet Goddess Project (Honey Pot Performance), The Misanthrope (DePaul University), and Shadow of a Gunman(Seanachai Theater Company). Garvin is a staff electrician at the Historic Merle Reskin Theater and is studying Lighting Design at DePaul University.

Adam Smith (Sound Designer) designed our productions of Sweet Bird of Youth, Trouble In Mind, Marisol, and A Touch of the Poet.  He has also worked with other Chicago theatres including Stage Left, Eclipse Theatre, SiNNERMAN Ensemble, Greenetree Productions and Babes with Blades, and his regional credits include Actors Theatre of Louisville and Jenny Wiley Theatre in Kentucky.  

Loretta Rode (Stage Manager) is an AH company member and has worked on our productions of Sweet Bird of Youth, Trouble in Mind, Marisol, and A Touch of the Poet.  Loretta graduated from Columbia College with a Bachelor in Technical Theatre. 

 Your Role

Help us make it happen by pledging today.  Your pledge is an invaluable contribution to the Chicago theatre tradition and our commitment to continue bringing it to you.
story_txt:
We Reached our Goal, but We Still Need Your Help!
The Artistic Home's production of The American Plan is set to open July 22, 2012. 
Thanks to you we not only closed the gap on the funds to pay our performers, we also managed to do the same for our designers and technical staff!

Other recent design credits include The Sea with Theatre Mir @ Theatre Wit, They Are Dying Out and The Word Progress on my Mother’s Lips at Trap Door Theatre, Ironmistress with Oracle, Old Times with Strawdog, and Brand with Red Tape.
Emily McConnell (Costume Designer) is new to The Artistic Home, though she is company costume designer for O’Malley Theatre Productions and Head Costume Designer for the National High School Institute. She has worked in Chicago with Steep Theatre, Gift Theatre, Griffin Theatre, Theatre Mir, American Theatre Company, Remy Bumppo, About Face, and others since receiving her M.F.A. in Costume and Set Design from Northwestern University. 
Garvin Jellison (Lighting Designer) designed our productions of Marisol and Tea and Sympathy. You may have also seen Garvin's work in Sweet Goddess Project (Honey Pot Performance), The Misanthrope (DePaul University), and Shadow of a Gunman(Seanachai Theater Company). Garvin is a staff electrician at the Historic Merle Reskin Theater and is studying Lighting Design at DePaul University.
Adam Smith (Sound Designer) designed our productions of Sweet Bird of Youth, Trouble In Mind, Marisol, and A Touch of the Poet.  He has also worked with other Chicago theatres including Stage Left, Eclipse Theatre, SiNNERMAN Ensemble, Greenetree Productions and Babes with Blades, and his regional credits include Actors Theatre of Louisville and Jenny Wiley Theatre in Kentucky.  
Loretta Rode (Stage Manager) is an AH company member and has worked on our productions of Sweet Bird of Youth, Trouble in Mind, Marisol, and A Touch of the Poet.  Loretta graduated from Columbia College with a Bachelor in Technical Theatre. 
 Your Role
Help us make it happen by pledging today.  Your pledge is an invaluable contribution to the Chicago theatre tradition and our commitment to continue bringing it to you.

story:
I took the opportunity of my aunt's wedding to schedule a clown quest with my wife and son to Washington DC from October 2nd- 9th, 2013. 

1000th Pie in the face for... Somebody

I deliver pies in the face to willing faces only.  As of today I have delivered pies to ~1000 willing faces.  I believe the pie-in-the-face symbolizes innocence, purity, new beginnings, and the sweetness of life.

A willing face HAD agreed to rendezvous with us on the 8th, so we booked our flights to coordinate with his schedule.  However, he abruptly walked away from the project, and  our tickets are non-refundable & non-transferable.  Typical clown reversal of fortune.

Expenses:

This is an estimated breakdown of the trip for Justin, Trish & Orion.  My family will come as assistants, biggest fans, and voices of reason/ moderation.

  • Cross Country Travel: We bought 3 RT tickets from Seattle (SEA) to the Ronald Reagan Airport in Arlington (DCA).  We departed on Wednesday October 2rd and returned on the Wednesday 9th. ~ $1020 (@$340*3 ppl)
  • Local Travel: The airport shuttle, public transport around DC (MetroRail/ MetroBus), taxi. ~$150
  • Accommodations: We'll stay at the cheapest place we can (Motel 6). ~$531 (before tax)
  • Meals: We estimate food for three will cost at least ~$300 (@50*6)
  • Lost Income: We'll each be missing a week of work.
  • Pet-care: We will offer a stipend to a friend for a week's pet-sitting expenses for the dog, bird and turtle ~ $100
  • Indiegogo will take 4% if I do meet it and 9% if I don't.
  • PayPal also takes their 2.9% cut.


Perks:

I'm providing a great deal of value for contributors, so my profit margin is not actually that great.  In many cases, I'm just asking for an advanced booking and at a reduced rate.  You can book a pie in the face/ seltzer delivery, singing telegram, full party, Laughter Yoga session, or comedy consultation for less than I ordinarily charge.

I developed other collateral materials like: Pie Soap, Pie Garden Paver, How To Deliver a Pie Manual, Jusby T-Shirt, etc.  The funds raised have helped get those into production.  The first limited edition run of hand silk screened shirts is completely spoken for.  There were 20 shirts produced in Large, XL, & XXL.



The Impact

I've paid it forward for seven years, often bringing Jusby the Clown to public and private events and fundraisers for great local organizations for free or below retail.  I have offered the vast majority of the 900+ pies in the face FREE OF CHARGE for the purpose of inducing healthy laughter by participants and audience.

I've said it many times, "Whipped Topping Doesn't Grow on Trees... it grows in a lab somewhere." 

  • I've been clowning professionally since 2005.  I started delivering pies to willing faces in 2007. 

  • My 300th willingly pied face belonged to Patch Adams, MD and was delivered in Seattle, on the occasion of his 65th birthday. 

  • The 400th willingly pied face belonged to Rabbi Seth Goldstein and was delivered at Temple Beth Hatfiloh during the festival of Purim. 
  • Other notable faces pied include: authors James Bernard Frost (“World Leader Pretend”), Lance Reynald (“Pop Salvation”), Monica Drake (“Clown Girl”), and Kass Alonso (“Core”), delivered in Portland, OR.

Monica went on to write an essay about the experience for the Paris Review Daily.

Click to read the essay in a new tab>>The Clown Continuum<<.

I have delivered pies to willing faces in Washington, Oregon, Michigan, Tennessee, and Louisiana. But never in our nation's Capital!  Never on the steps of the Supreme Court (or other national landmark).

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Take us out or bring us in for meals.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Short Summary

Hi I'm Simon Woodcock. i'm an aspiring actor from Bradford, West Yorkshire. 

Let me tell you a bit about myself. I've been performing since a very young age- primary school plays set off a love that continued through high school, doing various theatre projects including becoming a member of the National outside of school before going to university. Whilst at university I performed in a number of plays with the recently formed theatre society there and helped to grow the society and its reputation. Since then I've been working in retail whilst really, really missing the stage and performing. Desperately keen to get into the industry with very little money and no real connection into the industry I knew it was time to apply for training. Researching the options online I discovered the work of Fourth Monkey. It offers innovative actor training for young people based around forming a repertory theatre company in the second year of the course; with my experience at university there was a real Rep feel that I wanted to build on in a more professional atmosphere.

 

So I applied and after a couple of auditions, I got accepted!

 

The course looks amazing (details here: http://www.fourthmonkey.co.uk/content/twoyearrep.) and I've been in contact with others who have been accepted and all of us are massively excited about it. Actor training of this calibre is not cheap. Over the course of two years the fees add up to £15900 and that's without the living costs of London. I am committed to making my acting dream a reality and this training will really enable me to do this.

 

Moving from a northern city like Bradford to somewhere like London is a huge move but its something I'm really ready for. Now I have a place, I'm ready and raring to go but I need help to pay for it. I'm on indiegogo to hopefully find people willing to help!

 

 

How it Breaks Down:

The course costs are as follows:

Year One

£700 non-refundable deposit payable on acceptance of place

£2500 payable by 1st September 2012

£2500 payable by 5th January 2013

£2250 payable by 5th April 2013

Total: £7950

Year Two 

£3000 payable by 1st September 2013

£2500 payable by 5th January 2014

£2450 payable by 5th April 2014

Total: £7950

 

I've set a target on here of £5500 (accounting for indiegogo's fees).

If raised this money will pay for my first and second terms at Fourth Monkey. Obviously this is not where the fundraising ends. I'm selling things on ebay and trying to attract funding from a variety of other sources locally and nationally. I will be continuing to raise money throughout my time training.

 

Remember, if just 100 people gave £25 each I could pay for one term outright. Even the smallest amount could really make the difference for me.

 

So What's in it for you?

The chance to be an integral part of a young performers early career? :D

 

Realistically there is not loads I can do in return for your kindness. What I can do though, I will put in every effort to do!

 

I pledge to send you a personalised letter of thanks for your contribution. And let me tell you in advance how truly thankful I am for any contribution you can offer! As often as possible I will keep you up to date on my progress and training and wherever possible I will notify you in advance of any forthcoming performances and offer complimentary tickets where available.

 

Also, if you do contribute and  think you can use my performing skills for anything; corporate videos, commercials, presenting or events I'd be more than happy to oblige wherever I can. And if there's anything else I can offer to help with- if you want a labourer, gardener whatever... I 'll try to help!

 

Lastly, I promise your contribution will not be wasted. If I can sort out the course fees through fundraising life will be slightly easier whilst I'm there and I will be able to work in order to pay for living costs whilst ever-continuing to fundraise more and more. I'm serious and commited to working in this industry and determined to succeed so despite the actors reputation for drinking I definitely won't be spending your contributions down the pub!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't offer financial support there are still other ways you can really contribute to my efforts. Maybe you know of a charity, an organisation or an individual that helps with cases like mine, or would be prepared to do so. Let me know, let them know. I'm trying everything I can but there will no doubt be funding source's I've overlooked or simply have no knowledge of. Every suggestion is gratefully received.

 

If you can't contribute financially but have something you could donate to my other fundraising channels (unwanted goods I could sell, a platform I could use to get people talking/contributing etc), anything at all. Please do get in touch.

 

Also, if you could get the word out that'd be really helpful. Share this page on social networks, let people know about me and my cause. I need as many people to see this as possible to succeed.

story:
OUR PROJECT

SuitCase Dances is a dance theater collaborative directed by former Staatstheater Darmstadt soloist Peter de Grasse, performance artist and choreographer Vicki Lloid, and designer and former Rome Opera Ballet dancer Raffaele Exiana.  The collaborative creates original, multi-disciplinary work using a team of artists specially assembled for each individual production.  Performances encompass the expertise of dancers, actors, choreographers, writers, and artists, each of whom contributes original materials to the creation of layered worlds of dance theater, tailor-made for the venues in which they are performed.

OUR PERFORMANCE AT THE GESA POWER HOUSE THEATRE APRIL 26

Our current project, “The Relatives,” a narrative dance theater production, tells the tale of a gothic cult that lies in wait for an Innocent to fall victim to their final ritual.  As the ritual goes unexpectedly to ruin, The Relatives  engage in a final conflict with  the Innocent, not knowing that in so doing they risk losing their very identities.  Complete with virtuosic dancing, fairy tale narration, and some comic hijinks along the way, “The Relatives” follows an imaginative, twisting path to the triumph of the human spirit.

YOUR CONTRIBUTION

The 6,000 dollars we raise will go to rental of the theater, honoraria for the composer, production designer, artistic directors, actors, dancers, and musicians, as well as to incidental costs, including everything from SuitCase Dances‘ marketing campaign to bottled water for the performers.

WHY THIS IS IMPORTANT

The project began with a jam-packed performance at Charles Smith Wines last spring, and was presented in preview by the Whitman College Gender Studies Program as the opener for Washington D.C.-based dance/rock act Tia  Nina, who played The Gesa Power House Theatre in October.  
The full production will include a team of five dancers, three actors, and a compact musical ensemble whose members will perform music composed especially for the project.  When this group of unique collaborators comes together at The Power House Theatre on April 26 to bring original dance theater to Walla Walla, you’ll want to be there!

CONNECT

If you’d like to learn more, check out SuitCase Dances on Facebook, and see the artistic directors’ stories, as well as updates on festival appearances, news of the latest members of the team, and the inside scoop on our regular rehearsals.

story:
(10% of all contributions will benefit the Voices Inside/Out Prison Playwriting Program. More info at Theaterspeak.)

70 Playwrights in one window? How are they gonna fit? (And are they neked?)

Yeah! (well, kinda) Over 70 playwrights are gonna be writing Brand New Plays in the window of the Drama Book Shop in Times Square while the screen shot of their computer faces the street, making their process visible to the public. That's pretty naked, people! Three weeks, two hour time slots, 70 playwrights equals Pure Unadulterated Process. That's like TRIPLE Xciting!

That is Triple Xciting but why?

Did you know that traditionally theater artists developed their skillZ with a capital Z in off-off Broadway theaters and performance spaces, many of which are now closed or closing due to the sucky economic environment? They later went on to contribute to the cultural landscape winning Pulitzers, Tonys, among other honors.

Like who?

We're talking (and this is just a sampling)

  • Sam Shepard (Actor/playwright: True West and Heartless currently opening at Signature Theatre Co. Aug. 7th - Sept 16)
  • John Guare (Playwright: Six Degree of Separation and recent Free Man of Color, Lincoln Center)
  • Lanford Wilson (Playwright: Burn This)
  • Lisa Kron (Performer, playwright: Well)
  • Charles Busch (actor, playwright, screenwriter: Die Mommie Die!)
  • Doric Wilson (founder of TOSOS, first professional gay theatre)
  • Al Pacino (Actor hullo!)

But I don't live in New York so I don't get to see any of that.

You ever wonder how movies like The Social Network got made? Or TV shows like Law and Order, Nurse Jackie and Mad Men? It was the accumulation of lots of lots of work by a lot of people but without the writer that shiznit would not be there.

And ya know what? ALL of those shows and many more were written by playwrights! Love your playwright!

I do love my playwright! (And I really like those shows.)

So does Theaterspeak! We also love this country and world of ours made up of PEOPLE like YOU who CREATE meaningful connections in their lives, large and small. Theaterspeak believes that we are as great as the stories we tell (from every walk of life) and that's why are going to give playwrights a place to write and we invite you to be part of the story.

Really? Little ol' me?

Check it:

  • You can come by and watch the writer and their process (and maybe become a part of it)!
  • You can FB, Tweet and follow the playwright's career!
  • You can watch their shows or buy their plays and read them (or do them and then tell us about it!)
  • You can support a whole new 21st century canon of work by the most exciting award-winning and up-and-coming playwrights of the new millenium! (Yowza!)
  • And the next time you're watching the Tonys, Lilys, Emmys or Academy Awards, you can say you were there.

Some of the stuff you're funding:

The biggest expense of Write Out Front is maintaining the installation and taking care of the playwrights in the way that Theaterspeak thinks all playwrights should be taken care of. So this is the drill which rinses and repeats every two hours.

  • The Playwright comes in and is greeted with a big smile.
  • We hook up their notebook to the monitor and make sure they are communicating well. (It turns out every notebook is different and some of them are persnickety!)
  • We document them pinning their personal item of inspiration to the WOF Wall of Inspiration (part of which will be donate, part of which is a perk!)
  • We get them coffee and water.
  • We promote them by posting pics and comments on FB, Twitter, Instagram and the theaterspeak website.
  • We interview them about their process and what it was like in the window.
  • After the writing session, we have them sign the WOF Desk with a gold or silver pen.
  • They  chose a different colored pen and write some inspirational words to emerging writers and artists on the Large WOF Inspiration board which will then be donated.
  • Sometimes hugs happen.
  • At the end of the week, we continue to promote the playwrights by compiling a video of the previous weeks interviews and footage.

Needless to say, the day job is being a little neglected.

In addition to that there is:

  • the rental truck
  • the supplies to create the window
  • The opening party
  • buying lunch for the PA (keep PA happy!)
  • a multitude of adapters

So if you'd like to support this work, please consider contributing to WOF today. Even 10$ helps. And if you can't contribute, consider sharing with friends.

Keep creating.
