a multitude of adapters

So if you'd like to support this work, please consider contributing to WOF today. Even 10$ helps. And if you can't contribute, consider sharing with friends.
Keep creating.

story:
Iï¿½ll be honest with you. Giving money to a non-profit theater project is not like investing in a commercial work of art. I cannot promise you tickets to the premiere, meetings with stars, or a return on your dollar. And yet effective fundraising requires that I offer something to donors in return for their support. So what am I offering you?

I am offering you an opportunity to participate not just in the representation of culture but also in the very making of it. Art does not just reflect. It is not just a way of looking at the present or the past and understanding something new, though it certainly is that. It is also a way of shaping the future: In the theater we are forced to face the consequences of the world we live in and we are enabled to imagine the possibility of a different future. Theater can change the way people feel, think and behave. And I donï¿½t know about you, but Iï¿½m of the opinion that change is needed.

As Long as Fear Can Turn to Wrath, an adaptation of selected chapters of a certain great American novel, will be presented as part of Son of Semele Ensemble's Company Creation Festival in January and February. The play, like the book, begins by illuminating the consequences of an unregulated home loan industry. We then follow the collective Okies as they are swindled by used car dealers, forced to beg for bread to feed their children, denied pay for work they have already performed, and kicked off the one piece of land ï¿½ the Hooverville ï¿½ they have chosen to occupy. By focusing not on any one individual or family but rather on the more than 300,000 people that made up the ï¿½Okies,ï¿½ our production shows that the scourge of poverty infects whole societies, not just individuals.

People will not believe that the words of this theater piece were not written about current events. The problems these families face and the conclusions they draw are separated from those of today only by time, not by sentiment. (Check out our tumblr of images relating then to now.)

We believe that there is power in telling stories and that awakenings can happen when people witness the real human struggles of poverty, hunger and oppression, if only in performance. In this piece, we hope to reveal the consequences of joblessness, convince the viewer that our current path will only lead to more division, and reinforce the necessity of collective action in solving problems.We must change course, and that doesnï¿½t just take action ï¿½ it takes a movement.

Be a part of the movement: Give today. We only need $3500 to make this show happen. (I know, right? Thatï¿½s nothing!) That would cover the set, costumes, lights, sound, and tiny, tiny fees for the 11 individuals without whose creative talents this kind of art does not happen. Thatï¿½s all we need, and you can help.

story:
Our Story

Hi, I am Nicole Roerick, Artistic Director of Nicole Roerick Collective based in Madison, WI. Ever since being involved in the arts, I have struggled to find a way in which to sustain my art making and to be able to reach a wider population. After completing my BFA and MFA in Dance, I am now continuing to create work and to bring it to as many people as I can. My passion for choreography and performance is something that I can not put into words, but I will try. Movement fills my body with emotion, discovery, awareness, and is my life. I want to share my creative visions with others and to draw them into my world and leave them feeling something they may not have felt before. I am extremely grateful for my dancers and think that is important that they receive money for all of their hard work and the time commitment involved. I am presenting one of my works, Enfetter, in New York city with myself and dancers Janelle Bentley and Emily Miller, and I need help with the costs!


What: Enfetter performance

Where: WestFest Dance Festival at the Merce Cunningham Dance Studio in New York City 

When: Dec. 8th and 10th, 2011


The Impact


I have always believed strongly in the arts and the ways in which artists have this ability to reach out to people. My work has the ability to reach people and draw emotions from them and will leave them thinking about the work and how it affected them. Presenting my own work in NYC is important for me so that I am able to bring it to a wider audience and get myself out there in the dance field. Not being able to cover the costs is something that I will always be trying to overcome as I continue to produce and present work locally and nationally, especially as funding for the arts continues to decrease in our country.



What We Need & What You Get

I need help in covering the plane tickets/luggage costs for myself and the dancers involved: $850
Performance and application fee for WestFest: $260
Rehearsal and Performance fees for myself and dancers: $600
Food, transportation etc. for myself and dancers to be in NYC for 4 days: $500
Costumes: $150
Documentation fees: $100

I am also reaching out to my friends and family to help support the Nicole Roerick Collective for this particular performance and other projects along the way. Any amount that I receive will go towards any of the costs listed above and also other costs that are included in starting and running my own company. I also plan on producing a show in Madison, WI in the spring of 2012 and will be creating another campaign in the near future, so any additional funds over my goal will go towards the costs of this production.


This of course is just an estimated budget, and the costs for dance artists in the U.S. are always something looming over our heads. Please help in any way that you can and support artists in need!


By donating money, you will not only be helping me to fulfill my dreams and aspirations, but you will also be giving art the ability to reach people in so many ways. I will include your name on my facebook page and my blog and keep you updated on my future projects as the newsletter is created. I am also willing to offer one and one conversations about myself or my work, private Yoga instruction (I am 200 hour certified), informal showings of my work, and dinner at my home!


Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word and check us out on facebook on our page, Nicole Roerick Collective, and the blog at: nicoleroerickcollective.wordpress.com. A website is being created very soon for NRC!

story:
We are a week away from our Encore performance of Into the Woods!

Sponsor seats now so that our Riverdale Rising Star Teens can attend!!

For $250 you will receive a Full Page Ad

For $100 you will receive a Half Page Ad

PLEASE NOTE:

You may also donate any amount to our RRS Scholarships, that allow any of our RRS students with talent and motivation, but without the needed funds, to pursue their dreams of performing on stage!


We hope to see you Saturday night, March 16, 2013 at 8pm at the Riverdale Y!

 

ONE NIGHT ONLY:
Saturday, March 16, 2013 at 8pm

Broadway luminaries and Riverdale’s most talented performers will join forces for a 25th Anniversary concert production of Stephen Sondheim’s classic fairy tale musical INTO THE WOODS, to be performed at the Riverdale YM-YWHA on Saturday, March 16, 2013, at 8pm.

This one-night only Gala event will benefit the performing arts programs at the Riverdale Y, including the Riverdale Rising Stars scholarship fund, which will enable children and teens to participate in the organization’s productions.

Tax-deductible tickets range in price from $50-$250, and may be purchased by calling 718.548.8200, online here or at www.RiverdaleY.org.

ABOUT THE SHOW

Follow the stars and travel INTO THE WOODS! Everyone thinks they know the stories of Cinderella, Little Red Riding Hood, Jack and the Beanstalk, and Rapunzel. But what happened after “happily ever after?” This witty and sophisticated musical about the legacy we pass on to future generations features an ingenious book by James Lapine and a timeless Stephen Sondheim score which includes the songs “Children Will Listen” and “No One Is Alone.”

Riverdale Rising Stars Director of Performing Arts Laurie Walton (the Broadway revival of Show Boat) stars as the Witch alongside Broadway veterans Jim Walton (The Mystery of Edwin Drood, 42nd Street, Merrily We Roll Along), Emily Walton (Peter and the Starcatcher, August: Osage
County), Joe Cassidy (Catch Me If You Can, Next to Normal, Dirty Rotten Scoundrels), Joseph Kolinsky (Titanic, Les Misérables, A Christmas Carol), Jamey Hood (How the Grinch Stole Christmas, The Shaggs), and Maryrose Wood (Merrily We Roll Along).

The cast is rounded out by teenagers and adult alumni from the Riverdale Rising Stars program, many of whom have performed Off-Broadway, Off-Off-Broadway, and on national tours. Joining the Broadway talent will be Annette Arnold, Lily Bayrock, Eric Berger, Wiley Cohen, Arianne DeCerb, Jim DeBlasi, Patrick Dwyer, Leora Einleger, Shara Feit, Gregory Kanter, Jacob Levi-Dabby, Drew Lewis, Leo Lopez, Katleen Lozada, Luz Montez, Ezra Mutnick, Liz Powers, Marilyn Raider. Elia Rangel, Michal Schorsch, Catherine Schwartz, Diego Velazquez, Breffni Ward, and Chris Wilson.

This concert production will be directed by Bob Walton (performer in Broadway’s The Drowsy Chaperone, 42nd Street, Show Boat, and City of Angels), and the full orchestra will be led by music director Justin Fischer.

 

We are a week away from our Encore performance of Into the Woods!

Sponsor seats now so that our Riverdale Rising Star Teens can attend!!

For $250 you will receive a Full Page Ad

For $100 you will receive a Half Page Ad

PLEASE NOTE:

You may also donate any amount to our RRS Scholarships, that allow any of our RRS students with talent and motivation, but without the needed funds, to pursue their dreams of performing on stage!


We hope to see you Saturday night, March 16, 2013 at 8pm at the Riverdale Y!

story:
Short Summary

Haste are a brand spanking new all female international theatre company fresh out of their training on St Mary's Physical Theatre course. Our varied and strong creative backgrounds make us open to experimentation with forms old and new, resulting in a vibrant theatrical mix.

We look for the moments that make you laugh and cry at the same time, we are fascinated with stories that can reflect something of reality back to the audience and we make sure you have a lot of fun in the meantime.

Oyster Boy will be our third show together, touring throughout the UK and internationally in the summer of 2013. We have already been invited to perform at San Diego , Rome and Camden Fringe Festivals and schools across London, with plans for Germany and Scotland all in the mix.

What We Need & What You Get

We are super excited to travel to pastures new and share our work with as many different people from as many different walks of life as possible... but it all comes at a cost:

Flights for 6 to our various destinations: £5,000

Venue and production costs: £750

Marketing and promotion: £200

Insurance: £1000

We will of course be seeing a return from our ticket sales, projected at around £2500, but this will not be until after we have finished our tour and we need all the help we can get from you lovely people to get us there!

If we sadly do not reach our goal, any conribution large or small will still go far in helping us reach our destinations, and if we are lucky enough to raise more than our total any money surplus will go into company development to ensure longevity and help future projects. 

 

The Impact

Oyster Boy explores what it means to be different in a world where appearance is key and celebrates everything a little bit different. We amalgamate a wide mix of theatrical styles in order to make a piece full of energy, fun, beauty and poignancy that leaves audiences not just entertained but moved.

We are a grass roots company making our way in the world, and we are interested in making affecting theatre that defies pretention and welcomes audiences from all backgrounds to join in our fun. We are part of a strong new wave of young theatre makers who want theatre to be for everybody and not just regular theatre goers.

We are performing Oyster Boy in schools around London, a scheduled street performance as well as traditional theatre venues in order to reach as many people as possible, and your support will go a long LONG way in helping us.

Other Ways You Can Help

Money is not the only kind of support that we are looking for, and if you can't donate don't worry, there are plenty of other ways to help us-

SPREAD THE WORD/FOLLOW US

https://www.facebook.com/HasteTheatre

https://twitter.com/HasteTheatre

And share our Indigogo campaign so as many people possible know about our project.

 

HELP US HELP YOU

If you are an aspiring artist and you think you can help us in any way we would love to hear from you. This will help build up your portfolio of work as well as open yourself up to a whole new network of creatives that could potentially be the start of a beautiful working relationship... 

Musicians, designers, marketing geniuses, writers, technicians, poets, painters, film makers, choreographers, fight directors, puppeteers, circus artists etc

 

The world is our oyster...

story:
We've broken ground on our dream!

Caitlin Bronza-Smith, owner of Bella Diva Dance LLC, has teamed up with Erin Anderson, founder of Communitas Movement LLC, to share a space for people to learn dance, explore movement, and connect through shared experience. 

Construction has begun!

We signed the lease and construction is underway: two complete dance studios, a multi-use treatment room and the ever necessary extra bathroom. Funds are needed to finish the floors and open the doors! If 500 people donate $25 we will exceed our goal. Any dollar amount is deeply appreciated!

  • Our dance studios will reflect our belief in caring for the body, mind and spirit with a padded sport-floor and warm colors. 
  • A treatment room will be available for individual appointments to help care for your body, mind and spirit with a variety of healing modalities.

Our Vision is becoming reality!

  • Caitlin started Bella Diva Dance in 2010. It has been steadily  growing over the past four years and is in need of its own space!
  • Erin has been envisioning Communitas - a community healing arts space - for decades and is ready to launch it to the world!
  • We met in 2011 through Bella Diva Dance and enjoy bringing world dance to Denver! 
  • Together we will serve our community through dance and a variety of healing opportunities.

Other Ways You Can Help!

  • We can always use help with putting the finishing touches on our space. Let us know if there are things you'd like to contribute to this community space! 
  • Please pass our dream on and Join the Movement! using Indiegogo share tools!

and connect through shared experience. Construction has begun!We signed the lease and construction is underway: two complete dance studios, a multi-use treatment room and the ever necessary extra bathroom. story:
What We Need

I've been working on this solo show for the past year and a half and have poured my whole heart and soul into it. This show is the result of an intense collaborative process with the brilliant David Ford and Rebecca Fisher (more below), and countless other peers and audience members who have helped me create what I hope is a moving and thought-provoking show that investigates the terrain of race and love in contemporary America. What does it mean to be a young, dark-skinned black woman in America trying to find love in 2014? How much does skin color still shape our romantic experiences? In attempting to answer these questions, I uncover a deeply traumatic experience that appears to be the real driving force of the show.

After 10+ shows, 100+ hours of prep work, 5 standing ovations, and buckets of blood, sweat, and tears, the hard work has paid off because I've been invited to perform the show at the Cleveland Public Theater (CPT) as part of their Big Box Theater Series. Big Box is an annual showcasing of new, innovative work.  This is an AMAZING opportunity because shows appearing in the Big Box Series receive a lot of publicity and often go on to full production at CPT, Off-Broadway, and the Cleveland Playhouse (birth place of some of the greats like Tom Hanks and Ruby Dee). 

The Cleveland Public Theater also recently joined the National New Play Network, a potent alliance of more than 70 nonprofit theaters that champions the writing and production of new plays. This means, if my show does well, it could run at one or more of the theaters in the network. 

This is truly an amazing opportunity to springboard this show to the next level of production. 

And we can't do it without your help. Your contributions are VITAL to the success of this endeavor and will help fund: 

  • Travel and lodging in Cleveland July, September, and January
  • Crew Fees: director, producer, videographer, choreographer
  • Rehearsal Space
  • Marketing/Promotion

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute financially, but would like to contribute in another way, for example:

  • If you have extra miles that might help with flights to Cleveland.
  • If you know people that love bold and thought-provoking theater, tell them about the show and encourage them to contribute. 
  • If you know someone that might be willing to film the Cleveland Performances on a volunteer basis.
  • Any other ideas about contributing: email me at: brown.echo@gmail.com 

No contribution is too small and and anything given is greatly appreciated!  

***********************************************************************

Show Synopsis

Echo is about to lose her virginity to a good looking white hipster that she met on Craigslist. This will happen in one hour. That gives Echo just enough time to do exactly what you shouldn’t do on the eve of your virginal christening: contemplate America’s racial problems. Echo is black. So she’s use to pondering race. But she doesn’t want to ponder race IN THIS MOMENT. Right now, all she wants to do is convince herself that she is beautiful, despite a lifetime of conditioning to the contrary. To make herself believe in her own beauty, Echo will pray to all of the gods, call her best friend over 20 times, and talk to her cat about the meaning of life. Over the course of the night, Echo will ask some tough questions about love and race in "post-racial" America and she will also come to terms with a traumatic past events that continue to haunt her from the depths.

Review of show: http://www.dailycal.org/2014/01/30/soaring-imaginations-make-superb-solo-sundays-stage-werx/

Artistic Development Team : 

Director: David Ford

David Ford is a renowned, Goldie Award-­‐winning playwright recently named San Francisco’s Theater MVP for 2013 by SFGate. Bringing 25+ years of experience and insight, David has been an integral part of helping develop this show. 

Creative Consultant: Rebecca Fisher

Rebecca is a producer, director and an award-winning writer and performer of solo work. She produces the well-known series Tell it on Tuesday and has directed shows with the SF Fringe Festival, The Exit, and The Marsh. Her most recent solo show Memphis on My Mind won 2013 SF Best of Fringe and is scheduled for a fall run at The Marsh. 

Choreographer: Matrayi Saksena
story_txt:
What We NeedI've been working on this solo show for the past year and a half and have poured my whole heart and soul into it. This show is the result of an intense collaborative process with the brilliant David Ford and Rebecca Fisher (more below), and countless other peers and audience members who have helped me create what I hope is a moving and thought-provoking show that investigates the terrain of race and love in contemporary America. What does it mean to be a young, dark-skinned black woman in America trying to find love in 2014? How much does skin color still shape our romantic experiences? In attempting to answer these questions, I uncover a deeply traumatic experience that appears to be the real driving force of the show.After 10+ shows, 100+ hours of prep work, 5 standing ovations, and buckets of blood, sweat, and tears, the hard work has paid off because I've been invited to perform the show at the Cleveland Public Theater (CPT) as part of their Big Box Theater Series. Big Box is an annual showcasing of new, innovative work.  This is an AMAZING opportunity because shows appearing in the Big Box Series receive a lot of publicity and often go on to full production at CPT, Off-Broadway, and the Cleveland Playhouse (birth place of some of the greats like Tom Hanks and Ruby Dee). The Cleveland Public Theater also recently joined the National New Play Network, a potent alliance of more than 70 nonprofit theaters that champions the writing and production of new plays. This means, if my show does well, it could run at one or more of the theaters in the network. This is truly an amazing opportunity to springboard this show to the next level of production. And we can't do it without your help. Your contributions are VITAL to the success of this endeavor and will help fund: 
Travel and lodging in Cleveland July, September, and January
Crew Fees: director, producer, videographer, choreographer
Rehearsal Space
Marketing/Promotion
Other Ways You Can HelpIf you are unable to contribute financially, but would like to contribute in another way, for example:
If you have extra miles that might help with flights to Cleveland.
If you know people that love bold and thought-provoking theater, tell them about the show and encourage them to contribute. 
If you know someone that might be willing to film the Cleveland Performances on a volunteer basis.
Any other ideas about contributing: email me at: brown.echo@gmail.com 
No contribution is too small and and anything given is greatly appreciated!  ***********************************************************************Show SynopsisEcho is about to lose her virginity to a good looking white hipster that she met on Craigslist. This will happen in one hour. That gives Echo just enough time to do exactly what you shouldn’t do on the eve of your virginal christening: contemplate America’s racial problems. Echo is black. So she’s use to pondering race. But she doesn’t want to ponder race IN THIS MOMENT. Right now, all she wants to do is convince herself that she is beautiful, despite a lifetime of conditioning to the contrary. To make herself believe in her own beauty, Echo will pray to all of the gods, call her best friend over 20 times, and talk to her cat about the meaning of life. Over the course of the night, Echo will ask some tough questions about love and race in "post-racial" America and she will also come to terms with a traumatic past events that continue to haunt her from the depths.Review of show: http://www.dailycal.org/2014/01/30/soaring-imaginations-make-superb-solo-sundays-stage-werx/Artistic Development Team : Director: David Ford
David Ford is a renowned, Goldie Award-­‐winning
playwright recently named San Francisco’s Theater MVP
for 2013 by SFGate. Bringing 25+ years of experience and
insight, David has been an integral part of helping
develop this show. Creative Consultant: Rebecca FisherRebecca is a producer, director and an award-winning writer and performer of solo work. She produces the well-known series Tell it on Tuesday and has directed shows with the SF Fringe Festival, The Exit, and The Marsh. Her most recent solo show Memphis on My Mind won 2013 SF Best of Fringe and is scheduled for a fall run at The Marsh. Choreographer: Matrayi Saksena

story: When setting up our schedule of shows for the new season, we don't get to pick our ideal dates, only what is available on the calendar.  So, once again we have a show when the Seahawks are playing in the Super Bowl (Go Hawks!).   Great for the Seahawks, but not for ManeStage.  Last year, we did have a small audience and our cast and crew gave them a fantastic performance!  However, the funds we lost due to the smaller crowd had a definite impact. Will you consider donating a "ticket" to help us make up the difference this year?  We know you will still come and see the production (either on Super Bowl Sunday or another performance date), but your $20 donation will help us weather this event and keep ManeStage going strong!  Thank you for your consideration!

story:
ABOMINABLE or The Misappropriation of Beverly Onion by Forces Beyond Her Control

Is the story of Beverly Onion, the world’s loneliest mortician’s assistant (and Star Wars fan), who finds herself the unsuspecting subject of a wager between the forces of Fate and Luck. Her darkly comic heroes journey takes her from the basement of Hortaman's funeral home, to the Upper Peninsula of Michigan, to the mountains of Nepal (with plenty of Star Wars Jokes and strange characters along the way), as she seeks to understand her deep connection to the mythical Abominable Snowman. Written by Katie May, directed by Chloe Bronzan, and produced in conjunction with Symmetry Theatre Company as part of PlayGround's 20th annual PlayGround Festival of New Works, this is a play for the lonely hearts, the awkward monsters, and the unabashed geeks inside us all. 

We mentioned there's a Yeti in it, right?

This play was commissioned by PlayGround. It had a staged reading in the Best of PlayGround Festival in May of 2013.  It was further developed at The Lark New Play Development Center in NYC, and it has an amazing cast of actors many of whom have been with the project since day one. And now we're ready for a full production, with a rock star team of talent on board. 

But we want to do it right. That's where you come in.

The When and the Where

  • The Thick House in San Francisco's Potrero Hill.
  • PREVIEWS: JUNE 6th - JUNE 7th 
  • OPENING: JUNE 8th - CLOSING: JULY 9th 
  • Purchase your tickets through the campaign at discounted rates, and we'll hook you up with the dates you want! For the complete performance schedule, visit http://playground-sf.org/abominable.

Not your Grandma's Theater

We've seen lots of Shakespeare, and we like Shakespeare, it's just, well...we've seen A LOT of Shakespeare. This is a World Premiere production of a play for your non-theater friends, for anyone who feels alone in a crowd, for the Yeti-believing cryptozoologists, the Wampa-loving would-be Hoth dweller and, yes, for all you Shakespeare enthusiasts who don't mind coming to the theater and seeing something new. (And if that applies to your Grandma, by all means bring her too!)

So donate if you can, grab your tickets if you're ready, and we look forward to seeing you in the theater!

~Team Abominable 

Abominable is a fiscally-sponsored project of PlayGround (94-3336399) a California non-profit corporation. All donations to Abominable are tax-deductible to the extent allowed by law.

story:
Our Story


“The Edwin Booth Company Presents…” provides a unique opportunity for the students in University of Wisconsin-Whitewater’s Theatre/Dance Department like nothing that this department has done before during the academic season.

It is an original script and the students will be presenting the world premiere performance opening on November 29,  2011. The next step in this educational experience is to take our show on the road and share this accomplishment with the theatre community. This is where you can help!

 

The following is a statement from the play’s writer and director Angela Iannone:


The exciting new play "The Edwin Booth Company Presents…" was written and is being produced specifically to showcase the talents of University of Wisconsin-Whitewater students in all of the disciplines offered in our training program. Please help us fund the productions' participation in the American College Theatre Festival by making a donation today in whatever amount is possible for you. Any donation is appreciated, and will help our students reach their educational and professional goals!
The UW Whitewater Theatre/Dance Department pursues an ongoing commitment to the development of new scripts, new playwrights and emerging professionals in the acting, dance, management and technical theatre fields. To that end, we continue to look for new venues and opportunities for our students to explore their craft. The department is searching out new fund raising tools to supplement the university funds available. Your donation can make all the difference!

 

 

The Impact

 

All donations go to the UW-Whitewater Theatre/Dance Department to start a fund that will help students to extend their education to a national level. This fund will allow students to take their art and their talent on the road to share with the theatre community outside of Whitewater.

The plan of the Theatre/Dance Department is currently to take “The Edwin Booth Company Presents…” to competition at the American College Theatre Festival in January 2012. If this is not possible, the fund will be used to support the students in representing UW-Whitewater in every other way possible at the theatre festival.

 

What you get

 

This campaign will only raise a fraction of the funds needed to present “The Edwin Booth Company Presents…” at ACTF. However, without contributions from donors to offset the cost, this great educational opportunity would not be possible.

By donating any amount, you will be helping to extend the educational and artistic horizons of UW-Whitewater students. This is a once in a lifetime opportunity for many students.

As a thank you for helping us, we will give something back to you. Any person donating $20 or more will receive an autographed copy of the program for “The Edwin Booth Company Presents…” Any person donating $50 or more will receive an autographed copy of the poster from “The Edwin Booth Company Presents…” in addition to a signed program.

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

Even the smallest donation can make a huge difference! Any amount is welcome, encouraged, and greatly appreciated.

Even if you are unable to make a donation at this time, you can make a difference by spreading the word. Share this page with friends, family, co-workers, or anyone you know who supports the arts.

As an additional fundraiser, students are selling raffle tickets. Ask a cast member for more information if you may be interested.

story:
Ticket Availability:

Friday, January 9th - 7:30 (Night): 165 seats left
Saturday January 10th - 2:30 (Matinee): 200 seats left
Saturday January 10th - 7:30 (Night): 140 seats left

Doors of the building open 1 hour before show. Doors to the theatre open half an hour before show. No latecomers admitted. Ticket availability updated daily. No babes in arms. This show is filled with questionable material, including harsh language, as well as strobe effects, fog and mature content. Viewer discretion is advised.

'Donation/Perk' Explanation:

If you would like to make a donation, or get some of these sweet perks, this is the place to be! Donations are simple-simply select the 'Donation/Perk' perk on your right and enter the amount you would like to donate! As for our perks, you have a few to choose from:

Video Recording of the Show: $20 (Add $5 for physical copy)
Soundtrack: $20 (Add $5 for physical copy)
Video+Soundtrack Combo: $30 (SAVE 25%!) (Add $5 for physical copies)
Signed "Herbie Shore and the Quest for the Octamount" Book: $30
Herbie Canvas Print Small (8" by 8"): $40
Herbie Canvas Print Large (12" by 12"): $60

(Physical copies are a CD or DVD. Otherwise you will receive a download link through email.)

You can get as many of each of these as you'd like! All you have to do is add up the total (For example, if you wanted a signed book and a large canvas print, you would add $30+$60 to get the total of $90. If you wanted four soundtracks, none of which are physical copies, you would add $20+$20+$20+$20 to get $80), and then enter that amount for your donation amount! We will then contact you through email to get a list of the perks that you ordered (or you can preemptively send the list to shwawawaproductions@gmail.com). Keep in mind, the soundtrack and the video recording, including their physical counterparts, will be able to ship anywhere in Canada or the United States. The other three perks will not, and MUST BE PICKED UP AT THE PERFORMANCE.

Please keep in mind that if we do not reach our $5000 goal, we will not have enough funds, and most likely will not put up the show. We will then contact you and refund your donation amount. For this reason, it is encouraged you invite your friends to come to the performance, and encourage them to order perks such as a signed book or a lovely, sensual painting of Herbie Shore (a great conversation starter that goes with any and all decor!)


What will you do with $5000?

Why $5000? What will you do with all that money?

The reason we need $5000 is because of all our costs. Our venue alone will cost roughly $2000, alongside our sets and props estimated at upwards of $2000 (since we will essentially have to build a fully furnished side-by-side on stage). We also need to pay people, print posters, advertise, print programs–expenses add up quickly. Our minimum of $5000 ensures the show will be what it needs to be in order to film and send to producers–an end product which shows what the show will REALLY look like if it's put up in another city, province or country!

story:
Who We Are

Hello! We are Sheldon Carpenter and Ilyssa DePonte, co-founders of Torrent Theatre. We have been working over the past few months to prepare Neil LaBute’s Reasons To Be Pretty, and we need your help to present a fully-fledged production of this tragically beautiful comedy.

A love story about the impossibility of love, Reasons To Be Pretty introduces us to Greg, who really, truly adores his girlfriend, Steph. Unfortunately, he also thinks she has a few physical imperfections, and when he casually mentions them, all hell breaks loose. A hopelessly romantic drama about the hopelessness of romance, Reasons To Be Pretty is a gorgeous play.

As a team, we strive to take the training we’ve received at or Alma Mater (Albright College) and our life experiences thus far in order to produce theater that consistently pushes the envelope and challenges our society’s ideals, presenting works that encourage our audience to start a dialogue about humanity and social norms. What has come to be expected of us? Have we fallen into a trap - a vicious cycle of repetitive motions? Do we embrace the status quo and cling to tradition, or do we choose to resist that cycle and make waves in order to strive for something better?


Cast and Creative

Joshua Radford (Greg) Credits include performances in new plays at the Fringe, Thespis and Strawberry One-Act festivals. Other credits include Joe Pitt in Angels in America Part I & II (Geva Theatre), Leslie Williams in The Hostage (Irish Classical Theatre), and Marie Antoinette: The Color of Flesh (Blackfriars Theatre in Rochester). Josh is a proud graduate of SUNY Fredonia and The Barrow Group Theatre Company’s Conservatory Program.

Ilyssa DePonte (Steph) is thrilled to work with such a collaborative and supporting team on Reasons To Be Pretty. NY credits: The Callback at 54 Below, So You Think You Can Belt, and The Cranky Cabaret. Other favorite roles include: Ordinary Days (Deb) and On The Verge (Fanny) with The Domino Players and Susannah (Mrs. McLean) with The Berks Opera Theatre. She would like to thank her friends and family for their continuous support.

Jeffrey Parrillo (Kent) is thrilled to be working with Torrent Theatre on Reasons To Be Pretty. Recent television credits include: Blue Bloods, Lilyhammer, A Crime To Remember. Theater: Two Brothers (Theater for the New City), Painted White With A Bow (Strawberry One-Act Finalist). MFA graduate of The Actors Studio Drama School. 

Taylor Rae Cole (Carly)  is making her ‪New York City Theatre debut. She earned her Bachelor of the Arts Degree in Theatre from Albright College. During her undergraduate career, she had the honor of performing at the Region II American College Theatre Festival on two separate occassions. Favorite past roles include Eurydice (Eurydice by Sarah Ruhl), Stella Kowalski (A Streetcar Named Desire by Tennessee Williams), and Thomasina Coverly (Arcadia by Tom Stoppard). She would like to thank the cast and crew for this wonderful experience, as well as her family and friends for their love and support.


Director: Sheldon Carpenter

Stage Manager: Siobhan O'Hara

What We Are Asking

Producing a play is not an easy or inexpensive venture which is why we need your help. In order to bring this play to an audience, we need to raise $4,500. This includes the costs of the following:

  • Royalties
  • Performance Space
  • Rehearsal Space
  • Props and Scenery
  • Costumes
  • Promotional Materials
  • Artist Stipends for our Cast/Crew

Other Ways You Can Help

If you’re poor (like us) and cannot afford to donate to our cause, all we ask is that you share this campaign to everyone you know in hopes that it can reach even further. If we can get ten different people to donate at least ten dollars every day, we will be able to reach our goal and bring you this witheringly funny dark comedy that is Reasons To Be Pretty.

Visit our Website!

Like us on Facebook!

Purchase Tickets!

story:
Who are we?

Precipice Productions is the collective brainchild of a group of Ryerson School of Performance students, who wanted to create the dangerous art they wished to see in the world.

What are we doing?

Duncan Sheik and Steven Sater’s Spring Awakening is an achingly beautiful rock musical. It is the late 19th century in Germany, a handful of adolescents, trapped by the societal repression of the times, find themselves in the midst of adolescent urges they can neither explain nor deny.

It's a story about sex, growing older and institutionalization of youth. 

We have a stellar team of actors, director, designers and are hard at work bringing the production to the stage!

Where do you come in?

      We need your support to make this all happen, your contribution helps us share this story.

      The money we're raising will go into the production. Our $1,000 goal will go into building our set, achieving the best lighting, and getting the most optimum sound. Any profits made will go directly into our next production. 

       We have some great perks, from stickers/buttons, signed posters, shoutouts, to reserved seating for a show! 

Why are we doing it?

      This may sound cliché, but this is a story about young people told through the lens of young people. Everybody involved in the production is under 25 years old. Some of us are exploring what "adulthood" means, others are just stepping into it.

      Putting up this show is a labor of love. We just have the will to share this story. If you'd like to follow it, here's our Facebook and our Instagram page.

      Thank you for your support, whether it's $2, $10, $50, or sharing our campaign, we appreciate it! <3 

      #SpringIsComing
story_txt:
Who are we?
Precipice Productions is the collective brainchild of a group of Ryerson School of Performance students, who wanted to create the dangerous art they wished to see in the world.
What are we doing?
Duncan Sheik and Steven Sater’s Spring Awakening is an achingly beautiful rock musical. It is the late 19th century in Germany, a handful of adolescents, trapped by the societal repression of the times, find themselves in the midst of adolescent urges they can neither explain nor deny.
It's a story about sex, growing older and institutionalization of youth. 
We have a stellar team of actors, director, designers and are hard at work bringing the production to the stage!
Where do you come in?
      We need your support to make this all happen, your contribution helps us share this story.
      The money we're raising will go into the production. Our $1,000 goal will go into building our set, achieving the best lighting, and getting the most optimum sound. Any profits made will go directly into our next production. 

       We have some great perks, from stickers/buttons, signed posters, shoutouts, to reserved seating for a show! 
Why are we doing it?

story:
Summary

My work animates questions of identity and centers on relationships.  I value seeing the body in a spectrum from virtuosic spontaneity to blunt gestural unison.  My aesthetics insist on attention to revolving state-based material for example a sense of loneliness, or control, or tenderness, or humor, or dissonance, or ritual, or a combination; resulting in multi-dimensional layering of physical and vocal expressivity. Themes in my work comprise of collective humanity; how we exist in our mundane and extraordinary socio-cultural environments.​

The Impact

I am one of 43 grant award recipients – 26 Latinx artists, 17 arts organizations – awarded through NALAC (National Association of Latino Arts and Cultures) Fund for the Arts. This requires that I raise a matching amount through fundraising.  This campaign will ensure I accomplish this goal!

Additionally, any contribution will support us rolling out development of Blood Language in four phases:

Phase 1:  January - May 2019 Currently creating our first iteration of Blood Language to be presented May 3rd as part of the Candy Box Dance Festival Happy Hour program.  Through the Generating Room Open Proposal program we will present free workshops and a Lecture/Demonstration inform and share our creation process. 

Phase 2:  August - October 2019 A custom made residency with New Movement Collaborative culminating in a shared evening performance in Boston, MA.

Phase 3:  February - April 2020 Residency with the National Center of Choreography in Akron, Ohio as supported in part by the McKnight Foundation.

Phase 4:  2020/2021 Minneapolis premiere of Blood Language.

Meet the Collaborators:

Anat Shinar (Collaborator, Performer)

Marggie Ogas (Collaborator, Performer)

Marisol Herling (Collaborator, Performer)

Marcela Michelle (Rehearsal Director)

Taja Will (Choreographer, Performer)

Laura Larson (Songwriter)

Carlisle Evan Peck (Songwriter)

Photo by Bill Cameron

Genevieve Johnson (Project Administrator)

Blood Language will also include contributions from b.a. musser (sound designer) and Michael Wall (SoundForMovement) and  photographer Isabel Fajardo, her images are featured as the central promotional images for the work. 

 

Risks & Challenges

We are only giving ourselves 30 days to raise this $8,000!  Although a challenging timeline for our end goal, but reflects a realistic and critical amount of financial capital to support artistic labor in a equitable way and to leverage our upcoming tour residency opportunities. By traveling with these artists and this work we create more visibility for it's social justice content and create deep relationships for each artists to new communities and those communities to the Twin Cities arts. 

The risk for contributing is very low; all funds will be used to support Blood Language collaborators labor and travel, set design, marketing and administrative support.

Other Ways You Can Help

Support comes in many shapes and forms; if financial contribution is something you cannot commit to now, please help us spread the news about this campaign!  We hope to continue building community through this process!

story:
The IRNE Awards

The Independent Reviewers of New England proudly present the IRNE Awards.  Each year, we host the biggest party for greater Boston’s theater community for an evening of celebration and appreciation of a year in the theater.  There are nominees in 54 categories, recognizing the companies, directors, playwrights, actors, designers, and choreographers who strive to keep Boston’s audiences enthralled with vibrant, exciting and challenging theater.

On April 7, we present the 2014 IRNE Awards, and remain fully committed to it being the biggest party of the year in the theater community – and we insist it’s FREE to attend, no ticket required, all are welcome to celebrate the theater community.

The IRNE Committee is comprised of theater critics dedicated to celebrating the extraordinary talent in Boston Theater Community. 

This year, for the first time, we invite you to assist us in this celebration and, more importantly, to shine a spotlight on theater artists and companies large and small by becoming a supporter of the IRNE Awards.

What We Need & What You Get

It’s central to our mission that attending the IRNE Awards is free and open to all and that the whole world knows about it.  We are blessed to be generously hosted again this year at the Cyclorama by the Boston Center for the Arts, this year we need some additional assistance. 

We plan to celebrate those that help make this party happen, and this is where you come in.  All contributors will be recognized at the party – traditionally attended by over 500 theater artists, supporters, and friends.  Let them know you appreciate their work, and that all their work, nominated or not, is a critical part of Boston’s cultural landscape.

Make no mistake – the nominees and the winners are the star of this show and we are gathered to thank and appreciate them and all who strive to bring magic to the stage.  But we all benefit from their contributions to art of theater, their talents, and their exploration of humanity on our stages. 

It is a community that work hard and all too frequently for few rewards, the IRNE Award is a small way to celebrate the achievements of some, but the impact of all.  Please join us in making this celebration worthy of their work.

The Impact

Contributions will be dedicated to practical things like rental of a sound system (so everyone can hear who the winners are), an audiovisual show (so everyone can see what the nominees look like), something to eat, and to promote what is the BIGGEST theater awards program in New England. 

Contributions at any level will be appreciated and recognized at the event. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We’ll confess – it’s been suggested we just sell the tickets.  We refuse.  All are welcome.  No ticket required.

Many in the theater community work hard often for little or no pay, some even spend their own money on shows and give it their all.  Whether nominated or simply wishing to applaud their colleagues, we refuse to charge anyone an entrance fee. It’s your party.

If you are not in a position to contribute, please share this campaign with any who’d like to help us celebrate.  A share on your Facebook page, a Tweet, and email to a few friends – every bit helps and we thank you.

story:
Short Summary

This campaign was created to help compensate the dancers for the work done outside of rehearsals to bring this project to a more diverse audience with greater impact, to pave the way for future residencies, tours, and partnerships. The Recognizing Women Project was inaugurated in 2001 with several of its pieces performed for years before. Each year the project brings together a multi-cultural group of around 25 female dancers, ages 16-45, and university students in the social sciences to work as a multi-disciplinary research analysis team. The mission is to help women develop an inter-sectional understanding of their experiences and to share their understandings through community dialogue and public presentation. We feel that the more research we pour into the project, the more urgency we have to share our stories and spark others to do the same. Though emotionally challenging and physically demanding, this work is a labor of love. At the core of it we find undeniable strength and serenity that runs within all women, ready to be awakened and energized.

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $10,000. The Recognizing Women Project includes 6 months of rehearsals and many dancers. The money raised through this campaign will go to the dancers; compensation for the hours of work in the studio and especially, for the time given outside of rehearsals as part of our commitment to sharing this project. Because we value your support tremendously, we’re further offering our time with perks as unique as we are, hopefully as a way to get to know our supporters too. Do you know someone who may need certified tutoring for 7-12th grade? Been wanting to try AntiGravity yoga or the GYROTONIC® Method? Maybe you just haven’t taken Nathan’s class in a while and want to join us for company class and rehearsal! We want to share these experiences and other services with you!

The Impact

Today, women are standing up and telling their stories, and in doing so, encouraging others to. The Recognizing Women Project is a platform for women to connect deeper and experience the strength that lives within vulnerability. It has created a space where women regularly witness each other share experiences by which they once felt isolated. These testimonials from past projects show the lifelong impact of the work we're doing today.

  • "[The RWP] allowed me to connect with women of all different cultural backgrounds and relate to one another on an emotional and intellectual level" 2017 Participant
  • "I learned sisterhood from the work I did with fellow cast members" 2011 Participant
  • "The investigative process was really rewarding, and helped me to go deeper into my own identity, understand my heritage, my past and see how it fits into the present." 2002 participant
  • "Recognizing the fact that our existence is something to behold" 1996 Participant

Risks & Challenges

The challenges we face are ones that many NY residents and artists will understand. We spend hours commuting on trains going to and from rehearsals, jobs, and second (maybe third) jobs. We also know that there are many small companies and projects in need of support. The dancing, administrative and organizational work for the RWP however, has lent us a space to heal from the challenges of our personal histories and from female objectification. It has given us a community to depend on throughout that healing, and ultimately, this allows us to meet and exceed these challenges with spirited energy to be thrifty and determined! This is what must be shared, and what your donations will allow us to continue to share.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot give at this time, or if you're looking for more ways to help us achieve our goal:

  • SHARE this campaign with your friends and colleagues! (If you'd like, you can follow us on social media for easier link sharing too... Facebook: nathantrice/RITUALS dance theater and Instagram: @ntrituals
  • Buy tickets and invite your friends and colleagues to our performances March 15th and 16th at LIU's Kumble Theatre (Tickets available at: kumbletheater.tix.com)
  • If you know of organizations that may be interested in investing in our project, please email your suggestions and contacts to campaign.nathantricerituals@gmail.com
  • Volunteer to be a stage hand at one our our performances (https://www.dance.nyc/for-audiences/community-c...

story:
Pittsfield Shakespeare in the Park aims to provide a highly engaging, vital and accessible theatrical experience to Pittsfield’s underserved and diverse community via a free, outdoor production of a Shakespeare play in one of the city’s municipal parks.

This summer, we'll be producing Shakespeare's classic, magical comedy  A Midsummer Night's Dream in Springside Park, featuring a cast of local professionals mixed with students from elementary through high school.



Why Shakespeare?

Shakespeare was born 450 years ago this month. His plays are filled with magic, poetry and unforgettable characters — there's a reason we still read and perform his plays. For kids, only Shakespeare's themes are large enough to capture the bigness of the world. By presenting the show for free, we're lowering the barrier to entry for live theatre for many families.



We need your help.

In order to produce the show, we need to raise money to rent the lights and sound equipment, costumes, sets, and to hire the technicians, stage managers, and actors to put it all together.




Match Grant provided by Berkshire Money Management!

We made it!

Thanks to our contributors so far, Lead Sponsor Berkshire Money Management will generously match the first $5,000 raised here on Indiegogo in the first ten days!

story:
Hi!

We are The MoveShop, a dance theater company based in Brooklyn, NY and headed by Artistic Director Leslie Guyton.  Over the last nine years, we've produced five full length works and two short works, many of which have toured various parts of the country.  Our last piece, Racine D'or, was a collaborative project with Grammy nominated musician Cedric Watson and his band Bijou Creole and toured the southern U.S. last fall.  After a short respite, we're back in the studio and hard at work on our next project.

This new dance theater piece You Absolute Dreamer, inspired by F. Scott Fitzgerald's magnum opus The Great Gatsby, is the first time we've turned to a piece of text for inspiration.  We've begun to find our own relationships to the themes of Fitzgerald's novel and how it pertains to our lives in society today; how the characters continue to be reflected in our everyday lives; how we function within a world where great excess and crippling destitution coexist.  This outlook on the work has created new and exciting challenges as we explore how to translate our ideas onto the theatrical spectrum in a fashion that not only communicates our passion for the project, but also challenges ourselves and the audience to see something new within a classic piece of literature.  The themes and images of Gatsby are still prevalent today, and we aim to shed a new and innovative light upon them.

We're set to premiere the piece this fall in New York City.  A project of this magnitude requires not only time, dedication, and imagination, but also funds to pay for rehearsal space, sets, costumes, props, and performer fees.  Your support will help make this new and exciting piece of dance theater an incredible reality.


What We Need & What You Get

Our campaign on IndieGogo is one of the many avenues we are utilizing to fund this piece.  On this platform, our goal is $8000.  This amount will go toward the purchase of rehearsal space in New York City, costumes, set pieces, lighting, and artist fees.  

Donating to us through IndieGogo has some fantastic perks!  They range from buttons and totebags to flights to NYC and massages!  Unlike our other avenues for seeking funding, you are the only ones receiving memorabilia, and much more for your generous contributions!  Check out what we have to offer on the right side column!


The Impact

One of the many aspects of this work that we find exciting is its relevance to society today.  Our last production was an exploration of folklore within an established culture, and was met with acclaim in the cities we visited on tour.  This new piece, however, presents the opportunity for us to dive into the societal stigmas of not only the 1920s but also of today.  As with our last productions, we are excited to not only bring you an evening of lively entertainment but also a piece of dance theater that shines a new light onto the way you may see the world around you.  Art, at its best, is a mirror that simultaneously flatters and challenges the viewer...and that's what we aim to do. 


Other Ways You Can Help

If you find this project exciting and want to help but are unable to contribute financially, please feel free to contact us!  We love an extra hand in the creation of our work, and there are many methods to help spread the word.  Find us at:  www.moveshop.org.

story:
Smashworks Dance Collective, directed by choreographer Ashley McQueen, is a New York-based group of movers dedicated to the strengthening of artistic voice and experiential movement. Originally founded in St. Louis amidst performances presented by ANNONYArts, Smashworks relocated to New York City in 2015.

 

Who We Are 

My name is Ashley McQueen, and I am a dancer, choreographer, and Artistic Director for Smashworks Dance Collective. Originally from Alabama, I received my BFA in Dance from Webster University and danced professionally in St. Louis for two years while choreographing throughout the area. I am currently pursuing my MFA in Dance from Hollins University, class of 2018.

Over a year ago I gave away my car, sold my furniture, and moved from St. Louis to New York with two suitcases and a dream to build a dance company that ignites passion, prompts conversation, and showcases the value of the arts in society. 

Last year, Smashworks performed at eight festivals across the five boroughs, including a 30-minute work presented by Take Root at Green Space in Long Island City. This year we will highlight  eight talented dancers in performances ranging from windows on Wall Street to a winery in Santa Barbara as part of a bi-coastal collaborative tour.

The Company

This is Smashworks' second New York season, and we are embarking on our first evening length production this January. We are thrilled to present three original works inspired by experiences of real people throughout the city. These pieces feature scenes that every New Yorker will recognize, from the grittiness of the morning subway commute to the socio-economic melting pot of daily life on and around Wall Street. Eight brilliant performers will bring these scenes to life on stage, providing an evocative audience experience that will encourage reflection and dialogue about what it means to be a New Yorker.

Performers: Laurie Deziel, Jesse Obremski, Sarah Dodd, Maria Gardner, Evelyn Joy Hoelscher, Ellen Sickenberger, Sarah Starkweather, Maria Vittoria Villa, and Ashley McQueen. 

     

    What We Need & What You Get

    Our evening length performance will take place at the Center for Performance Research "CPR" on Saturday, January 21 and Sunday, January 22, 2017 at 7:30pm. Theater performances are expensive, and we need your help to bring this experience to life.  Your support will contribute directly to dancer wages, theater rental, costume design, and rehearsal space. The full cost of the performance is detailed below:

    • Theater rental for two evening performances: $1300
    • Event insurance: $400
    • Dancer wages [8 dancers]: $2500
    • Rehearsal space rental: $500
    • Costume design: $200
    • Performance Advertising: $100

    Total Cost: $5000

    All funds raised [no matter what the campaign outcome] will go towards paying for the expenses outlined above.

    • In addition to supporting this unique, innovative performance, your contribution will also grant you access to exclusive perks available at a wide range of donation levels from a social media shout out to a personalized dance video.

    The Impact

    What does it mean to be a New Yorker?  How does New York change you? Through our performance, we hope to encourage audience members to reflect on their own New York experience and to share these insights with friends and family both within the five boroughs and beyond.

    • We provide an outlet for the audience to experience their daily lives through a new lens. This event will bring together New Yorkers from different neighborhoods and provide an environment for networking, constructive dialogue, and personal development. 
    • In each of the past four years of professional dancing and choreographing, my passion for working with dancers and bringing performances to life has grown. In creating this work, I have built upon a record of successful evening length performances in other cities, and with your support, we can bring that success to New York. 

    Risks & Challenges

    As a dancer who works five (5) jobs to cover the costs of running a successful dance company, I understand the riskiness of putting on a large production in New York. This performance is important, because it provides a paid opportunity for our dancers to perform, network in the New York dance community, and have a positive professional experience that challenges them physically and artistically.

    I also aim to present work that questions our identity as "New Yorkers." How do we define ourselves? How are we defined by others? In what ways does our environment impact our overall perception and sense of self?

    Smashworks has been my lifelong dream - and this is only the beginning! With your help it can continue to develop and provide even more opportunities for live performance, education outreach, and creative exploration.

    All photos by Stephen Delas Heras

     

    Other Ways You Can Help

    • Share our campaign on social media!
    • Stay in touch - Follow us on Facebook/Instagram or visit our website to join our mailing list!
    • Spread the word about Smashworks - and our upcoming performances!
story_txt:
Smashworks Dance Collective, directed by choreographer Ashley McQueen, is a New York-based group of movers dedicated to the strengthening of artistic voice and experiential movement. Originally founded in St. Louis amidst performances presented by ANNONYArts, Smashworks relocated to New York City in 2015.
 
Who We Are 
My name is Ashley McQueen, and I am a dancer, choreographer, and Artistic Director for Smashworks Dance Collective. Originally from Alabama, I received my BFA in Dance from Webster University and danced professionally in St. Louis for two years while choreographing throughout the area. I am currently pursuing my MFA in Dance from Hollins University, class of 2018.
Over a year ago I gave away my car, sold my furniture, and moved from St. Louis to New York with two suitcases and a dream to build a dance company that ignites passion, prompts conversation, and showcases the value of the arts in society. 
Last year, Smashworks performed at eight festivals across the five boroughs, including a 30-minute work presented by Take Root at Green Space in Long Island City. This year we will highlight  eight talented dancers in performances ranging from windows on Wall Street to a winery in Santa Barbara as part of a bi-coastal collaborative tour.

story:
Summary

Broads' Word Ensemble came together when seven women sat down and said: “there’s a scarcity of strong roles for women in the theatre. Let’s change that.”

So we are.

After three successful productions in two years, we are ready to expand. Join Broads’ Word Ensemble for our first full season as we continue our charge to break barriers and shatter ceilings for women artists and female representation.

  • In the spring, we’re presenting Barbara Kahn’s docu-comedy The Lady Was a Gentleman. The play follows one of America’s greatest unknown actresses of the 1800’s, Charlotte Cushman, a lesbian who played both male and female roles, as she encounters a host of other women and their exploits. 
  • In June, we're putting our stamp on a classic by a female playwright from “The Other Canon” for the Hollywood Fringe Festival.
  • In the fall, we are partnering with the Los Angeles Female Playwrights Initiative (LAFPI) to host a staged reading festival for original 10-minute plays or short excerpts from original full-length scripts from Los Angeles based female playwrights. 

Can we count on your support to make this production a reality? Please contribute however you can today, and be a part of this journey.

What We Need & What You Get

We need at least $16,500 to fund the three performances of our first full season. Our projected expenses break down like this:

  • $7,500 actor and production team compensation
  • $5,700 venue rent and insurance
  • $2,100 production materials
  • $1,200 promotion

Additional funds would increase our production value, participant compensation, and allow for more participants to join our season.

Since you are supporting live theatre, a contribution as small as $25 already gets you a ticket to Barbara Kahn’s The Lady Was a Gentleman.

Want to secure seats to the entire season? We have several options to ensure you never miss a performance.

The Impact

Our goal is to create a space and forum for emerging female artists throughout Los Angeles in a field overwhelmingly dominated by men.

In a theatrical climate where there are always an abundance of talented actresses and very few good roles for them to bring to life, Broads' Word Ensemble is dedicated to letting those actresses shine in a way you've never seen them before.

Hand in hand with our mission of putting women on stage, we support parity across all areas of theatre. Our productions are geared toward providing substantive, creative opportunities for women in theatre as performers, directors, writers, producers, and all other aspects of the craft.

Risks & Challenges

As experienced theatre practitioners dedicated to parity in Los Angeles theatre, Broads' Word Ensemble will use every dollar we raise for our 2017 season. The biggest challenges are funding for participant compensation and venue rent. If we are not fully funded, the scope of the season and/or the compensation we are able to offer our participants may decrease.

Tax Deductible Donation

Broads' Word Ensemble 2017 Season is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Broads' Word Ensemble 2017 Season must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

All perks require your shipping information, so Fractured Atlas can issue tax receipts. 

To receive the largest benefit from your donation, you can choose not to receive a perk. The non-deductible value of some perk items (such as the face value of tickets to our shows) will reduce the tax-deductible value of your donation.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute right now, we totally get it! There are non-monetary ways you can lend a hand...

  • When you see our Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram posts, share 'em! Helping us get the word out is huge, and we really appreciate it -- not just for this campaign, but for the good of the company in general.
  • Have you had a great time at a Broads' Word show? Tell the world! If you share our fundraising link along with an anecdote about how worthwhile our work is, that's huge. 
  • If you know someone who is a patron of the arts (or wants to be), let them specifically know about Broads' Word and our campaign! 
  • Have we posted a picture that entertained you or article that caught your eye? Pass that along to your pals, and include our good ol' fundraiser link. (Pretty sneaky, sis.)
  • Basically, tell your mama, tell your friends, tell anyone whose heart can comprehend. Send it in a letter baby, tell them on the phone, we're not the kind of Broads who like to work alone. (Are we paraphrasing Janet Jackson? Uh, that's Miss Jackson if you're nasty. And yes.)

story:
The goal of this campaign is simple -- to raise money to better compensate actors who are pursuing their dream of making a living on stage. I am self-funding and self-producing the world premiere of my play "With Hidden Noise" as part of the New York Theater Festival.                        (http://newyorktheaterfestival.com/with-hidden-n...). The play will run on August 9, 10, and 13.

I am paying the four very talented actors what I consider to be a modest stipend, but they deserve to be paid more. That's the point of this campaign. 100% of the donations will go to the actors. Not one cent will go to me to pay for the production.

The four actors in my cast are pursuing their dream and are acting because they love working in live theater. They recognize how competitive theater is in New York and they are willing to work for low pay. This campaign is an attempt to reward them beyond what I can afford to pay, to show that others value their work and the dream they're pursuing.

I'm not offering fabulous perks as thanks for donations because I suspect that most people who will donate will do so because they value live theater and want actors to be fairly paid for their work. But, I do want to thank you for donating, so for every $50 donation, you will receive a copy of the play, signed by the playwright, director and entire cast. For every $100 donation, you will receive a signed copy of the play plus a link to a video of the play.
