story:
I am Gemma Wilcox, actor/playwright/director/producer of Gemma Wilcox Productions. Born and raised in London, UK, I am now based in majestical Boulder, Colorado where I have been living, breathing and creating theatre for the past 10 years.  

Some you know me, but for those of you that don't here is a little bit about me and my work:

  • I am a strong believer in the power of GREAT, heartfelt live theatre to awaken, enliven and inspire the human spirit!
  • Since 2001, I have been creating, writing, performing and producing original, highly physical, heart-fully humorous, tenderly moving, and deeply authentic theatre.  
  • I have written 5 one-woman, multi-character shows, and 2 two-person shows,  and toured them to 36 fringe festivals across USA and Canada. 
  • My shows have received 14 'Best-of-Fest' Awards.

THIS SUMMER, I am thrilled beyond belief to be performing 3 of my 1-woman shows, for 28 performances, at 6 different theatres, over 3 months, in 5 cities, in 2 countries!

I have been touring across Canada and USA since 2003, and have never done a fundraising campaign, but this year the tour costs are way more than they have ever been!  Seriously! For instance, Edmonton Fringe Festival alone is $5000 in sheer expenses!

SO...

♥ This summer I need your help to produce and offer my work in the following places:

  • July 9-13, 2014 - REGINA, CANADA - The Honeymoon Period is Officially Over @ Regina Fringe Festival
  • July 25, 2014 - BOULDER, CO - Magical Mystery Detour @ Wesley Chapel Theatre
  • Aug 14-24, 2014 - EDMONTON, CANADA - The Honeymoon Period is Officially Over @ Edmonton Fringe Festival
  • Aug 22-31 - 2014 - VICTORIA, CANADA - Magical Mystery Detour @ Victoria Fringe Festival
  • Sep 17-28, 2014 - BOULDER, CO - Shadows in Bloom @ Boulder Fringe Festival
  • Oct 11, 2014 - NEW YORK, NY-Extract from shows @ Emerging Women Conference

What I Need & What You Get

In order to successful and sanely execute this tour without breaking the bank I intend to raise at least $12,000* to cover my basic expenses! 

Check out the sexy pie chart below (designed by the lovely and talented Kelly Sosan Bearer), to see what your money goes towards. 

*PLEASE NOTE: The $12,000 I am aiming to raise does not cover all of my tour expenses this summer. The actual expenses are $15,000 for all the production and touring costs, and this does not include paying myself as the performer .

Expenses for Gemma's Summer Tour 2014

Now...if you donate to this campaign you can get some extra sweet perks (and each perk includes the perk before it!) that are even sexier than this pie chart!  These include VIP tickets to any Gemma Wilcox show, signed copies of the show soundtrack, happy hour drinks with the artists....AND, if you really throw in the big bucks you can get a 1:1 creativity session with Gemma, name a character in the show, or become an executive producer of the show (whilst getting a sweet tax break! ;-))  

Pretty Awesome!

    The Impact

    *** YOU WILL BE SUPPORTING GREAT ART! ***

    By contributing to this campaign:

    • YOU make it completely possible - and a lot less stressful! - for me to tour USA and Canada this summer offering my award-winning work. 
    • YOU support important work which explores and illuminates intimate relationships, the mundane and sacred aspects of our day to day human existence, and the beautiful and sometimes terrifying roller-coaster ride that is this life -  I believe that is pretty darn important! :-)
    • YOU help me to smoothly, sanely, professionally and successfully execute this tour and reach as many audience members as possible with my shows that have received incredible reviews such as:

    "Wilcox is a master of the theatre"                                                                                       -The Victoria Times Colonist

    “A Sybil-esque multiple-personalitied solo performance virtuoso.”
    – Denver Westword 

    “She holds her audience in thrall. This woman can do anything, it seems, and she does...she shows you what theater can be."                                                             – Elizabeth Maupin, Orlando Sentinel        

    "You might not see a better performance at this year's festival than the one Gemma Wilcox delivers in this solo comedy”                                                                  – Kevin Prokosh, The Winnipeg Free Press

    “Wilcox is a shape-shifter extraordinaire."                                                                      – Patrick Langston, Ottawa Citizen

    "Gemma Wilcox is both an adroit chronicler of the human condition and a wondrous chameleon of a performer.”                                                                                
     – Minneapolis Pioneer Press

    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you cannot contribute financial - or even if you can - you can also help this campaign in other ways, such as:

    • Please use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the news of this campaign far and wide...
    • Shout out about this campaign from hill and mountain top, on street corners, and whisper into your friends ears about it! :-)  AKA please spread the word on Facebook, Twitter and all such lovely social media sites!
    • Send emails to those in your communities that you think may be interested in supporting.

      And Last, but Not Least...

      Deepest gratitude to you all for taking the time to read about this campaign, your contributions, your word-spreading, your love and care...and support of my work in the world in all the ways you do!

      With Love and Creative Oomph,

      Gemma <3 
      _____________________________________________________________________________

      Update #1

      The Honeymoon Period is Officially Over Gets 4.5 Stars from Edmonton Journal

      The Honeymoon Period is Officially Over

      "4.5 stars out of 5

      Stage 48, Rutherford School

      Gemma Wilcox is an amazing party favour for first-time visitors to the Fringe festivities. Her solo show, The Honeymoon Period is Officially Over, returning here after five years away, is a reminder of what theatre can be.

      Physical theatre and multiple role-playing are her specialties, with everything in play, including inanimate objects. In this funny-sad tale of a foundering romance, Wilcox shifts seamlessly from female to male characters but she slips just as comfortably into the skin of a house pet. She’s a saxophone at one point; a flaming fire you simply must stare into; the most astonishing peacock in all the world.

      A wickedly flexible body, a sly wit, and a riveting stage presence conjure up a virtuoso performance. Run to see her, brush up to a jolt of pure energy.

      We come to learn that this British-born dynamo, now based in Boulder, Col., packs along these multiple personalities on an almost constant tour schedule. Can such wild versatility be snapped on and off like a kitchen light? It makes you wonder who Wilcox is when she’s alone."

      — Richard Helm

      _______________________________________________________________________________

      Update #2

      The Honeymoon Period is Officially Over SOLD-OUT Three Nights in a Row

      Gemma Wilcox's "The Honeymoon Period is Officially Over" sold out three nights in a row at the Edmonton International Fringe Festival. A total of 900+ people came to see the 10 year anniversary run of Wilcox's first show. 

      She's now in Victoria, BC, running "Magical Mystery Detour" the third installation of her trilogy. But don't worry, all her shows stand alone, so tell all your friends in Victoria to come out and see "Magical Mystery Detour". 

      VENUE: Venue #2 - Downtown Activity Centre (755 Pandora Ave)

      TICKETS: $11 – Buy at: http://www.victoriafringe.com/

      SCHEDULE: 
      Mon Aug 25 @ 6:00pm 
      Tue Aug 26 @ 8:45pm 
      Wed Aug 27 @ 6:30pm
      Thu Aug 28 @ 8:45pm 
      Sat Aug 30 @ 7:15pm 
      Sun Aug 31 @ 2pm

      _______________________________________________________________________________

      Update #3

      Magical Mystery Detour - The Interview

      For veteran performer Gemma Wilcox her third time at the Victoria Fringe is more than a charm, it’s a pleasure. Especially as she’s arriving with a sparkling new award-winning multi-character, one-woman show, Magical Mystery Detour.

      Who is Gemma Wilcox?

      Good question.  Well, addressing the performer part of me, here goes: I am the actor/playwright/director/producer of Gemma Wilcox Productions. Born and raised in London, U.K., I am now based in majestic Boulder, Colorado, where I have been living, breathing and creating theatre for the past 10 years.

      I am a strong believer in the power of great, heartfelt live theatre to awaken, enliven, and inspire the human spirit. Since 2001, I have been creating, writing, performing and producing original, highly physical, heart-fully humorous, tenderly moving, and deeply authentic theatre. I have written five one-woman multi-character shows, and two two-person shows, and toured them to 36 fringe festivals across the U.S.A. and Canada. 

      With Magical Mystery Detour, you get back on the Fringe circuit for the third time. After all this time, does the process of creation and development become even easier and more organic or does the danger of being static get bigger and the discovery of originality even harder?

      Actually, I have been touring three of my one-woman shows for past 10 years.  But this is my third time in Victoria. I think it does, on the whole, become a wee bit easier and organic, and it certainly helps that people remember you from previous years.  Yes, it can be challenging to keep things fresh and present, but I actually love that particular challenge; every show I aim to perform it as if it was my first time ever.

      So what can audiences expect to find on the Magical Mystery Detour? Besides a nostalgic show title.  

      Well, it is a magical mystery detour, not tour. So humor, laughter, maybe tears, frustration, feeling like you are going one way in life and then realize that life has other plans for you, blocked roads, detour signs, letting go, release, and opening up to the mystery of life.

      Out of the other runners in this year’s Fringe, whom would you recommend that audiences check out? If you don’t mind throwing fuel to the competition.

      Definitely see the Wonderheads new show, and shows by TJ Dawe, Steve Larkin, Travis Burnhardt, Nancy Kenny, Jem Rolls, and I heard Kit and Jane were pretty awesome. 

      Where does a performer with your experience draw their inspiration? 

      My life. All my shows are semi-autobiographical. I love exploring the mundane and sacred aspects of intimate relationship. 

      What advice would you share with first time Fringe performers? 

      Flyer like crazy, don’t be shy to ask fringe veterans for advice, rest and eat well, work hard and gently and play hard and gently, make sure you take days off, hit the streets and poster as soon as you arrive. 

      14 Best of Fest’s is certainly nothing to scoff at. I’m curious, do you use this as a measure of experience or a spur to make you work even harder at your material? 

      Both. When I am feeling a little insecure about writing a new show, it’s great to remember that I can write and create successful work. I am always trying to create work that brings me to my edge as a performer. I just need to listen to what is inspiring for me and exciting and challenging in my life at the time. But mostly, at the end of the day, the awards help the most with publicity.

      What’s the best thing about being a performer/working in the arts and alternatively what’s the most challenging/frustrating? Besides money of course. 

      I love and feel very grateful to be doing what I love and making the majority of my living from doing what I love to do. The lack of consistency in income is a little challenging. The lottery of the fringe festival applications is also a bit tricky when trying to plan my summer work schedule. I get to explore and embody many aspects of myself and the human condition, and animals and inanimate objects in my case.

      In the next few years, I’m curious in what direction you’d like to develop your work towards? Do you think you’re on the right path at the moment?

      Wow, intense question. And one I have been chewing over a lot myself at the ripe old age of 36. Over the next year I have decided to shift my creative attention to creating a program where I will be teaching workshops and helping artists unblock areas in their creative expression where they feel held back and stuck.  I will still tour the fringes in the summer, with my three one-woman shows, and then most likely create a new show in the winter of next year. I believe this is the right path for me right now.

      What are you most excited to share with audiences in this piece?

      The simple joy of the dog character I play, and the talking car and Queen characters. I am also excited to see how the slightly more esoteric aspects of this show land with audiences in Victoria. 

      Ultimately, why should audiences come and see the Magical Mystery Detour?  

      Because you will be taken away on a theatrical magical mystery ride.

      The Magical Mystery Detour will perform at the Downtown Activity Centre (755 Pandora) on:

      Mon 25 - 6:00pm

      Tues 26 - 8:45pm

      Wed 27 - 6:30pm

      Thur 28 - 8:45pm

      Sat 30 - 7:15pm

      Sun 31 - 2:00pm

      Tickets are $11+ fringe button
      Tickets are available at the door, and online at http://sa1.seatadvisor.com/sabo/servlets/TicketRequest?eventId=936067&presenter=INTREPID&venue&event&version
      (and through www.victoriafringe.com )

      _______________________________________________________________________________

      Update #4

      Victoria Fringe : Magical Mystery Detour

      I unfortunately missed a show last night due to my inability to arrive at a venue fast enough, so I was only able to catch the opening performance of Magical Mystery Detour by Gemma Wilcox. I had previously spoken to the performer while she was at the Edmonton Fringe about her show and what Victoria can expect. Before the show, I had only recently heard of her previous work that has won awards all over the continent. All I knew walking in was that I was going to watch Wilcox’s character of Sandra take a journey that would follow some twists and turns. What I didn’t expect was the well-crafted one woman show that not only told a story, but proved to be one of the most relatable pieces of theatre I have seen in a long time.


      Sandra is a single woman with a career, friends, a dog, and a seemingly normal life. The audience learns early on that her mother has recently passed, and this is clearly a weight Sandra carries. Wilcox’s performance was not just of Sandra but of many other characters including people, inanimate objects, and various animals. The other characters brought humour to the piece but also brought the audience closer to the performance. The play was full of truth with a magnifying glass directed at the insecurities of your mid-30s, and was easy to connect to. The play altogether was more light than heavy, with plenty of laughs through the characters and Sandra’s quirks. It was just plain entertaining to watch Wilcox perform and I think is definitely a play to see at this year’s Fringe.

      In case you missed it, you can listen to my interview with Gemma below: 

      https://soundcloud.com/cfuv/victoria-fringe-mag...

      Magical Mystery Detour continues at the Downtown Activity Centre from August 26th-31st.


      Until next time,
      Phoenix
story_txt:
I am Gemma Wilcox, actor/playwright/director/producer of Gemma Wilcox Productions. Born and raised in London, UK, I am now based in majestical Boulder, Colorado where I have been living, breathing and creating theatre for the past 10 years.  
Some you know me, but for those of you that don't here is a little bit about me and my work:


I am a strong believer in the power of GREAT, heartfelt live theatre to awaken, enliven and inspire the human spirit!
Since 2001, I have been creating, writing, performing and producing original, highly physical, heart-fully humorous, tenderly moving, and deeply authentic theatre.  
I have written 5 one-woman, multi-character shows, and 2 two-person shows,  and toured them to 36 fringe festivals across USA and Canada. 

My shows have received 14 'Best-of-Fest' Awards.



THIS SUMMER, I am thrilled beyond belief to be performing 3 of my 1-woman
shows, for 28 performances, at 6 different theatres, over 3 months, in 5 cities, in 2 countries!
I
have been touring across Canada and USA since 2003, and have never done a fundraising campaign, but this year the tour
costs are way more than they have ever been!  Seriously! For instance, Edmonton Fringe Festival alone is $5000 in sheer expenses!
SO...
♥ This
summer I need your help to produce and offer my work in the following places:





July
     9-13, 2014 - REGINA, CANADA - The Honeymoon Period is Officially Over @
     Regina Fringe Festival

July
     25, 2014 - BOULDER, CO - Magical
     Mystery Detour @ Wesley Chapel
     Theatre



Aug
     14-24, 2014 - EDMONTON, CANADA - The Honeymoon Period is Officially Over @
     Edmonton Fringe Festival



Aug
     22-31 - 2014 - VICTORIA, CANADA - Magical Mystery Detour @
     Victoria Fringe Festival



Sep 17-28, 2014 - BOULDER, CO - Shadows in Bloom @ Boulder Fringe Festival



Oct
     11, 2014 - NEW YORK, NY-Extract from shows @ Emerging Women Conference




What I Need & What You Get In order to successful and sanely execute this tour without breaking the bank I intend to raise at least $12,000* to cover my basic expenses! 
Check out the sexy pie chart below (designed by the lovely and talented Kelly Sosan Bearer), to see what your money goes towards. 
*PLEASE NOTE: The $12,000 I am aiming to raise does not cover all of my tour expenses this summer. The actual expenses are $15,000 for all the production and touring costs, and this does not include paying myself as the performer .

Expenses for Gemma's Summer Tour 2014



Now...if you donate to this campaign you can get some extra sweet perks (and each perk includes the perk before it!) that are even sexier than this pie chart!  These include VIP tickets to any Gemma Wilcox show, signed copies of the show soundtrack, happy hour drinks with the artists....AND, if you really throw in the big bucks you can get a 1:1 creativity session with Gemma, name a character in the show, or become an executive producer of the show (whilst getting a sweet tax break! ;-))  
Pretty Awesome!




The Impact



*** YOU WILL BE SUPPORTING GREAT ART! ***
 By contributing to this campaign:


YOU make it completely possible - and a lot less stressful! - for me to tour USA and Canada this summer offering my award-winning work. 
YOU support important work which explores and illuminates intimate relationships, the mundane and sacred aspects of our day to day human existence, and the beautiful and sometimes terrifying roller-coaster ride that is this life -  I believe that is pretty darn important! :-)

YOU help me to smoothly, sanely, professionally and successfully execute this tour and reach as many audience members as possible with my shows that have received incredible reviews such as:



"Wilcox is a master of the theatre"                                                                                       -The
Victoria Times Colonist

“A Sybil-esque multiple-personalitied solo performance virtuoso.”– Denver Westword 
“She holds her audience in thrall. This woman can do anything, it seems, and she does...she shows you what theater can be."                                                             – Elizabeth Maupin, Orlando Sentinel        
"You might not
see a better performance at this year's festival than the one Gemma Wilcox
delivers in this solo comedy”                                                                  – Kevin Prokosh, The Winnipeg Free Press
“Wilcox is a
shape-shifter extraordinaire."                                                                      – Patrick Langston, Ottawa Citizen

"Gemma Wilcox is both an
adroit chronicler of the human condition and a wondrous chameleon of a
performer.”                                                                                 – Minneapolis Pioneer Press
Other Ways You Can Help
  
If you cannot contribute financial - or even if you can - you can also help this campaign in other ways, such as:

Please use the Indiegogo share tools to spread the news of this campaign far and wide...
Shout out about this campaign from hill and mountain top, on street corners, and whisper into your friends ears about it! :-)  AKA please spread the word on Facebook, Twitter and all such lovely social media sites!
Send emails to those in your communities that you think may be interested in supporting.

  

And Last, but Not Least...
Deepest gratitude to you all for taking the time to read about this campaign, your contributions, your word-spreading, your love and care...and support of my work in the world in all the ways you do!

With Love and Creative Oomph,

Gemma <3

Update #1
The Honeymoon Period is Officially Over Gets 4.5 Stars from Edmonton Journal


The Honeymoon Period is Officially Over
"4.5 stars out of 5
Stage 48, Rutherford School
Gemma Wilcox is an amazing party favour for first-time visitors to the Fringe festivities. Her solo show, The Honeymoon Period is Officially Over, returning here after five years away, is a reminder of what theatre can be.
Physical theatre and multiple role-playing are her specialties, with everything in play, including inanimate objects. In this funny-sad tale of a foundering romance, Wilcox shifts seamlessly from female to male characters but she slips just as comfortably into the skin of a house pet. She’s a saxophone at one point; a flaming fire you simply must stare into; the most astonishing peacock in all the world.
A wickedly flexible body, a sly wit, and a riveting stage presence conjure up a virtuoso performance. Run to see her, brush up to a jolt of pure energy.
We come to learn that this British-born dynamo, now based in Boulder, Col., packs along these multiple personalities on an almost constant tour schedule. Can such wild versatility be snapped on and off like a kitchen light? It makes you wonder who Wilcox is when she’s alone."
— Richard Helm
_______________________________________________________________________________
Update #2
The Honeymoon Period is Officially Over SOLD-OUT Three Nights in a Row


Gemma Wilcox's "The Honeymoon Period is Officially Over" sold out three nights in a row at the Edmonton International Fringe Festival. A total of 900+ people came to see the 10 year anniversary run of Wilcox's first show. 

She's now in Victoria, BC, running "Magical Mystery Detour" the third installation of her trilogy. But don't worry, all her shows stand alone, so tell all your friends in Victoria to come out and see "Magical Mystery Detour". 

VENUE: Venue #2 - Downtown Activity Centre (755 Pandora Ave)
TICKETS: $11 – Buy at: http://www.victoriafringe.com/
SCHEDULE: Mon Aug 25 @ 6:00pm Tue Aug 26 @ 8:45pm Wed Aug 27 @ 6:30pmThu Aug 28 @ 8:45pm Sat Aug 30 @ 7:15pm Sun Aug 31 @ 2pm

_______________________________________________________________________________
Update #3
Magical Mystery Detour - The Interview


For veteran performer Gemma Wilcox her third time at the Victoria Fringe is more than a charm, it’s a pleasure. Especially as she’s arriving with a sparkling new award-winning multi-character, one-woman show, Magical Mystery Detour.
Who is Gemma Wilcox?
Good question.  Well, addressing the performer part of me, here goes: I am the actor/playwright/director/producer of Gemma Wilcox Productions. Born and raised in London, U.K., I am now based in majestic Boulder, Colorado, where I have been living, breathing and creating theatre for the past 10 years.
I am a strong believer in the power of great, heartfelt live theatre to awaken, enliven, and inspire the human spirit. Since 2001, I have been creating, writing, performing and producing original, highly physical, heart-fully humorous, tenderly moving, and deeply authentic theatre. I have written five one-woman multi-character shows, and two two-person shows, and toured them to 36 fringe festivals across the U.S.A. and Canada. 
With Magical Mystery Detour, you get back on the Fringe circuit for the third time. After all this time, does the process of creation and development become even easier and more organic or does the danger of being static get bigger and the discovery of originality even harder?
Actually, I have been touring three of my one-woman shows for past 10 years.  But this is my third time in Victoria. I think it does, on the whole, become a wee bit easier and organic, and it certainly helps that people remember you from previous years.  Yes, it can be challenging to keep things fresh and present, but I actually love that particular challenge; every show I aim to perform it as if it was my first time ever.
So what can audiences expect to find on the Magical Mystery Detour? Besides a nostalgic show title.  
Well, it is a magical mystery detour, not tour. So humor, laughter, maybe tears, frustration, feeling like you are going one way in life and then realize that life has other plans for you, blocked roads, detour signs, letting go, release, and opening up to the mystery of life.
Out of the other runners in this year’s Fringe, whom would you recommend that audiences check out? If you don’t mind throwing fuel to the competition.
Definitely see the Wonderheads new show, and shows by TJ Dawe, Steve Larkin, Travis Burnhardt, Nancy Kenny, Jem Rolls, and I heard Kit and Jane were pretty awesome. 
Where does a performer with your experience draw their inspiration? 
My life. All my shows are semi-autobiographical. I love exploring the mundane and sacred aspects of intimate relationship. 
What advice would you share with first time Fringe performers? 
Flyer like crazy, don’t be shy to ask fringe veterans for advice, rest and eat well, work hard and gently and play hard and gently, make sure you take days off, hit the streets and poster as soon as you arrive. 
14 Best of Fest’s is certainly nothing to scoff at. I’m curious, do you use this as a measure of experience or a spur to make you work even harder at your material? 
Both. When I am feeling a little insecure about writing a new show, it’s great to remember that I can write and create successful work. I am always trying to create work that brings me to my edge as a performer. I just need to listen to what is inspiring for me and exciting and challenging in my life at the time. But mostly, at the end of the day, the awards help the most with publicity.
What’s the best thing about being a performer/working in the arts and alternatively what’s the most challenging/frustrating? Besides money of course. 
I love and feel very grateful to be doing what I love and making the majority of my living from doing what I love to do. The lack of consistency in income is a little challenging. The lottery of the fringe festival applications is also a bit tricky when trying to plan my summer work schedule. I get to explore and embody many aspects of myself and the human condition, and animals and inanimate objects in my case.
In the next few years, I’m curious in what direction you’d like to develop your work towards? Do you think you’re on the right path at the moment?
Wow, intense question. And one I have been chewing over a lot myself at the ripe old age of 36. Over the next year I have decided to shift my creative attention to creating a program where I will be teaching workshops and helping artists unblock areas in their creative expression where they feel held back and stuck.  I will still tour the fringes in the summer, with my three one-woman shows, and then most likely create a new show in the winter of next year. I believe this is the right path for me right now.
What are you most excited to share with audiences in this piece?
The simple joy of the dog character I play, and the talking car and Queen characters. I am also excited to see how the slightly more esoteric aspects of this show land with audiences in Victoria. 
Ultimately, why should audiences come and see the Magical Mystery Detour?  
Because you will be taken away on a theatrical magical mystery ride.
The Magical Mystery Detour will perform at the Downtown Activity Centre (755 Pandora) on:
Mon 25 - 6:00pm
Tues 26 - 8:45pm
Wed 27 - 6:30pm
Thur 28 - 8:45pm
Sat 30 - 7:15pm
Sun 31 - 2:00pm
Tickets are $11+ fringe buttonTickets are available at the door, and online at http://sa1.seatadvisor.com/sabo/servlets/TicketRequest?eventId=936067&presenter=INTREPID&venue&event&version(and through www.victoriafringe.com )

story:
Who are we?

We are The Song and Dance Players (or SoDa for short), a registered non-profit society in Singapore. That basically means that we are a bunch of non-professional, big-dreamin' musical theatre enthusiasts. 

And we have decided to put up our first, full-fledged musical at the end of this year (A.D. 2015), before winter solstice. To be precise, when Sleeping Beauty Awakes on 18th December to 20th December.

Contributing to this will allow us to fulfill a few things.

1) Bring to Singapore an off-beat, funny musical piece called Awaking Beauty - a cheeky postlude to the life after Princess Aurora wakes up.

2) Display the first fruits of the past 3yrs of practice in various aspects of theatre such as voice, movement, playing and acting. 

3) Entertain! Which is what we were born for! Before Life (and parents?) smacked us on the head and gave us day jobs. 


How you can help:

We then peeked into how much it would take to put up a musical in Singapore at a decent Black Box. If you help us hit...

  • $3000, it will help cover cost of copyrights, permits and licenses 
  • $9000, it will help cover cost of our performance venue
  • $15000, it will help cover cost of building sets, buying props & costumes (we won't need to mime. Yay!) 
(Apologies that you will have to help in USD, this site only accepts a select few currencies. But if you have currency difficulties, please contact us @ sodaplayers@gmail.com or your nearest SoDa member!)


Can't support financially? You can still be a SoDa angel!

We know that you want to help, but we understand financially isn't always possible. Here are some other ways you can still help:

  • Share our event's Facebook link: https://www.facebook.com/events/1640103199569100/  
  • Share our Indiegogo campaign with your friends on Facebook, Twitter, G+, and other social media
  • Share with your friends our full sponsorship video too! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SzoY2irMrpQ
  • Email us at sodaplayers@gmail.com to volunteer
